loans.name: Ana Cecilia

texts.es:
La Sra. Ana esta casada, se dedica a la venta de cd´s musicales y películas en un puesto ubicado en la Av. Buenos Aires, una zona muy concurrida y comercial de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene ya 7 años en esta actividad. Vive con su esposo y sus suegros, en la zona de Valle de las Flores, su suegra es una cliente antigua y muy puntual de nuestra institución. Su esposo trabaja como chofer asalariado en el Sindicato "Simón Bolívar", y junto a ella están ahorrando dinero para ir comprando muebles y electrodomésticos  poco a poco, no tiene hijos todavía. El crédito será invetido en la compra de mercadería como cd´s musicales, películas y demás pedidos que tiene.
La Sra Ana Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito
texts.en:
Ana is married. She works selling music and films on CD in a stall located on Buenos Aires Avenue, a very busy commercial zone in the city of La Paz. She has been doing this for 7 years. She lives with her husband and her in-laws in the Valle de las Flores ("Flower Valley") area. Her mother-in-law is a long-time and very punctual customer of our institution. Her husband works as a salaried chauffeur in the "Simón Bolívar" union, and together they are saving money to buy furniture and appliances little by little. Ana has no children yet. The loan will be invested in the purchase of merchandise like music CDs, films and other orders she has. Ana is very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust placed in her with the granting of the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Marufu

texts.en:
Marufu is a fashion designer who creates lovely Nigerian designs for his customers, who are mainly friends, residents and neighbors. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. Marufu, who hopes to be a world class designer in the future, is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials. He has a good relationship with LAPO.

Marufu, 43 and married to a petty trader, is the father of four children, all of whom he hopes to provide with a quality education. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase calves

loans.name: Maria Lourdes

texts.es:
María S. de 21 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, cuenta con agua y luz como servicio básicos. Es soltera y sin cargas familiares.

El negocio de la tienda lo inicio el papa vendiendo frutas en el mercado de la perimetral. Cuando ella cumplió la mayoría de edad empezó con una tienda pequeña en la casa de sus padres.

Ahora ella trabaja todos los días desde las 07h00 hasta las 21h00 vendiendo bebidas, arroz, azúcar, frutas etc. Una de las complicaciones del negocio es no tener un transporte para transportar la mercadería.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar colas, lácteos, arroz, para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener su propio Minimarket.
texts.en:
Twenty-one-year-old María S. lives in a peri-urban area in Perimetral de Guayaquil. She has running water and electricity in her home. She is single and has no family to support.

Her father started out by selling fruits at the perimetral market. When she came of legal age, she opened up her own small store inside her parents' home.

She now works from 7:00 am to 9:00 pm every day selling drinks, rice, sugar, fruit, etc. One of the difficulties of this business is not having the means to transport her goods.

With this loan, she will purchase soft drinks, dairy products, and rice to restock her business. In the future, she would like to start her own mini market.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase soft drinks, dairy products, and rice

loans.name: Diouma

texts.en: Diouma M. is a 70-year-old woman from the village of Maka near Diourbel in Senegal. She is married and takes care of a child. In the eight years that she has been a member of the Village Bank "Mbarry Gouytane," she has been able to pay back her loans on time. Diouma has  long experience in raising cattle and is requesting a loan to buy more cattle.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: Las Maravillas Group

texts.es:
Las Maravillas así se denomina  el Comité conformado en fecha 17 de marzo de 2008, en la Compañía Jhugua Ñaro de la Ciudad de Itá, gracias a que la Sra. Dionisia B. quien se dedica a la venta de tabacos (cigarros) y actual Directora General, se contacto con la asesora para interiorizarse de como funciona el programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras,posteriormente logró conformar su grupo con unas 17 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto con la Fundación Paraguaya .
Todas las integrantes del comité asisten a las reuniones semanales y trabajan en forma conjunta para el logro de todos los objetivos que tienen en común.
Es un grupo muy activo y solidario que se desempeñan excelentemente como tal,demuestran compañerismo y se ha formado una muy linda amistad con todas las integrantes del Comité.
Todas las mujeres son muy humildes y luchadoras así como la señora Dionisia B. quien se dedica a la fabricación y venta de cigarros, ella realiza esta actividad para ayudar a su marida quien no posee un ingreso fijo ya que es jornalero, pero juntos toda la familia procura y trata de sobresalir de la mejor manera posible.
Se citan las actividades de cada una 
1
Dionisia B.
Venta de tabacos
2
Ciriaca A.
Venta de tabacos

Heriberta A.

texts.en:
Las Maravillas is the name of this committee, established on March 17, 2008 in the Compañía Jhugua Ñaro of the City of Itá, thanks to Ms. Dionisia B., the current general director, who sells tobacco (cigars) for a living. She got in touch with the consultant to obtain information on how the Committee of Enterprising Women program works. Subsequently, she was able to start her own group of 17 women who are working contentedly with Fundación Paraguaya.

All the committee members attend weekly meetings and work in solidarity in order to achieve their common goals.

This is a very active and united group of women who fulfill their duties excellently, demonstrating comradeship. There have been some beautiful friendships formed among the members of the committee.

All of these women are humble and hardworking, like Ms. Dionisia B., who makes and sells cigars in order to help her husband, who does not have a steady job because he is a day laborer. However, the whole family works together to try to get ahead as best as they possibly can. The following are the group members and their businesses: 1 Dionisia B. Tobacco sales 2 Ciriaca A. Tobacco sales 3 Heriberta A. Tobacco sales 4 Felisa Ávalos Tobacco sales 5 Amparo Fernández Book and notions shop 6 Mariana R. General store 7 Epifania A. Tobacco sales 8 Lucia Ávalos Tobacco sales 9 Andrea Ávalos Tobacco sales 10 Laura C. Clothing, bedspread, and CD sales 11 Mirtha B. Tobacco sales 12 Josefina R. Tobacco sales 13 Perla O. Tobacco sales 14 Elisa O. Tobacco sales 15 María A. Tobacco sales 16 Lidia A. Tobacco sales 17 María C. Tobacco sales

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tobacco to make cigars

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en:
Making clothes for her customers is one business activity that Felicia loves so much. She makes lovely Nigerian and western designs for her customers and also sells tailoring materials in her stall. She hopes to own a fashion institute where she will teach young girls and boys how to sew. Felicia is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

She is 49 years old and married with three children. Her husband is a teacher who also supports the home. Felicia duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Johana Patricia

texts.es: Johana es una mujer muy popular, por lo que siempre busca la manera de salir adelante. Esta no es la primera vez que realiza financiamientos, con Fundación León 2000 por lo que siempre se ha preocupado por mejorar los ingresos necesarios de su familia. Este financiamiento que está solicitando es para comprar cosméticos como perfumes, pinturas de uñas, pinturas de labios, cremas y otros productos. Ella tiene mucho tiempo de laborar con este negocio, pues todo el tiempo se ha sacrificado por mejorar sus condiciones de vida. El deseo de ella mantener activo su negocio que es el único medio de vida que tiene.
texts.en:
Johana is a very popular woman who is always looking for a way to get ahead in life. This is not the first time she obtains microloans through Fundación León 2000 as she has always been concerned with improving the family income. The loan that she is requesting will be used to purchase cosmetics like fragrances, nail polish, lipsticks, lotions, and other beauty products. She has been in business for a long time, sacrificing a lot in order to improve her living conditions. Her desire is to keep her business afloat since it is her sole means of support.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Huguette

texts.fr: K. Huguette est née en 1963 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à POBLI Albert, un pêcheur et commerçant, Huguette est mère de trois enfants.  Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés.  La famille vit ensemble à Agbalilamè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 6 ans.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Huguette n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Huguette mène comme activité, la vente des divers produits et des condiments (tomates fraîches et conserves de tomates, piments, gingembres, épices, bicarbonate, etc.) au marché de Agbalilamé. Huguette exerce cette activité depuis 13 ans.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Huguette s’approvisionne.  Huguette a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Huguette sollicite un troisième crédit en vue de renforcer ses activités et de mieux faire face à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Huguette K. was born in 1963 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Albert POBLI, a fisherman and trader, Huguette has three children. Not all the children are at school. The family has lived together in Agbalilamé in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji for 6 years. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Huguette has never been to school. In order to meet her needs, she runs a business selling various products and condiments (fresh tomatoes, tinned tomatoes, peppers, ginger, spices, bicarbonate of soda etc.) at the market in Agbalilamé. Huguette has been carrying out this activity for 13 years. She stocks up at Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She has already had two loans from ALIDé which she has repaid. She is applying for a third loan in order to strengthen her business and to meet customer demand more readily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: K. Elisabeth est née vers 1978 à Avrankou dans le département de l’Ouémé mais vit depuis 12 ans à Kadjacomé, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin.  Mariée à AYABA Jean-Marie, un soudeur, Elisabeth est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés.  Elisabeth vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Elisabeth n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Elisabeth vend de l’akassa (aliment local préparé à base d’amidon de maïs) accompagné du poisson à son domicile.  Parallèlement à cette activité, Elisabeth a un moulin à piments, qui lui procure un certain revenu. Elisabeth exerce cette activité depuis 12 ans.  Elisabeth s’approvisionne en maïs et en poissons à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Elisabeth a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Elisabeth sollicite un troisième crédit en vue d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
Elisabeth K. was born in 1978 in Avrankou in the "département" (administrative division) of Ouémé; she has however lived for the past 12 years in Kadjacomé in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. Married to Jean-Marie AYABA, a welder, Elisabeth has five children, all of whom are at school. Elisabeth lives together with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Elisabeth has never been to school. In order to meet her needs she sells "akassa" (a local dish made from corn starch) together with fish at her home. In parallel with this activity, Elisabeth has a pepper mill, which brings in some income. She has been carrying out this activity for the past 12 years. She gets her supplies of corn and fish in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Elisabeth has already had two loans from ALIDé which she has paid back without incident. She is applying for a third loan in order to increase her stock and to boost her income.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn

loans.name: Bolaji

texts.en:
Bolaji, a businesswoman who has a beauty salon where she makes lovely hair styles for her customers, also sells hair extensions and cream at retail prices. She loves this business because she does not sell on credit; her customers pay in cash when they come to purchase hair extensions. She is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more hair extensions to sell, and she hopes to soon expand her business. 

Bolaji is 25 years old and married with two children, a five-year-old and a two-year-old, both of whom are making progress in school. Her husband sells onions and also supports the home. Bolaji duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Amy

texts.en: Amy N., a 53-year-old married mother of six children, has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. She has long experience in raising sheep and has always paid back her loans on time. With this loan she will buy sheep which she will raise and sell on the market. This activity allows Amy to improve her and her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase sheep to raise and sell

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys B. is single and has two children. She has received schooling through senior high. Gladys sells bags of water and ice-cream in Elmina. She has been doing this for sometime now. Gladys is responsible for paying school fees and utility bills.

She will use the loan to buy more bags of water and fun yogurt products for sale. She hopes to save the new profits to re-invest into her business.

loans.use: To buy more water and yogurt products for sale

loans.name: Kyakapekye Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
M. Alice, in the small photo in the top left-hand corner, is the leader of her lending group, although she does not appear in the big group photo. She is a friendly and very hardworking lady. She is married with seven children and also takes care of two dependents. 

Alice is in the business of selling produce from Kiboti trading centre. She ensures that her produce is of good quality in order to maintain her customers. She hopes to become a wholesale supplier of produce and to have a stable family. Alice needs a loan to buy more produce and increase her stock, and thereby, increase her income.

loans.use: To buy more produce for resale

loans.name: Inti Amaru

texts.es: Inti Amaru es un joven de 22 años de edad, vive en el barrio Batahola Norte, en la capital de Managua, soltero y vive junto con su papa y sus dos hermanos, su papa se desempeña como arqueólogo lo que  hace que viaje mucho poco esta con ellos, el es un joven muy esforzado y talentoso a pesar que su mama falleció hace cinco años, y la tristeza embarco a su familia no dejo sus estudios y gracias al apoyo que tuvo de sus padre concluyo su carrera, y esta trabajando desde hace dos años como contador, lo cual ha sido para el una gran oportunidad que esta aprovechando para  comenzar hacer las mejoras en su casa. Este préstamo lo quiere para construir un muro ya que se ve en la necesidad de reguardar más su vivienda para una mejor seguridad ya que la delincuencia asecha día a día, en el barrio. Lo cual comprara materiales de construcción para comenzar la obra. A futuro espera seguir mejorando las necesidades que hace falta en su casa,  que por falta de capital no había realizado, y con este financiamiento lograra el objetivo para una mejor comodidad que junto con sus hermanos espera salir adelante
texts.en:
Inti Amaru is a young man who is 22 years of age. He lives in the Batahola Norte neighborhood of the capital city of Managua. He is single and lives with his father and two brothers. His father works as an archeologist, which means that he has to travel a lot, so he does not spend much time with his sons. Inti Amaru is a hardworking and talented young man. Despite the fact that his mother passed away 5 years ago and sadness struck the family, he did not leave his studies. Thanks to his father's support, he was able to finish his degree and has been working as an accountant for 2 years, which has given him a chance to start on home improvement. He needs this loan in order to build a protective wall around his yard because he wants to provide safety from the crime that threatens his neighborhood day after day. With this loan, he will purchase construction materials to start building. In the future, he hopes to keep improving whatever is needed in his house, which he has not been able to do so far due to lack of capital. This loan will help him reach his goal of living more comfortably with his brothers so that they can get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase construction materials to build a protective wall

loans.name: Women Of Faith Group

texts.en:
Women of Faith is a group of five borrowers. The group is led by Theresa T., who is 50 years old and single with five children aged between 18 and 32 years. Theresa could not continue her education past 8th grade due to poverty.

Theresa sells doughnuts and charcoal to the residents of her community on Old Road in Monrovia. She has been running this business for 20 years, and her hope is to grow her business. Theresa started her business with 2,000 Liberian Dollars and now has 4,000 Liberian Dollars as working capital.  She maintains good business relationships with her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Theresa will use this loan to purchase more charcoal and flour to increase her doughnut production.  She dreams that one day she and her family will be able to live in better conditions.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Theresa is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP: 
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal and flour

loans.name: San Cayetano Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre San Cayetano, se conformó en fecha 20 de marzo del 2009, gracias a que la Directora General la Sra.Basilia B. que se dedica a la venta de frutas, se informó del Programa gracias a la presidenta de otro grupo que era su vecina y la misma la invitó a formar su propio grupo, la misma contacto con la asesora informándose del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y su forma de trabajo.
Cada una de las actividades que realizan las mujeres de este comité es independiente pero sin perder en sentido de pertenencia y solidad hacia el grupo.
Todas las señoras son luchadoras, como ejemplo la vida de la señora Basilia B., vendedora de frutas y verduras, ella posee una casilla al costado de la ruta donde ofrece sus productos, y al mismo tiempo debe cuidar la casa para ayudar a su marido quien se dedica a la agricultura de varios cultivos, con mucho sacrificio la familia sobrevive.
Se citan las actividades de cada integrante:

Copetín
texts.en:
The San Cayetano Women's Committee was established on March 20, 2009, thanks to the Ms. Basilia B., general director, who sells produce for a living. She learned about the program thanks to the president of another group, who was her neighbor. Her neighbor invited her to form her own group, so she contacted the consultant to get information about the Committee of Enterprising Women program and how it works.

Each business that the women of this committee owns is independent, but without losing that sense of belonging and solidarity with the group.

All of these women are hardworking. Take, for example, the life of Ms. Basilia B., who sells fruits and vegetables. She owns a fruit stand on the side of the road where she sells her produce, but at the same time, she has to take care of her household to help her husband, who works in agriculture. Through much sacrifice, the family is able to survive.

The following are the group members and their businesses: 1 Basilia B. Produce sales 2 Rafaela Fernández Sandwich sales 3 Claudelina V. Notions shop 4 Agustina C. General store 5 Blanca B. Fashion jewelry sales 6 Nicolaza T. Foodstuffs 7 Francisca S. Charcoal sales 8 Shirley A. Cosmetics sales 9 De las Nieves T. Produce sales 10 Griselda R. Newsstand 11 Raquel C. General store 12 Felicia V. Pharmacy 13 Ma. Mercedes B. Candy store 14 Rosenda C. Fashion jewelry sales 15 Ma. Lourdes P. Newsstand 16 Quiteria C. Café

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits (apples, pears, pineapples, melons) and vegetables (onions, tomatoes, bell peppers, potatoes)

loans.name: Ramona Ayala

texts.en:
Ramona is 25 years old and lives in the Sportivo neighborhood in Itá with her parents and brothers. She is single and does not have any children. Ramona rents a retail space where she has operated a hair salon for the past five years. In the salon she cuts, brushes and dyes hair, gives hair extensions, hair layering and conditioning treatments, and offers manicures and pedicures to her clients, who are mainly teachers.
Ramona is seeking a loan to purchase dyes and hair for hair extensions (a very popular request) as she has been offered a good price and does not want to miss the opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase hair dye and hair for hair extensions

loans.name: Okunlola's Group

texts.en:
I. is 44 years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos with her family. She is very hardworking and, through her hard work, makes sure she has food on the table every day. 
I. owns a shop where she sells clothes. She loves her business because of the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is requesting a loan of 80,000 NGN to purchase more clothes to meet customer demand. She thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Saye

texts.en: Saye T. is a 40-year-old woman from the region of Diourbel in Senegal. She is married and a mother of three children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. Her main activity is raising sheep and selling them on the market. This loan will enable her to buy more sheep. The resulting revenue will help her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: To buy more sheep

loans.name: Alba Luz

texts.es: Alba Luz tiene su actividad económica que es la venta de ropa, hace más de 15 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que realiza sus compras en Managua ya que es aquí donde le resulta más favorable obtener su mercadería, aunque es un poco peligroso porque en los mercados les sacan las cosas de su bolso sin que ella se dé cuenta es por eso, que tiene que tener mucha precaución al realizar estos viajes. Esta mujer luchadora ha sabido muy bien administrar este negocio pues siempre se ha dedicado a trabajar fuertemente. Ella solicita este financiamiento para la compra de pantalones, camisas para vestir, pantalones y trajes. Ella sueña con mejorar obtener un lugar en el mercado en donde pueda ofrecer sus productos.
texts.en:
Alba Luz sells clothing for a living. She has been in business for over 15 years. She makes her purchases in Managua since it is more favorable for her to obtain her merchandise there. However, it is a bit dangerous because at those markets, thieves take out her garments from her bags without her knowing. For this reason, she has to be extremely cautious when she makes these trips. This hard-working woman has been able to manage her business well as she has always worked assiduously. She is requesting this loan in order to purchase pants, dress shirts, and suits. She dreams of opening up her own shop in the market where she can sell her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Diéye

texts.en: Diéye N. is 49 years old and lives in a small village in the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and the mother of eight children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. She raises cattle and sells them on the market. This loan will allow her to buy more cattle and thereby increase her revenues.

loans.use: To buy more cattle

loans.name: God Is Our Witness Group

texts.en:
Comfort D. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called "God Is Our Witness". She is 27 years old, single, and has a six-year-old child who is in kindergarten. Comfort could not continue her education through 12th grade due to poverty.
Comfort sells cosmetics such as body cream, spray and styling gel. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She has been running this business for five years and hopes to grow her business in the near future.
Comfort attracts trade by selling her products at the front of the market, which is convenient for customers. She will use this loan to purchase additional cosmetics products for resale. Comfort dreams of her family being healthy and being able to afford medication if any of them is sick. 
In the photo that accompanies this profile, Comfort is the one holding the sign. Orlando M. is inset at the lower right of the photo.

About LEAP
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional cosmetics products for resale

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth E. is single and has three children. She has no educational background. Elizabeth bakes bread to sell in Elmina. She has been doing this for some time now. Elizabeth uses her income to pay school fees and utility bills. 

Elizabeth will use the loan to purchase more flour, margarine, oil and ingredients for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Elizabeth plans to save to educate her children and to buy land for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more flour, margarine, oil and ingredients

loans.name: Asunmo

texts.en:
A. is 38 years old and married with a child. She runs her business in Lagos and her family lives together in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells drinks, foodstuffs, provisions and frozen food to her customers  in order to make a living. 

She wishes to expand her business and meet the needs of her customers and meet her family's basic needs. A. hopes for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to invest in her business. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Adesina

texts.en:
M. owns a building-materials store, where she sells all types of building materials. She has four children and lives in Lagos with her family. M. is 38 years old and she is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira. 

She will use this loan to invest in her business by buying building materials in bulk to get a better price. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase larger quantities of building materials

loans.name: Maimouna

texts.en:
Maïmouna Y. is 35 years old, married and the mother of six children. She lives in the region of Diourbel, Senegal, and has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. 

She raises cattle, which she later sells on the market. She will use the loan to buy more cattle. This allows her to improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Buy more cattle and increase her working capital

loans.name: Mahasa Kawarujju Bee Keepers, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en: T. Wilson, on the top left side of the photo, is the leader of this group. He is 47 years old and married with 12 children, most of them in secondary school. He also takes care of other dependents. Wilson has been involved in selling second-hand clothing in the town of Kawarujju for 4 years. He sells in periodic markets and his biggest challenge is traveling to his work stations. This is the first loan that Wilson is seeking from Pearl Microfinance/Kiva and he hopes to become a successful old businessman and have a stable family. He needs a loan to be able to buy more used clothing for resale so that he can earn more profit.

loans.use: buy more used clothing for resale

loans.name: Jose Eduardo

texts.es:
José C. de 39 años, vive en una zona urbana en el Suburbio de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento pero solo cuenta con luz como servicio básico. Su esposa trabaja en una panadería con ella tienen 4 hijos de 18, 16, 12, 7 años.

El aprendió desde pequeño hacer monturas para caballo con su padre. Cuando creció decidió que esa iba a ser su profesión. Poco a poco con la ayuda de su esposa obtuvieron dinero para comprar las maquinas de coser.

Ahora el trabaja desde las 05h00 hasta las 22h00 todos los días. Hace monturas de caballo con hilos y su maquina de coser. También las arregla y confecciona. Una de las dificultades que  tiene es el transportar las monturas a su destino. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar hilos, arnés, remaches para poder elaborar más monturas. En el futuro quiere tener su propio local en la ciudad de Cuenca de Guayaquil.
texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old José C. lives in an urban area of el Suburbio de Guayaquil. His house is made of cement, but his sole basic utility is electricity. His wife works in a bakery, and they have 4 children ages 18, 16, 12, and 7.

When he was young, his father taught him how to make horse saddles. When he grew up, he decided that this would be his profession. Little by little, with his wife's help, he was able to obtain the money to purchase sewing machines.

He now works from 5:00 am until 10:00 pm every day. He makes horse saddles with thread and a sewing machine. He also repairs them. One of the difficulties he experiences is having to transport the saddles to their destination.

With this loan, he would like to purchase thread, harnesses, and rivets so that he can make more saddles. In the future, he would like to open up his own shop in the city of Cuenca de Guayaquil.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials to make saddles

loans.name: Rafael

texts.es:
Rafael R. M., tiene la edad de 61 años, está casado, y tiene un hijo que es su mayor prioridad. El tiene 22 años. El crédito lo quiere para la compra de dos vacas, la idea es tener ganado para doble propósito (leche y carne). Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al ganado para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando se vendan. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contento con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Don Rafael tiene muchos años de trabajar con ganado. El espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productor.

About FUDECOSUR:
The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Rafael R. M., is 61 years old, he is married and has a son who is his top priority. His son is 22 years old. With this loan he wants to buy two cows, the idea is to have cattle for the dual purpose of milk and meat. He hopes to adequately care for them in order to earn the highest possible income when he sells them. This is his first loan with FUDECOSUR and he is very happy with the services that they offer. Don Rafael has worked with cattle for many years. He hopes that he will be able to provide for his family a better quality of life and a more stable economic situation and to be able to continue growing as a person and a producer. About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Fiorella Ivonne

texts.es:
Fiorella, tiene 21 años, es soltera y aun todavía no tiene hijos. Fiorella es socia nueva del banco comunal “Sol de Oro” de la Asociación Arariwa. 
Fiorella estudia la carrera profesional de turismo en el instituto “Antonio Lorena” y esta en el segundo semestre y en sus horas libres ofrece productos de belleza por catalogo a sus amigas y familiares. Fiorella nos cuenta que compra productos de belleza que están de oferta, ella hace pedidos a la empresa “ESIKA” y después de 15 días llegan los productos. Ya son 45 días que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Fiorella es una mujer joven y emprendedora requiere el crédito para comprar colonias y aretes. Fiorella se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Fiorella is 21 years old. She is single and doesn't yet have any children. Fiorella is a new partner of the group “Sol de Oro” at Asociación Arariwa. Fiorella studies tourism in the Antonio Lorena Institute and is in the second semester. In her free time she sells beauty products from a catalog to her friends and family. Fiorella told us that she buys beauty products that are on sale, she orders from the business ESIKA and after 15 days the products arrive. She already has 45 days with the business and has done very well thanks to the commitment she has put into her work. Fiorella is a young woman and is enterprising, she will use the credit to buy perfumes and earrings. Fiorella is thankful for this opportunity and is committed to complete the repayments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fiorella needs this loan to buy perfumes and earrings

loans.name: Sénoumé Fidèle

texts.fr: Z. Sénoumé Fidèle est née le 26 avril 1981 à Enagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, où elle vit toujours.  Sénoumé Fidèle est mariée à HONFO Bienvenu, un électricien, et est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés.  Sénoumé Fidèle vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Sénoumé Fidèle n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Sénoumé Fidèle vend divers produits pour cheveux à Akpakpa dodomé. Sénoumé Fidèle exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Sénoumé Fidèle s’approvisionne.  Sénoumé Fidèle a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Sénoumé Fidèle sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux satisfaire ses clients.
texts.en:
Sénoumé Fidèle Z. was born on April 26, 1981 in the neighborhood of Enagnon in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and still lives there. She is married to Bienvenu Honfo, an electrician, and is the mother of two children who attend school. She lives with her husband and her children. Both parents provide for their family. Sénoumé Fidèle never attended school. To provide for herself, Sénoumé Fidèle has sold hair products in Akpakpa-Dodomé for 5 years. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She was already granted a loan by Alidé which she repaid on schedule. Sénoumé Fidèle came now to Alidé and applied for another loan which she will use to bolster her business and better keep up with her customers' demand.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beauty products

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.es: Reyna Isabel tiene 50 años de edad, su actividad económica es la venta de cosméticos. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica a esta actividad, ella cuenta con muy buena clientela pues siempre esta y con el paso del tiempo ha logrado incrementar su mercadería y la amplia variedad de clientes que posee, pues siempre está pensando en la mejoría de su familia  ya que busca la forma de ganarse el pan de cada día. Ella solicita este financiamiento como una oportunidad para comprar cremas, tratamientos para el cabello, pintura de uñas, pinturas de labios, perfumes, maquillajes, delineadores y brillos labiales. Por lo que sueña con obtener muchos clientes y ofrecer el mejor servicio.
texts.en:
Reyna Isabel is 50 years old, her economic activity is the sale of cosmetics. For more than three years this has been her business. She has always had a very good clientele and over time she has increased her inventory and the variety of clients that she has. She is always thinking of the best interest of her family and how to earn their daily bread. She is seeking this loan as an opportunity to buy creams, treatments for hair, nail polish, lip sticks, perfumes, makeup, eye liners and lip glosses. Her dream is to gain more clients and to offer better services.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: creams, treatments for hair, nail polish, lip sticks, perfumes, makeup, eye liners and lip glosses

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Francisca, pertenecen al banco comunal  “NUEVA VISION DE URUBAMBA”, nuestra socia está ubicado en el corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, Urubamba está a 1 hora 10 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 32 años ella es conviviente, tiene 2 hijos de 5 y 1 año de edad; Nuestra socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, la socia tiene una agro veterinaria propia, nuestra socia es una mujer muy emprendedora siempre trabajo en todo tipo de negocios y ahora aprovechó que su pareja ha estudiado agronomía técnica y ella ha solicitado un préstamo hace años de este mismo banco y junto a su esposo pusieron su propio negocio, la socia ahora administra y sabe todo sobre este negocio y solicita el préstamo para comprar más mercadería de veterinaría en Lima. 

Nuestra socia agradece  la oportunidad brindada y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Our partner Francisca belongs to the "NEW VISION OF URUBAMBA" communal bank. Urubamba is one hour and 10 minutes away from Cuzco, in the heart of the sacred valley of the Incas. Francisca is 32 years old and lives with her partner. She has 2 sons, one is 5 years old and the other is 1 years old. She alternates her home activities with retail; she has her own agricultural veterinary store. She is a very entrepreneurial woman who has worked in different types of businesses; and now she has taken advantage of the fact that her partner has studied technical agriculture. She had already requested a loan from the communal bank some years ago, and she set up her own business with her live-in partner. Francisca manages her business and knows all about it. She is requesting a loan to purchase more veterinary merchandise in Lima. Our partner is thankful for the opportunity you give her and is committed to fulfill the loan payments in the established period.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for the agricultural veterinary store

loans.name: Laba

texts.en: Laba N. is from the region of Diourbel, Senegal. She is 44, married, and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. Her main activity consists of raising cattle and sheep. She will use this loan to buy more cattle. The increased revenues will allow her to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: buy more cattle

loans.name: The Women´s Bank In Search Of Success (Banco Mujer En Busca Del Éxito) Group

texts.en:
This group's name translates as ¨The Women´s Bank in Search of Success¨(Banco Mujer en Busca del Éxito). The 7 group members live in Pococi, Limon, a rural region located near the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. The women in this group are involved in various entrepreneurial productive activities including: clothing and jewellery sales as well as sewing and bread-making (and selling). This loan will be used to make general investments conducive to the expansion of business activities by purchasing clothing, jewellery, and materials necessary for bread-making and sewing clothes. The group members engaged in clothing sales contact suppliers, make clothing purchases and sell clothes to members of the Pococi community. The other members produce clothing and bread in their homes to sell at a later date. 

Some of the members engaged in bread-making aspire to one day open their own bakery. In general the group hopes this loan will assist them in improving their standard of living; specifically, the members would like to be able to invest in a higher level of education. A main obstacle for the members of this group has been the lack of available financial services in their community. This loan will extend the reach of business loans to a group of hard-working entrepreneurs living in a poor Costa Rican community. 

The Women´s Bank in Search of Success was formed in July of 2009. This loan will be the group's second with Fundación Mujer. The loan consultant who has been working with the group members over the past 7 months describes these women as hard-working, entrepreneurial-minded individuals who aspire to improve living conditions for themselves and their families. The women work together well and have exhibited responsibility and punctuality with respect to past loans. 

In general, there is ample demand for the products sold by the women of this group. The members have successfully used their first loan to build their client base. They are happy and excited to now be applying for a larger loan amount than they have in the past. 

For the members, the name of this group symbolizes the possibility of succeeding in life and the goal of becoming self-sufficient.

loans.use: For the purchase of raw materials needed for bread-making, sewing, and to purchase clothing and jewellery

loans.name: Anyela Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Anyela Del Carmen  posee un negocio que es una pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación desde hace cinco años, ella trabaja junto a su esposo el cual le ayuda con el cuido de la pulpería, cuando el no está trabajando ya que trabaja en la construcción y sus trabajos son ocasionales, realiza sus compras de contado y sus ventas son al crédito y de contado, las compras las efectúa en el mercado de Managua y a ciertos camiones repartidores, que le llegan a dejar ciertos productos. La señora está solicitando un nuevo financiamiento para invertirlo en su negocio ya que se aproxima la temporada en donde ella vende más, además la señora es madre de dos niños de 6 y 10 años los cuales asisten al colegio gracias al apoyo de su esposo. Por lo que sueña que algún día mejorara la situación económica que posee actualmente.
texts.en:
Ms. Anyela Del Carmen has owned the small store located in her house for five years. She works with her husband who helps her with taking care of the store when he isn't working, since he works in construction and his jobs are only occasional. She pays for everything upfront and her sales are both with credit and upfront. She buys merchandise from the Managua market and from several delivery trucks that deliver certain products. She is requesting a new loan to invest in her business since the high season is coming. Furthermore, she is a mother of two, one is 6 years old and the other is 10, and they go to school thanks to her husband's help. She dreams about one day improving her current financial situation.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Emilia

texts.en: Emilia E. sells Fante kenkey (locally made with corn, commonly found in the central region of Cape Coast) with varieties of sauces and soups in Elmina. She also sells soaps to earn additional income.  Emilia has received no education.  She is married to a carpenter and has five dependents. Emilia has been selling soap and kenkey for sometime now. She supports her husband in the payment of utility bills and school fees. Her loan will be used to buy corn and other ingredients for the making of the kenkey, and soap. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy corn and other ingredients for the making of the kenkey, and soap

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Hilda, pertenecen al banco comunal  “NUEVA VISION DE URUBAMBA”, nuestra socia está ubicado en el corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, Urubamba está a 1 hora 10 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestra socia tiene 23 años de edad y tiene 1 hijo de 8 meses, ella es conviviente y alterna sus actividades del hogar con el comercio minorista, nuestra socia compra y vende ropa en el centro comercial sr de Torrechayoc en Urubamba, en el stand A-4 nuestra socia viaja para traer de la capital Lima la ropa al por mayor y luego la lleva a la provincia de Urubamba, ella alquiló su stand y vende ropa de temporada, nuestra socia ahora aprovechará la época escolar y traerá ropa deportiva y de colegió como camisas de vestir en toda las tallas, medias, interiores, cafarenas, faldas escolares y pantalones, zapatos y zapatillas deportivas. Nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder viajar a comprar ropa escolar para la venta en marzo.
 
Nuestra socia agradece  la oportunidad brindada y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Our partner Hilda, belongs to the "NEW VISION OF URUBAMBA”, communal bank. Urubamba is located 1 hour and 10 minutes from Cuzco, in the heart of the sacred valley of the Incas. Our partner is 23 years old and has a son of 1 year 8 months. She lives with her partner and alternates her home activities with retail. She buys and sells clothes in the Sr de Torrechayoc market in Urubamba, in stand A-4. Our partner travels to Lima to buy clothing that she purchases wholesale and then brings it to the Urubamba province. She rented her stand and sells clothes that are in season. Our partner will now take advantage of the school season and will bring sports clothing and other clothing for school such as dress shirts in every size, socks, underwear, skirts, pants, shoes and sneakers. Our partner is requesting a loan to be able to travel and buy clothing for the sale in March. The partner is thankful for the opportunity and is committed to fulfill the payment of the loan in the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Esteban Riojas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing for the sale in March

loans.name: Good Will Group

texts.en:
Nancy K. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'Goodwill'. She is single with 2 boys aged 9 and 16 years old; their educational levels are 2nd and 3rd grade.  She could not continue her education through 12th grade due to poverty.
 
Nancy's business is the sale of foodstuffs such as rice, seasonings and peppers. She buys her goods from wholesalers and sells retail on a table in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia.  She has been running this business for 5 years and hopes to grow her business.  Nancy is very friendly, which encourages people to keep buying from her.

Nancy started selling with 3000 Liberian Dollars as working capital and now operates with 4000 Liberian dollars. She says that it’s hard for her to save money because she has to feed her children and send them to school.  Nancy will use this loan to purchase additional rice, pepper, and seasonings for resale.  She dreams of giving her children a good education and medical attention when needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nancy is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional rice, peppers, and seasonings for resale

loans.name: Concern Members Group

texts.en:
'Concern Members' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Satia W.. He is 27 years old and is single  with no children. Satia is a high school graduate. He could not continue his education past high school due to lack of financial support.

He lives in the Florado community of New Kru town in Monrovia, Liberia and sells T-shirts at Broad and Randall Street in Monrovia. He buys wholesale and sells retail to customers. He has been running this business for more than 5 years and hopes to expand it.

Satia started selling with 500 Liberian dollars.  He has a good relationship with his customers that encourages them to continue buying from him. Satia needs this loan to purchase more T-shirts to sell.  He says does not have any family dreams at this time.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Satia is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more T-shirts

loans.name: Maréme

texts.en: Maréme S. is 48 years old, married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years. Her main activity consists of raising cattle and selling them at the market. With the loan she can buy more cattle, which will allow her to increase her revenue.

loans.use: increasing her working capital

loans.name: Charlotte

texts.en:
Charlotte A. sells cooked rice and a variety of yams with sauces like garden eggs (small eggplants) and greens known locally as 'kotommere'. She runs her business at Elmina.  Charlotte has no educational background.  She is married and has six dependents.  Her husband is a carpenter. 

Charlotte has been selling rice for some time now. She helps her husband with the general up-keep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy rice and yams and other ingredients to prepare the food for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to build a small shop she can sell out of.

loans.use: to buy rice and yams and other ingredients to prepare the food for sal.

loans.name: Irène

texts.fr: V. Irène est née en 1984 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mais Irène s’est installée à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis son jeune âge. Irène est célibataire et n’a pas encore des enfants.  Elle vit seule.  Irène n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Irène vend des chaussures et des sacs de façon ambulante.  Irène exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Lomé au Togo, pays à côté du Bénin. Irène a déjà obtenu un crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé.  Irène désire élever le niveau de son activité afin de mieux satisfaire ses clients, mais elle manque suffisamment de moyens financiers pour y arriver.  C’est la raison pour laquelle Irène sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Irène V. was born in 1984 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. At an early age she settled in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji area. She is unmarried and has no children. She lives alone and has never attended school. To meet her needs, Irene sells shoes and handbags as an itinerant vendor. She has been doing this for the past five years and gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace, and also from Lomé in Togo, a country adjacent to Benin. Irene has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she has fully repaid. She would like to increase the level of her activity, but lacks the financial means to do so. That is why she is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy shoes

loans.name: Edgar

texts.es:
Nuestro socio Edgar, pertenecen al banco comunal  “NUEVA VISION DE URUBAMBA”, nuestro socio está ubicado en el corazón del valle sagrado de los inkas, Urubamba está a 1 hora 10 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestro socio tiene 34 años de edad, é es conviviente con la Sra. La socia Francisca, juntos tiene  2 hijos de  5 y 1 años, nuestro socio es técnico agropecuario estudio 3 años en la academia taller  de arariwa, nuestro socio comprarte una agro veterinaria con su pareja y él aparte trabaja socio como proveedor de  plantones, semillas, fertilizantes, al municipio de Urubamba, nuestro socio también alquila el transporte que es para estos trabajos un volquete, nuestro socio solicita el préstamo para  alquilar un volquete para llevar todos los pedidos que le hicieron del municipio, cuando el entregue toda la mercadería el municipio le pagará.
 
Nuestro socio agradece  la oportunidad brindada y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus diferentes cuotas en los plazos establecidos.
texts.en:
Our group member, Edgar, belongs to the 'Nueva Vision de Urubamba' (New Vision of Urubamba) Community Bank. He lives in the heart of the holy Incan valley. Urubamba is 1 hour and 10 minutes from the city of Cuzco.

He is 34 years old and lives with Mrs. Francisca. Together they have two children who are 5 and 1. He is an agricultural technician and studied three years at a technical school in Arariwa. He and his wife run a farm veterinary business, and he also works selling seedlings, seeds, and fertilizers to the town of Urubamba. He rents a dump truck to transport these goods and is asking for a loan to buy a dump truck to deliver his items. After delivering all the merchandise he will be able to repay the loan.

He is thankful for the opportunity provided to him and promises to be responsible and make the payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Meinecke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a dumptruck for transporting merchandise

loans.name: Oscar Moisés

texts.es:
El señor Oscar Moisés A. M., tiene 30 años es casado y su esposa trabaja como comerciante tienen 2 hijos de 4  y 2 añitos de edad, ellos se dedican a la siembra de la piña desde hace 11 años, comenzaron sus trabajos en la agricultura gracias al apoyo financiero que les brindo su padre. Dentro de los planes que tienen como familia está la remodelación de la vivienda y dentro de las mayores dificultades esta el alza de los precios de los productos, dentro de los planes para el negocio está la diversificación de los productos que cosecha en su finca, para esto solicita de un préstamo que invierta en la compra de materiales agrícolas tales como fertilizantes e insumos que le brinden a las tierras un mejor mantenimiento que haga que la producción sea de mejor calidad y de esta manera recuperar a corto plazo el dinero invertido. 

Esto beneficiaría a la familia en gran medida debido a  que es la fuente de ingreso más alta que tienen y el aumento de las ventas les daría una mejor condición de vida.
texts.en:
Señor Oscar Moisés A. M., age 30, is married. His wife works as a merchant, and they have 2 children, ages 4 and 2. They have been engaged in planting pineapples for 11 years. They began their agricultural work thanks to the financial support offered to them by Oscar’s father.

Among the plans they have as a family is the remodeling of their house. Among their greatest difficulties is the increase in the cost of living.

Among the plans for their business is the diversification of crops that they harvest on their farm. For this reason Oscar is applying for a loan that he will invest in the purchase of agricultural materials such as fertilizers and raw materials that will provide the land with better maintenance. This will make for better quality production, and, in this manner, he will recover the investment in a short time. This would benefit the family greatly due to the fact that farming is the biggest source of income that they have, and the increase in sales would give them a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizers for maintaining their land

loans.name: Henry Augusto

texts.es: Henry M. habita en el barrio Carlos Núñez de la Ciudad de Managua, es casado, tiene dos hijos de 5 y 3 años de edad  y uno que aún no ha nacido, ya que su esposa está embarazada. Su esposa es abogada y trabaja de forma independiente. Henry  trabaja como contador en una empresa de medicamentos. Hace algunos años adquirió su casa en este barrio y poco a poco le ha ido haciendo las mejoras necesarias para darle comodidad a su familia. Este crédito será usado con el mismo propósito,  construirá una habitación, ya que actualmente tiene sólo una habitación en donde comprara materiales de construcción para comenzar la obra. Espera en un futuro poder seguir invirtiendo en su hogar para así dar a su familia toda la comodidad necesaria.
texts.en:
Henry M. lives in the Carlos Núñez neighborhood of the city of Managua. He is married and has two children, aged 5 and 3, as well as one child on the way, since his wife is pregnant. His wife is a lawyer and works independently. Henry works as an accountant in a pharmaceutical company. A few years ago, he acquired his house in this neighborhood, and little by little he has been carrying out the necessary improvements to make his family comfortable there. This loan will be used for the same purpose; he will build an additional room, since the house currently only has one bedroom. He will purchase construction materials to start work on this project. In the future, Henry hopes to be able to continue investing in his home and thus giving his family all of the comforts they need.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Adding a room to his home

loans.name: God's Will Business Group

texts.en:
'God’s Will Business' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Hanachor S..  He is 42 years old and is married with 2 children, aged 6 months and 3 years old.  Hanachor is a high school graduate but could not continue his education through college due to a lack of financial support.

Hanachor sells goods such as candles, batteries, sugar and bread.  He buys his goods wholesale and sells retail in a shop to residents of his community in Paynesville, Liberia. He has been running this business for 3 years and hopes to grow his business.  Hanachor started out selling his goods out of a wheelbarrow, but now operates from a shop.

Hanachor interacts well with his customers, which encourages them to continue buying from him.  He will use this loan to purchase more candles, batteries, sugar and bread.  He dearly hopes that his children will remain in good health and that he can afford medical attention for them if needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Hanachor is the one holding the sign.  Jartu J. is in the inset at lower right.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more goods such as candles, batteries, sugar and bread for resale

loans.name: Erlinda Maricela

texts.es: La señora Erlinda Maricela tiene 23 años de edad. Ella se dedica a la venta de ropa de manera ambulante en sus comarcas, madre de 2 hijos una niña de 1 año y un niño de 4 años de edad, su esposo trabaja como obrero. Doña Erlinda tiene 3 años de trabajar de esta manera, ofrece sus productos a la gente del campo ya que ellos son sus principales clientes debido a que por falta de tiempo ellos no pueden venir a la ciudad, por lo que sus deseos de mejorar los ingresos necesarios para su familia son su principal prioridad pues diariamente ofrece lo mejor de ella. Es por tal motivo que solicita financiamiento para la compra de materia prima. Erlinda sueña con mejorar sus condiciones de vida y proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Erlinda Maricela is 23 years old. She works selling clothing as a street vendor in her neighborhood. She's the mother of 2 children - one girl who's 1 year old and a boy that's 4. Her husband works as a laborer. Erlinda has been working like this for 3 years, offering her products to the people of the countryside because they are her principal clients, as they are unable to come to the city due to a lack of time. Her desire to increase the necessary funds for her family is her primary priority since daily she gives it her all. It's for this reason that she is asking for financing for the purchase of raw materials. Erlinda dreams of bettering her living conditions and making improvements to her home. .

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: God Provision Group

texts.en:
God Provision' is a group of 5 borrowers led by Matthew R.. He is 27 years old and is married with 2 children, aged 9 months and 3 years old. The oldest child is in nursery school.  Matthew did not continue his education past the 7th  grade due to poverty.

He and his family live in the Old Road Gaye Town community, and he works nearby, opposite the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Sinkor.
Matthew’s business is wood planks. He buys planks wholesale and sells retail to residents of Sinkor, not far from downtown Monrovia.
 
He has been running this business from a stall on the street for more than 13 years.  He hopes to own a shop in the near future.  Matthew started selling with 1,500 Liberian dollars, but now operates with 2,500 Liberian dollars in working capital.

He sells good planks to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from him.  Matthew needs this loan to purchase additional planks.
He dreams of his family living in better conditions.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Matthew is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional planks

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama A. sells bananas, plantains and firewood at Elmina.  Ama has no educational background.  She is married and has six dependents. 

Ama has been selling plantains, bananas and firewood for some time now. She helps her husband in the general up-keep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy other additional food supplies like maize and yams for sale to meet the demand of her customers. 

She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to further her children’s education.

loans.use: to buy other additional food supplies like maize and yams

loans.name: Hawa Gull Group

texts.en:
Hawa G. Group is a group of 5 borrowers led by Hawa G.. She is 38 years old and is married with 3 children ages 16–20, their educational levels from 7th–8th grade. Hawa is an illiterate. She could not go to school due to poverty.

She and her family live in the Old Road community, and she sells at the Old Road Joebar Market located in the downtown part of Monrovia. Hawa’s business is the sale of dry goods. She buys at wholesale and sells at retail to customers. Hawa has been running this business for more than 7 years and hopes to own a shop to serve more customers.

Hawa started selling with funds that were given to her by her husband. Her most challenging times are when her goods remain too long and get spoiled. With the help of her husband and the susu group (community savings club) that she joined, she is able to buy quality goods and sell them to her customers to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Hawa needs this loan to purchase more foodstuff, such as peppers, bouillon cubes, salt, okra, etc., to add to her business. She dreams of owning a shop and building a house for her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Hawa is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy peppers, bouillon cubes, salt, okra, and other foodstuff for resale

loans.name: Innovative Group

texts.en:
Innovative Group is a group of 5 borrowers led by Nah O.. She is 31 years old and is single with 2 children ages 6 and 9. Nah is a high-school graduate but could not continue her education through university due to poverty.

For nine years, Nah has been selling used clothes on Carey Street in downtown Monrovia. In the future she would like to open a shop. She sells high-quality used clothes to customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Nah will use this loan to purchase additional used clothes. She dreams of being able to keep her children in school.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nah is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional used clothes

loans.name: Martha Auxiliadora

texts.es:
La señora Martha Auxiliadora P., tiene la edad de 47 años es cada y con su esposo vive en el Barrio Sierras Doradas, tienen 3 hijos de los cuales dos de los mayores trabajan y apoyan en los quehaceres de la finca y el menor estudia la secundaria, Dña. Martha se dedica a su venta de abarrotes y productos varios desde hace 2 años y fue con su esfuerzo propio que pudo realizar la apertura de su negocio.

La crisis por la que está atravesando el país, hizo que las ventas bajaran considerablemente  y la falta de capital, obstaculiza la inversión para nuevos proyectos. Dentro de estos proyectos esta la remodelación de patio trasero de su hogar y para esto solicita de este préstamo para la compra de materiales de construcción, esto le ayudaría y beneficiaría a sus hijos debido a que son alérgicos al polvo, de tal forma que embaldosando esa parte de la casa resguardaría la buena salud de los miembros de la familia.
texts.en:
Martha Auxiliadora is 47 years and lives with her husband in the Sierras Doradas neighborhood. They have 3 children, the two oldest of which work and help with the chores of the farm and the youngest studies in high school. Martha has worked selling groceries and various products for 2 years and it was able to open her business through her own efforts. The crisis that has swept her country has made her sales decrease considerably. And this lack of money hinders the investment in new projects. One of these projects includes the remodeling of the back patio of her home, which is why she is asking for this loan, so she can buy construction materials. This would help her and would benefit her children as they are allergic to dust, so tiling this part of the house would protect the good health of the family members.

Translated from Spanish by Kimberly Baker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: remodeling the back patio of her house

loans.name: Julie

texts.fr: K. Julie est née le 25 Octobre 1957 et vit depuis 7 ans environs au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est une veuve qui est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés, dont seulement deux restent à sa charge. Julie vit seule avec ses deux enfants et supporte seule leurs charges. Julie n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Julie vend des galettes d'arachide à son domicile. Julie vend également du maïs et du charbon de bois, de façon secondaire. C'est à Bohicon dans le département du Zou, que Julie se ravitaille. Julie exerce cette activité depuis 7 ans, et a déjà bénéficié d'un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Julie a bien remboursé ce prêt. En vue d'augmenter son capital et de renforcer son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et accroître son profit, Julie sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Julie K. was born October 25, 1957 and has been living for the past seven years in the Dandji neighborhood of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is a widowed mother of five children, all of whom have had schooling, but of whom only two remain under her care. Julie herself has not attended school; she lives alone with her two children and is their only support. To make ends meet, Julie sells peanut wafers from her home. She also sells corn and charcoal, as a second source of income. She gets her supplies from Bohicon, in the Department of Zou. Julie has been in this business for seven years, and has already been granted one loan by ALIDé, which was fully repaid. She is now requesting a second loan from ALIDé, to increase her working capital, bolster her activity to better satisfy customer demand, and thus generate more profit.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy baskets of peanut wafers and corn

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi A. sells toiletries, provisions, and soft drinks at Elmina. Esi has received a senior-high education. She is married and has one child. Her husband is a fisherman. Esi has been selling toiletries, provisions, and soft drinks for some time now. She supports her husband in the payment of accommodation and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy pork and other meat as additional goods to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to complete her building.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy pork and other meat as additional goods to sell

loans.name: Santa Librada Group

texts.es:
Santa Librada así se denomina el Comité conformado en fecha 18 de febrero de 2009,en Barrio Santa Librada da la Ciudad  de Yaguarón,gracias a que la Sra. Rosa S. ,quien se dedica a la venta de comidas,asistió a una charla de Capacitación del Programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y se quedó muy impresionada por la forma de trabajo del Comité,lo cual la motivo para formar su propio grupo en su comunidad,logrando juntar a 17 mujeres quienes se encuentran muy a gusto con la Fundación Paraguaya  y con Kiva.
Todas las integrantes del comité asisten a las reuniones semanales y trabajan en forma conjunta para el logro de todos los objetivos que tienen en común.
Es un grupo muy unido y sus integrantes son señoras muy luchadoras quienes se esfuerzan bastante para sacar adelante a sus familias, este el caso de la señora Ingrid quien como muchas madres se dedica a la venta de ropas, ella realiza este trabajo de manera ambulante, visitando muchas lugares concurridos por personas y ahí ofrece sus mercaderías, con el trabajo lo ayudan su esposo y sus hijos para vender sus mercaderías de esta forma logran salir adelante.

texts.en:
Santa Librada is the name of the Committee formed on February 18 of 2009 in the Barrio Santa Librada of the city of Yaguarón. This was thanks to Rosa S., who sells food. She attended a Program Training talk of the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras and she was very impressed with how the committee works. This was the reason that she formed her own group in her community, getting 17 women together. They are very happy with the Fundación Paraguaya and with Kiva. All of the members of the committee attend the weekly meetings and they work together to acheive the goals they have in common. This is a very united group and its members are fighters who work hard to get their families ahead. This is the case of Ingrid, who like a lot of mothers sells clothing. She does this as a street vendor, visiting many places where there are a lot of people and offering her merchandise there. Her husband and children help with the work to sell the merchandise and get ahead. 1 Ingrid T. Selling used clothes 2 Rosa S. Selling food 3 María G. Store 4 Verónica Ruiz Díaz Sewing 5 María Sánchez Notions 6 Martina C. Selling food 7 Idalina Ruiz Diaz Store 8 Aurora Ruiz Díaz Store 9 Dominga V. Selling clothes 10 Adelia P. Store 11 Evelin Ramírez Selling clothes 12 Elena Y. Selling clothes 13 Rosa Ávalos Snacks and ice cream 14 Gedeona E. Selling clothes 15 Myrian M. Mini-market 16 Teodora G. Store 17 Ana T. Pastry

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothes such as t-shirts, shirts, pants and all types of school uniforms.

loans.name: Success Group

texts.en: James G. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Success Group. He is married and has two children who are 1 and 3 years old. In addition to his children, James takes care of a friend. For three years, James has had a charcoal business in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. James says that he is successful because he allows his customers “to take the charcoal and return to pay me.” James plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 26,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more charcoal. His goal is to improve the living standard of his family. In the photo that accompanies this profile, James is the one holding the sign. Cecilia Q. is inset at lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Helen Group

texts.en: Helen Group is a group of five borrowers led by Helen T.. She is 38 years old and is married with five children aged 8 to 22 years, with educational levels of 1st grade through high school graduate. She also cares for a few siblings. Helen could not continue her education through 8th grade due to poverty. In the photo, Helen is the one holding the sign. Helen and her family live and work in Rock Spring Valley, on the Capital Bypass, near downtown Monrovia, the capital of Liberia. Helen’s business is the sale of provisions such as rice, sugar, and bread. She buys her goods wholesale and sells retail in a shop to residents of her community. Helen has been running this business for twenty years and hopes to improve her business to a higher level. She started selling on a table with little funds but now sells in a shop, which means she has been doing well in business. She sells good products in order to encourage her customers to continue buying from her. Helen needs this loan to purchase additional goods for her business such as sugar, rice, and bread. She dreams of seeing her children in good health and taken care of. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase additional goods such as sugar, rice, and bread

loans.name: Productive Business Women Group

texts.en: Finda G. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Productive Business Women. She is a widow with five children 2 to 18 years old with educational levels of nursery school through 12th grade. Finda could not continue her education past 12th grade due to poverty. Finda's business is the sale of charcoal. She buys her charcoal from rural Liberia and sells retail in the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She has been running this business for five years and hopes to grow her business in the near future. Finda sells high-quality charcoal in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. She started selling with 9,000 Liberian dollars and now has 70,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. Finda will use this loan to purchase additional charcoal for resale. She dreams of buying land to build a house for her family. In the photo, Finda is the one holding the sign. Miatta D. is inset at the lower left of the photo.
