She has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2010, Melinda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. Melinda plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children’s education. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lay

texts.en: Lay S., age 46, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in a business of selling hand-made brooms, earning approximately US $3 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially for the children’s education. She has been doing this business since 2000. Her husband is a skillful carpenter, earning an income of US $2 per day. Their standard of living has improved since S. started this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. S. is requesting a loan of US $500 to purchase more brooms to sell. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more hand-made brooms to sell

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn S., age 40, is married and resides with his wife in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He has four children. He is a skillful blacksmith. He operates his business at home, earning approximately US $6 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover the family expenses, especially those for the children’s education. He has been doing this business since 2005. His wife is a housewife who stays at home to look after the children and the household chores. Their standard of living has improved since S. started this business, so he wants to have a loan to expand his business. S. is requesting a loan of US $800 to purchase more metal. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva. (S.'s wife is pictured in the photo.)

The couple has two children who are going to school and dependent on their parents' income. 

Huon H. works very hard every day to sustain the family and is now asking for a loan of $500 which will enable her to hire a cultivating machine to plow the farmland, on which she plants different types of crops for extra profit.

loans.use: To hire a cultivating machine.

loans.name: Rufino

texts.en:
Rufino E., 43, is making sure that his family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Perlita E., they are blessed with two children. He makes sure that he provides well so that their family can have a better life.  He has been managing their variety store for quite some time now.

Rufino has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. He regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays his weekly dues consistently. Because of his good repayment performance with his previous loans, he was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s Cooperative.  He is consistent in paying his dues because he uses the money he borrows to expand and improve the store.

Now with your help, he would like to apply for a PHP 11,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to his expanding business by buying products needed to replenish and sustain stocks and operations of the store.

He dreams that his business will continue to grow so that he can provide for his children’s education until they finish their degrees. He also wants to have his own mansion to house his family.


* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy products for his store

Teresita has been engaged in her business for three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Teresita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC, a Kiva partner. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to pay for repairs for a motorcycle. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Teresita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional payment for motor repair

loans.name: Sheila's Group

texts.en:
Sheila B. is from the village of Brgy. Baresbes, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 27 years old. Sheila is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Sheila is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Sheila owns and operates a business of providing motorcycle transport services. Sheila has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $135 a month for this activity.

In 2010, Sheila joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be her 1st loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Darng

texts.en: Darng S., 62, grows rice and raises chickens and pigs.  She lives in Take province. She is married with two married children, who are employed as garment factory workers. Her husband is a bicycle repairman. She and her husband typically make a combined income of about US$5 each day, and would like a loan to expand her husband's business. In order to increase the family’s profits, she is asking for a US $600 loan for her husband to purchase mechanic tools. Darng S. is pictured with her husband and her grandson.

loans.use: To purchase mechanic tools.

loans.name: Reynante

texts.en:
Reynante S. is from the village of Umayco, Mambajao Camiguin Province. He is 31 years-old, separated from his spouse and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Reynante owns and operates a business which provides hairdressing and haircut services to local community members. Reynante has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Reynante joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynante is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Yib

texts.en:
Mrs. Yib S., is a 45-year-old rice farmer earning approximately $2 per day. Her husband, Mr. Ou Sitha, is 50. He produces and sells Khmer cakes, earning approximately $5 per day. They have five teenage children, two of whom are employed and the remaining three attend school. 

Yib S. always needs to pay money for a taxi to go anywhere because she does not have a vehicle for travelling. She wants to cut down on the taxi fares and decided to apply for a loan from Kiva’s project partner, HKL. She will buy a motorcycle to supply her transportation needs.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen M. is from the village of Southwestern Poblacion, Calamba, Misamis Occidental.  She is 73 years-old and married with one adult child. To make a living, Helen owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from her pension and selling of daily use goods in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for seven years and earns approximately 10,350 PHP a month.

In 2008, Helen joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Helen is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional housing materials. This loan will be the 21th loan taken out by Helen from PMPC. 
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas V., age 51, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has two children. She is engaged in the agriculture sector raising pigs, earning an income of approximately US$ 2 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has had this business since 1999. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of US$ 1.5 per day. Their standard of living has improved since V. has started her business, so she wants a loan to expand her business. V. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more pigs and pig food. This is her second loan from Kiva partner CREDIT. (V. is pictured with her husband.)

loans.use: To buy pigs and pig food.

loans.name: Thelma's Group

texts.en:
Thelma S. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal Proper, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is forty-two years old. Thelma is the group leader of a thirteen-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Thelma is married. To make a living, She owns and operates a general store in the retail sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap, and toothpaste in the local community. Thelma has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Thelma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Thelma  successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. She used this previous loan to purchase additional products to sell. Thelma is requesting a new loan of 22,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will Thelma's ninth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-five branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offerings

loans.name: Reyzee

texts.en:
Reyzee B. is from the village of North Poblacion, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. He is 19 years-old and unmarried.  To make a living, Reyzee owns and operates a service-based business providing transport services using his motor vehicle in the local community.. Reyzee has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Reyzee joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reyzee has successfully repaid a previous loan from HSPFI. Reyzee is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services provided. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Reyzee from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Teodoro

texts.en:
Mr. Teodoro I., from the village of Poblacion, Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental, is an 81-year-old widower blessed with six adult-aged children. He owns and operates a specialized retail store selling dried goods in the local community, earning 5,000.00 each month. His source of income comes primarily from this business and his pension.

In 2007, Teodoro joined PMPC to access its programs and services and has fully repaid a previous loan of 25,000.00 PHP from PMPC. Teodoro is now requesting a new loan in the amount of 35,000.00 which will be used as additional capital for his business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for his existing business

loans.name: Lindsey

texts.en:
Lindsey C., from the village of Cabu-an, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province, is 37 years old, married and the father of an infant. To make a living, Lindsey owns and operates a business venture providing transport services to local community members. Lindsey has been a "habal-habal" driver for over eight years now and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Lindsey joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI, he is now requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand the services he provides. This loan will be Lindsey's third from HSPFI, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his service.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided

loans.name: Lim

texts.en: Mrs. Lim O., 47, is a widow with four children, three of whom are married and living independently while the remaining child is single and a cleaner in the garment industry. To earn a living, Lim O. arranges into sets the small pieces of cloth that she gets from factories (the cloth is used to upholster furniture). By doing this work, she is able to generate $5 / day. Lim O. hopes to  find another source of income by investing in a new suitable business. Since she lacks money, she would like to take out a loan to begin operating a business selling pigs.

loans.use: To begin a business selling pigs

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha M. is from the village of South Pob., Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. She is 54 years old. Editha is married and has 7 adult children. Editha owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Editha has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Editha joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Editha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Editha is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Editha from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Suon K., 37, is a resident of Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia, where she has established a small family home and lives with other family members. She is married to Bun Sokha, 41, and has three school-aged children, who require her financial support. Her husband owns a small truck that he uses to pick up merchandise or garment workers for a profit. In order to earn an income, Suon K. buys clothing in bulk from the factory and from her wholesale supplier and sells it at retail prices in the local public market. Suon K. is taking out her loan to buy a new motorcycle which will allow her children to ride to school.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle

loans.name: Sendenbadam

texts.en: Sendenbadam is 58 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Their quality of life is average. She provides vegetables to her family by planting them during the summer. Sendenbadam's son owns and operates a horsecart. Sendenbadam started her water selling business with a horse cart in 1990. Currently, they have been using 9 horse carts for their business, and providing jobs for six people. They will continue this business. Sendenbadam is a very hardworking person and says, “I will constantly operate this business and from the business’ profit I will buy a car for my son.”

loans.use: To purchase horse hay and to buy a car.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph P. is from the village of Canta-an, Guinsiliban Camiguin Province. He is 24 years old. Joseph is married and has 1 infant child. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a service-based community transport business. Joseph has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Joseph joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Joseph has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. Joseph is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Joseph from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand services provided.

loans.name: Ganbold

texts.en:
Ganbold is 48 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. He operates a carpentry business with his wife. They have been living in their current home for 21 years. His two children are university students in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

Ganbold started manufacturing wooden products in 2001, building his workplace with planks. The workplace is 24 square meters and can be used during the summer. When spring comes in Mongolia  and weather is warm, they will expand the workplace. Ganbold and his wife have been planning to winterize their workplace as well, and have been collecting the necessary materials. They are also working hard to expand their business so they can increase the number of their customers. Ganbold says, “I would like to afford my two children's university tuition fees until they graduate and will be happy to see they're working after they graduate their universities.” He is requesting a 700,000 tugrug (~ 492 USD ) loan to purchase wooden planks to manufacture doors and frames for the gers of his customers.

loans.use: To purchase wooden planks

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Mrs. P. owns and operates a café in the village, catering to citizens living around her community. Through her business, she is able to feed her family. She also depends on her husband's income as a military policeman in the Ministry of the Interior. P. has been blessed with three children, two of whom are married while one is single and attends high school. P. wants to improve her business and is asking for a loan to accrue capital for her café. With any remaining money from the loan, she will decorate her shop.

loans.use: To accrue capital for her café

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy C. is from the village of Benoni, Mahinog Camiguin Province. She is 37 years old. Nancy is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nancy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Nancy has been engaged in her business for omore than 8 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nancy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nancy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Nancy is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan she has taken  from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto C. is from the village of Agoho, Mambajao Camiguin Province. He is 60 years old and married, with 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Roberto makes and sells food.  The main source of income for the business comes  from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Roberto has been engaged in his business for more than 15 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Roberto joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roberto has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Roberto is requesting his second loan, also for 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Laura Fariñas Group

texts.en:
Laura F. is from the town of Tinang, Concepcion. She is 32 years old. Laura is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Laura is married and has 2 infant children. To make a living, Laura owns & operates a business venture selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling personal and home products to tourists and local community members. Laura has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Laura joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laura has successfully repaid a previous loan  from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Laura is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Laura from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Gantumur

texts.en: Gantumur is 37 years old and lives with her three children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. She is solely responsible for her family, and she receives government help to support her children. Gantumur started a retailing business with her sister by purchasing products in Ereen, a Chinese border city, in 2008. She has been operating her business independently since June 2008 and the business has been stabilizing. Gantumur has been working hard to expand her business and to increase the variety of products she can offer. She says, “I would like to constantly operate my business and will expand the business.” She is requesting a 765,000 tugrug (~  538 USD) loan to increase the working capital of her business.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Munhdalai

texts.en:
Munhdalai is 36 years old and lives with his wife and son in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Their quality of life is good. 

Munhdalai and his wife have been running a mobile food-trading business since 2003. Besides this business, he operates a coal-trading business with his truck during the winter and sometimes he operates a taxi service in the center of his own province. Munhdalai  is a very hardworking person and says, “I would like to operate a permanent food-selling business in the center of the province with my business profit.”   He plans to begin building this business next summer.  He is requesting a 2,200,000 tugrug (~ 1548 USD)  loan to increase the working capital of his business.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia K. is from the coastal town of Talim, Binangonan, Rizal. She is 39 years old. She is married and has 5 young children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling fish in her village and nearby town. 

Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a week for these activities. In 2009, Virginia joined ASHI to secure access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.

Virginia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASHI. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fishnet and bamboos. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Virginia from ASHI. She plans to use the additional proceeds generated from the business to develop her business.

She hopes that, with the help of ASHI and the KIVA field partner, she can reach her ambition to step out from poverty, expand her business, and pay for the needs of her five children in school.


About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase additional fishnet and bamboo.

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en: Purevsuren is 30 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in their own apartment. His wife works as an inventory manager in a community hospital. His oldest daughter goes to secondary school and his son goes to kindergarten. Purevsuren and his wife have been living in their current apartment for three years, since they got married. During the day, Purevsuren has been operating a cell phone repairing business at the “Tuin Dolgio” market. Purevsuren started his business in 2009, and he is planning to change his workplace and improve his appliances and equipment for his business. They are planning to expand the business and create their own workplace. He will purchase a computer for installing songs and video clips on cell phones.  Purevsuren says, “I would like to expand my business.” He is requesting a 200,000 tugrug (~ 140 USD) loan, with 150,000 tugrugs (~ 105 USD) to be used for a computer and 50,000 tugrugs (~35 USD ) to be used for spare parts.

loans.use: To purchase a computer and spare parts

loans.name: Charmie

texts.en:
Charmie L. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 45 years old. Charmie is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Charmie owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling different vegetables in the local community. Charmie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Charmie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charmie is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Charmie from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth B. is a 42-year-old mother of three. She hails from the beautiful city of Antipolo, Rizal Province in the Philippines. Lilibeth is married to 42-year-old Jerry, her partner in business and a driver.  She has been in business working as an entrepreneur for almost 7 years. 

Lilibeth joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and a Kiva partner in the Philippines, in 2007. Since then, she has acquired capital for her business. She used her first to third loans for direct selling of Avon Products and Natasha Products. It has been great for her family. The business is running smoothly and bringing in enough proceeds. Now on her fourth loan, Lilibeth is applying for 20,000 pesos as additional capital for her business.

She hopes that in the near future she can build a more durable concrete house. And she also dreams of sending her children to school up to college so they can find a good jobs. She is hoping to have more stock to sell through her business.


About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: to buy more Avon and Natasha products to sell

loans.name: Redempta

texts.en:
Redempta L., 42, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Jose L., a messenger, they are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been selling ready-to-wear clothing for quite some time now.

Redempta has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times from CCT’s Cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her business.     

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 25,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more clothes that she can incorporate into her product inventory.

She dreams that her business will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.name: Ana María

texts.es: Ana María G. D. C. D. 60 años D. edad, resiD. en Cojutepeque, pueblo ubicado en el departamento D. Cuscatlán. Vive junto a su esposo el cual se dedica a trabajar como mecánico automotriz y junto a sus dos hijos D. 23 y 15 años D. edad, D. los cuales el mayor trabaja y el segundo se dedica a estudiar.  Ana María posee un negocio propio en el cual se encarga D. elaborar y vender pupusas, uno D. los platillos típicos salvadoreños que tienen mayor demanda por parte D. las personas D. este lugar. Su negocio está ubicado en las afueras D. su casa D. habitación, en donD. cada día Ana saca D. su hogar la cocina, mesas, sillas y todos los utensilios necesarios para iniciar su trabajo. Ella es una mujer con mucha experiencia, ya que posee 10 años D. realizar este oficio, razón por la cual posee muchos clientes, los cuales prefieren sus pupusas ya que es una persona la cual se ha ganado la confianza D. sus clientes. Ana María solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. maíz, frijoles, chicharrón y queso, los cuales son la materia prima para la elaboración D. las pupusas, así mismo desea surtir el negocio con bebidas heladas y calientes, esto con el fin D. que las personas no solo compren su productos para llevar a sus casa, sino también para que ellas opten por comer en el lugar, esto le brindaría  muchos beneficios a María puesto que aumentaría sus ventas los cual es D. mucha ayuda para su economía familia, la cual necesita mejorar en gran manera.
texts.en:
Ana María G. D. C., age 60, lives in Cojutepeque, a village located in the Cuscatlán department. She lives with her husband; he works as an auto mechanic. They have two children, ages 23 and 15. The older child works, and the second one goes to school. Ana María has her own business making and selling “pupusas” (flatbread stuffed with meat, cheese, or vegetables). It is one of the typical Salvadorian dishes that is in the most demand by people here. Her business is located outsiD. of her house. Everyday Ana takes the stove, tables, chairs, and all of the necessary utensils from her house to her business outsiD. in order to start her work. She is a woman with a lot of experience; she has been doing this work for ten years. That is why she has a lot of customers. They prefer her pupusas because she has won her customers’ confidence. Ana María is asking for a loan to be able to buy a greater quantity of corn, beans, pork rinds, and cheese. Those are the raw materials to make the pupusas. She also wants to stock her business with cold and hot drinks. This is so that people not only buy her products to take home, but they also opt to eat at her place. This will proviD. many benefits to María. It will increase her sales, and this is a big economical help to the family. The family needs to greatly improve their economic situation.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, cheese, rice, and beans

location.town: Cojutepeque en el departamento de Cuscatlán

loans.name: Francisca Del Carmen

texts.es: Francisca del Carmen G. D. M. D. 56 años D. edad, resiD. en el departamento D. Usulután. Vive en compañía D. su esposo quien se dedica a ayudarle con el negocio. DesD. hace 10 años que francisca posee su propio negocio, en el cual comercializa pollo, alitas y medallones D. pollo empaquetado, y así mismo embutidos, tales como salchichas y jamón. Ella es una mujer muy trabajadora la cual siempre ha tratado D. mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio, situación la cual le ha sido difícil, debido a que casi todas las ganancias las invierte en los gastos D. su hogar. Es por esta razón que Francisca solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. pollo, esto debido a que entre mayor cantidad compre, menores serán los precios por obtenerlo, lo cual le trae muchos beneficios a Francisca, ya que podrá obtener  mayores ganancias y así mismo podrá invertir más en el negocio.  Ella es una mujer muy responsable, la cual tiene muy buenos valores morales, por lo cual es muy querida en el mercado Regional D. Usulután, en donD. está ubicado su negocio.
texts.en:
Francisca del Carmen G. D. M., age 56, resides in the Usulután department of El Salvador. She lives in the company of her husband, who is dedicated to helping her with her business. For the past 10 years, Francisca has had own business in which she sells chicken, chicken wings and packaged cuts of chicken, as well as cold cuts such as sausage and ham. She is a very hard-working woman who has always tried to improve the shape of her business, a situation that has been difficult given that she spends almost all of her income on household expenses. For this reason, Francisca is requesting a loan so she can buy a larger quantity of chicken. With a larger quantity of chicken, the price to buy it will be lower, which would allow Francisca to benefit by earning more revenue and at the same time be able to invest more in her business. She is a very responsible woman and has very good moral values and therefore is well-liked in the Regional D. Usulután market, where her business is located.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.name: Anvar

texts.en:
O. Anvar is a very hard-working and enterprising man who cultivates his farmland and cares for his animals. Since it is to them that he owes his daily bread, he tries to take care of them as best he can. Every morning he can be seen walking to work. He is one of the most respected people in the area and is known as an example for his children and the townsfolk. The courage and dedication he puts into his job and his devotion to his family are what stand out in this man. Nonetheless, he has financial problems which is why Anvar is requesting your help with a loan of 10000 Somoni to increase his production by purchasing additional seeds and fertilizer.   

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed and fertilizer

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of cattle for expanding the business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom P., age 62, is married and lives with his wife in Takeo Province, Cambodia. They have three children. He is in the business of raising animals and growing crops, earning approximately US$ 2 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover his family expenses. He has been in business since 1999. His wife is a housewife who stays at home to look after the children and the household chores. Their standard of living has improved since P. began this business, so he wants a loan to expand it further. He is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work at a local garment factory. This is his first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the children to travel to work

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Rin Y., age 56, is married and resides with his wife in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He has five children. He has a business of selling fish with his wife, earning an income of approximately $4 each day. By doing so, he is able to cover his family expenses, especially the children’s education. 

He has been in this business since 1995. Their standard of living has been improved since Y. started this business, so he wants to have a loan to expand his business. Y. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase a motorbike to transport fish for sale at the market. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva. (Y. is pictured with his wife.)

loans.use: Buy a motorbike to transport fish for sale

loans.name: Rosie's Group

texts.en:
Rosie P. is 35 years old and she is from the town of Gomez, San Isidro. She is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosie P..

Rosie is married and has 6 school-aged children. She owns and operates a business venture providing manicure and pedicure services in the local community. Rosie has been involved in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from this activity.

In 2009, Rosie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase materials needed to provide service. Rosie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Luy

texts.en:
Luy S., 39, is married and lives with her five children in Takeo province. She is a farmer who works for less than US$1 each day, while her husband, pictured here, works in construction making US$5 each day. This couple is aided by two of the children who are construction workers.

The weather conditions have been difficult for farming in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult time for many farmers, Luy S. included.

Luy S. is asking for a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to use to commute to work. This will help reduce transportation costs and allow the family to save much more than before.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to use for commuting

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan M., age 36, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. They are shown together in the photo. They have three children.

M. is engaged in a business selling corn, earning approximately US$5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this business since 2005. Her husband sells palm fruits, earning an income of US$3 per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since M. has operated her business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of US$800 to purchase a motorbike to transport corn to sell at the market. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport corn to sell

loans.name: Jakhongir

texts.ru: Муратов Джахонгир проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 30 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам клиент зарабатывает путём разведения скота. Имеет небольшой коровник. Он покупает скот, откармливает и продает. Это помогает ему обеспечивать семью. Кредит берет для закупа скота. Именно сейчас покупка скота может быть выгодна, так как зимою животные исхудавшие и продаются по низким ценам. Он хочет приобрести корову и продать на рынке по более выгодной цене.
texts.en:
Jakhongir M. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 30 years old, married and has four children. His wife takes care of the household, while Jakhongir works in animal husbandry. He owns a medium-size cow shed. He purchases livestock, raises it and sells it. This income helps him look after his family. He is applying for a loan in order to purchase cattle. This time of the year is a favorable time to purchase animals, because over the winter cattle tend to lose weight and therefore command a lower price. He would like to purchase a cow and then sell it at the market at a higher price.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Laureta

texts.en:
Laureta S., 34, is from the town of Lipay Road Villasis, Pangasinan. She is married and has 5 school-aged children. Laureta owns and operates a business making and selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food, snacks and drinks in the community. Laureta has been involved in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Laureta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Laureta is requesting her first loan, for 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita P. is from the village of Magsaysay, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 69 years old, is married, and has three adult children.

Conchita is engaged in farming and also owns and operates a business selling rice in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for thirty years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Conchita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Conchita is requesting a new loan in the amount of 3,000 which will be used to purchase sacks of fertilizer and chemicals. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Conchita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family.  

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Khiev

texts.en:
Khiev N., 47, has a business selling brooms at the local market of Takeo province. She earns approximately US$3 each day while her husband, who is a rice farmer, makes less than US$1 a day.

This couple has three children: one is a student and two are employed as garment factory workers. Khiev N. told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$45 on food and US$15 on utilities.

Khiev N. has been making and selling brooms since 1998. Her brooms are made from a kind of long grass which grows in the forest.

Khiev N. is asking for a loan of US$1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to use to commute to work. This will help her children reduce transportation costs.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her childen to use for commuting

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El T., age 59, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She is shown with her husband in the photo. They have three children.

T. is engaged in a business selling desserts at her home, earning approximately US$2 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially the children’s education. She has been with this business since 2009. Her husband is a civil servant, earning an income of US$2 per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since T. has operated her business so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. She is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to study. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her children to travel to study

Her husband is a policeman. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.name: Abibath

texts.fr: A. Abibath est née le 17 février 1986 à Djidjè au Bénin.  Il y a 6 ans que Abibath s’est installée  à PK10 dans la commune de Sémé-Podji au Bénin.  Mariée à MITRODE Laurent, un forgeron, Abibath est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés.  Abibath vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Abibath a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Abibath vend des produits divers (savons, lait, galettes, conserves de sardines et de tomate, pâtes alimentaires, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Abibath s’approvisionne. Abibath exerce son activité depuis environs cinq ans, mais n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Abibath sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Abibath A. was born on the 17th of February, 1986, in Djidjè, Benin. Six years ago Abibath moved to PK10 in the Sémé-Podji borough of Benin. She is married to Laurent Mitrode, a blacksmith, and has five children, all of whom attend school; Abibath herself attended up to secondary school level. Abibath lives with her husband and children, and the couple work together to see to the family's needs. Now, she makes a living selling various products from home (soap, milk, biscuits, tinned sardines and tomatoes, pasta etc); she sources these from the international market in Benin. She has been working in this field for around five years, but has not yet sought a loan from ALIDé. However, she is now seeking her first loan in order to grow the business to meet increasing consumer demand.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing various products

loans.name: Agnès

texts.fr: Née en 1955 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, B. Agnès vit depuis 15 ans à PK11 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin.  Agnès est veuve et mère de six enfants, dont deux sont encore à sa charge.  Agnès vit seule avec ses enfants.  Agnès n’a fait que l’école primaire, mais tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Agnès vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs, sauce, riz, etc.).  Agnès exerce cette activité depuis 12 ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Agnès est une nouvelle bénéficiaire de ALIDé. Très sollicitée par ses clients, Agnès ambitionne renforcer son activité et agrandir son étalage afin de faire face à la demande sans cesse croissante. C’est la raison pour laquelle Agnès sollicite son premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1955 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Ms. B. Agnès has been living in PK11, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, Benin, for fifteen years. She is a widow and the mother of six children, of whom two are still in her care. She lives alone with her children. Agnès attended primary school only. To support herself, she sells food (cornmeal polenta, sauce, rice, etc.) She has been in this business for twelve years and gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is a new beneficiary of ALIDé. In high demand by her customers, she has the ambition of bolstering her business and expanding her display of goods, so as to cope with the ever-growing demand. For these reasons, Agnès is requesting her first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, fish, and condiments

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is a 32 year old father of two from Nairobi.  He is a fish monger and sells in the open market.  Daniel has been in this business for two years. 

He is requesting a loan of Kes. 20,000 to support his fish business.  He desires to live a good life and to create employment.  Daniel  says that he has learned to manage his business records since joining Faulu Kenya.  He describes himself as a capable salesman.

loans.use: Add stock of fish and fish products

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.en:
Feliciana N. is from the village of  Quezon Bukidnon. She is 59 years old, widowed and has 9 adult-aged children.  To make a living, Feliciana runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop in the local community.  Feliciana has been in business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Feliciana joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Feliciana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI to purchase additional products to sell.  Feliciana is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to expand her business. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Feliciana from HSPFI.
=======================================
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Bertille

texts.fr: A. Bertille est née le 5 novembre 1952 à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin.  Bertille est veuve et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés.  Bertille vit seule avec ses enfants au quartier Cocotomey à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a deux ans que la famille s’est installée là-bas.  Bertille n’a fait que l’école primaire.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Bertille vend  des boissons de la SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie) et des plateaux d’œufs au parc MIVVO à Sèmè-Podji.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et dans certains dépôts de boissons de Cotonou que Bertille s’approvisionne.  Bertille a 18 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine et sollicite son premier crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
A. Bertille was born on November 5, 1952 in Parakou, in northern Benin. She is a widow and the mother of four children who all had schooling. She lives alone with her children in the Cocotomey district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. The family settled there two years ago. Bertille attended primary school only. To address her needs, she sells beverages from SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie) and trays of eggs at the MIVVO parking lot in Sèmè-Podji. She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and from certain Cotonou beverage outlets. Bertille has eighteen years of experience in this domain and is requesting her first loan from ALIDé to bolster her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying beverages

loans.name: Elisabeth

texts.fr: O. Elisabeth est née en 1945 à Savè dans le département des collines.  Elisabeth est veuve et habite depuis 35 ans au quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.   Elisabeth est mère de six enfants qui ne sont plus à sa charge.  Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Elisabeth vend du charbon de bois à son domicile.  Elle a 30 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Elisabeth sollicite son premier crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité.
texts.en:
O. Elisabeth was born in 1945 in Savè, in Collines County. She is a widow and has been living in the Dandji district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, for 35 years. She is the mother of six children, who are no longer in her care. All of the children were provide with schooling. To address her needs, Elisabeth sells charcoal out of her home. She has thirty years of experience in this domain and gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She is requesting her first loan from ALIDé to bolster her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying charcoal

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en:
K. Sareth, 35, sells brooms at the local market of Takeo province. On average, she makes around $3 each day.  Her husband stays at home and helps her make brooms to sell. They have been making and selling brooms since 2000. 

Brooms are made of long grass which grows in the forest. 

They have three children living at home to support.  K. Sareth told a loan officer that she needs to spend around $45 on food and $5 on utility each month.  K. is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike to transport brooms to sell at the market.  This will help reduce their transportation expenses.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Eung

texts.en:
Eung Y., 60, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  They have three children.  She sells food, earning approximately $4 per day.  She is able to cover her family expenses, especially their children’s education. She has been in business since 1979. 

Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $1 per day.  Y. wants to expand her business and is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer for her husband to transport grass for sale.  This is her second loan from CREDIT.  (Y. is pictured with her husband)

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr: A. Gisèle est née en 1971 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a un an que Gisèle s’est installée avec son mari, DAH Epiphane, et ses trois enfants au quartier Yagbé à Cotonou.  Gisèle n’a fait que l’école primaire, mais tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Il y a huit ans, Gisèle s’est mise dans la vente de pâtes dentifrices de façon ambulante.  Gisèle est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé.  Gisèle a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé.  Gisèle voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits.  Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Gisèle sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Gisèle A. was born in 1971 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. One year ago, she moved in with her husband, Epiphane Dah, and his three children in the Yagbé district of Cotonou. Gisèle only attended primary school, but all of the children attend school. The couple shares the family responsibilities. Eight years ago, Gisèle began selling toothpaste as an itinerant vendor. Gisèle is on her third loan with ALIDé. She fully repaid the first two loans that she took out through ALIDé. Gisèle would like to build up her product inventory. Because of her very limited financial means, Gisèle is requesting a third loan through ALIDé.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase toothpaste

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam O., 33, is married and lives with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She has two children and sells fish and vegetable at home, earning approximately $1.50 per day.  She is able to cover her family expenses and has been with this business since 2004.  Her husband is an air-conditioner repairman, earning an income of $3 per day.  Sam wants to have a loan to expand her business and is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work.  This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike

loans.name: Tol

texts.en: Mrs. Tol L., 50, has been selling little fritters from home for an income. She is a married mother blessed with six children. Four of her children are single and two are married, living in their own homes. Another source of family income comes from her husband who sells rattan furniture. He buys furniture in bulk on credit from a handicraft maker and then uses his trailer to sell the furniture door-to-door around the community. Also, Mrs. Tol L. goes to sell rattan with her husband. In the past, Tol L. hired a neighbor's trailer to deliver her rattan to sell. Now, she hopes to reduce this fee, so she has decided to ask for a loan from Kiva to purchase a trailer to connect to her horse. She will use this method of transport to pick up her products. (Tol L.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To purchase a trailer.

loans.name: Herbette

texts.fr: A. Herbette est née le 2 septembre 1970 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a cinq ans que Herbette habite à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji.  Herbette vit là-bas avec son mari, MITOMBAOU Félix, un chauffeur, et ses deux enfants.  Herbette n’a jamais fréquenté l’école, mais tous les enfants de Herbette sont scolarisés.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Herbette vend des produits divers (riz, savon, lait, sardines) à son domicile. Herbette vend également de la nourriture à la devanture de sa maison. Herbette exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Herbette est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé.  Herbette a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits et sollicite un troisième crédit pour renforcer surtout son activité de divers.
texts.en:
Herbette A. was born September 2, 1970, in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Herbette has lived in Agblangandan, in the township of Sèmè-Podji, for five years. Herbette lives there with her husband, Félix Mitombaou, a driver, and her two children. Herbette did not attend school, but both of her children attend school now. The couple shares the family responsibilities. Herbette sells various products (rice, soap, milk, sardines) from her home. She also sells food from a walk-up window at her home. Herbette has been doing this type of work for five years and gets her supplies in Dantokpa, the international market of Bénin. She is on her third loan with ALIDé. She fully repaid the first two loans and is requesting a third loan to further build up her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase various products

loans.name: Ek

texts.en: Ek S., age 28, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She weaves Cambodian traditional silk, earning approximately $3 per day.  By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses.  Ek has been with this business since 2007.  Her husband uses his car as a taxi, earning an income of $3 per day.  Ek wants to have a loan to expand her business and is requesting $400 to purchase more raw silk to produce more products for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Jeannette

texts.fr: C. Jeannette est née en 1959 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a environs 9 ans que Jeannette s’est installée à Kadjacomé, dans la commune de Sémé-Podji.  Jeannette est mariée à C. Antoine, un pêcheur.  Le couple a trois enfants, qui vivent ensemble avec eux à Kadjacomé.  Certains des enfants sont scolarisés.  Jeannette n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Jeannette vend des plastiques au bord du lac de Agbalilamè dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji.  Il y a 10 ans que Jeannette exerce cette activité.  Jeannette s’approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo (capitale administrative du Bénin) et a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés.  Jeannette sollicite un troisième crédit pour renforcer son activité et mieux faire face à la demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
Jeannette C. was born in 1959 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. About nine years ago she setteld in Kadjacomé, in the community of Sémé-Podji, a district of Cotonou. Jeannette is married to Antoine C., a fisherman. The couple has three children, and the whole family lives together in Kadjacomé. Some of the children go to school. Jeannette never attended school. In order to provide for her and her children's needs, Jeannette sells household plastic goods by the lake of Agabaliamè in Sémé-Podji. Jeannette has been engaged in this business for 10 years. She purchases her stock at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo (the administrative capital of Benin); in the past she had obtained two loans from ALIDé, which she duly reimbursed. Jeannette is seeking a third loan in order to strengthen her business and better meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing plastic goods

loans.name: Chhun

texts.en: Chhun R., age 57, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She sells fish, earning approximately $5 per day. Chhun is able to cover her family expenses.  She has been in business since 2001.  Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $3 per day.  Chhun wants a loan to expand her business.  She is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more fish for resale.  This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy more fish for resale

loans.name: Karamatou

texts.fr: N. Karamatou est née le 15 juin 1972 à Zinvié au Bénin.  Depuis trois ans, Karamatou vit avec son mari, SIKIROU Affissou, un vendeur de pièces détachées, et ses deux enfants au quartier Sènadé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Karamatou n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a sept ans, Karamatou s’est mise dans la vente des pâtes dentifrices et des produits divers de façon ambulante.  Karamatou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Karamatou est à son deuxième crédit à ALIDé.  Karamatou a bien remboursé le premier crédit qu’elle a obtenu.  Karamatou voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits.  Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Karamatou sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
N. Karamatou was born on June 15, 1972 in Zinvié, in Benin.  For three years, she has been living with her husband, SIKIROU Affissou, who is a seller of replacement parts, and with her two children, in the Sènadé district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  The couple jointly ensure that family expenses are covered.  Karamatou never attended school.  Seven years ago, she started selling toothpaste and a variety of products door-to-door.  She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She is on her second ALIDé loan having repaid the first loan she obtained.  She would like to bolster her stock of goods.  But given the few financial means she has at her disposal, Karamatou is requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying toothpaste

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn B. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon.  She is 42 years old, married and has 6 school-aged children.  To make a living, Marilyn runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling mostly food and daily use products in the local community.  Marilyn has been in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Marilyn joined HSPFI to access financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Marilyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to expand her business.  This loan will be her 1st from HSPFI.  Marily plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 
---------------------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Expand her business

loans.name: Laure

texts.fr: A. Laure est née en 1975 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et vit depuis 30 ans au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou.  Laure est célibataire et mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Laure vit seule avec ses enfants.  Elle n’a fait que l’école primaire.  Pour assure les charges de la famille, Laure vend des produits divers (pâtes alimentaires, huile végétale, conserves de tomate, lait, petits pois, mayonnaise, etc.) à son domicile.  Parallèlement à cette activité, Laure vend également des produits pour cheveux dans sa boutique. Laure a cinq ans d’expérience dans ce domaine et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Elle sollicite son premier crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité et mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients.
texts.en:
A. Laure was born in 1975 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and has been living in the Finagnon district in Cotonou for thirty years.  She is unmarried and the mother of two children who are both in school and in her care.  She lives alone with her children.  Laure attended primary school only.  To cover family expenses, she sells a variety of goods (pasta, vegetable oil, canned tomatoes, milk, peas, mayonnaise, etc.) out of her home.  Along with this business, she also sells hair products in her shop.  She has five years of experience in this domain and gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  Laure is requesting her first ALIDé loan for bolstering her business and for responding better to the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying various goods

loans.name: Marie Jane

texts.en:
Marie Jane B. is from the village of Solinog, Calamba, Misamis Occidental.  She is 36 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Marie Jane owns and operates a general store.  Her main source of income comes from selling and buying coco lumber in the local community. Marie Jane has been in business for 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month.

In 2003, Marie Jane joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marie Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC to purchase additional products to sell.  Marie Jane is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and for working capital.  This loan will be her 12th loan from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 
---------------------------
About PMPC:
