Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Additional capital for her project.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en: Sok N., age 58, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia.   She is engaged in a weaver of Cambodian traditional silk, earning approximately $3 per day.  By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses.  Sok has been with this business since 2001. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of $1 per day.  Sok wants a loan to expand her business and is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase more raw silk to produce more silk products for sale. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy more raw silk to produce silk products

loans.name: Martine

texts.fr: G. Martine est née en 1972 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a trois ans que Martine vit au quartier Dandji à Cotonou.  Martine est mariée à ZANNOU Joël, un maçon, et mère de trois enfants.  Tous les enfants de Martine sont scolarisés.  Martine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille.  Martine a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire.  Depuis deux ans Martine vend du côme (aliment préparé à base de maïs), accompagné de poissons frits au Carrefour Abattoir à Cotonou.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, qu’elle s’approvisionne. Martine a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Marine sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et maximiser son profit.
texts.en:
G. Martine was born in 1972 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been living in the Dandji district in Cotonou for three years.  She is married to ZANNOU Joël, a mason, and is the mother of three children. All her children are in school.  She lives together with her husband and children.  The couple jointly support the family.  Martine has attended secondary school.  For two years, she has been selling côme (a food made from corn) served with fried fish, at Carrefour Abattoir in Cotonou.  She gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She has already benefited from an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid.  Martine is requesting a second loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business and maximizing her profit. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying corn, fish, condiments

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en:
Janeth C. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old, married and has 6 adult-aged children. To make a living, Janeth runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  Janeth has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Janeth joined HSPFI to access financial services help improve her living situation and to engage in business. Janeth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from HSPFI to purchase additional products to sell.  She is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP to expand her business.  This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 
---------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Expand the business.

loans.name: Mastula Nalukenge' S Group

texts.en:
Mastula is 27 years of age, married with one child.  Her family rents a one room house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and piped water at home and they eat three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses are utilities, school fees for children, medication, feeding the family and rent for her business and residence. 

Mastula owns a stall selling all types of food in Nakulabye, one of the city suburbs.  Mastula sells bananas, cassavas and sweet potatoes.  On average she receives 20 customers a day and has been in business for over two years.  

She sells on a retail basis only and has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her fourteenth loan, working with the same group mates.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas, sacks of cassava and sweet potatoes.  She aspires to see her business grow bigger.
.

loans.use: Buy more bananas, sweet potatoes and cassava.

loans.name: Chourb

texts.en: Chourb T., age 47, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She sells chickens and ducks at a local market, earning approximately $4 per day.  She is able to cover her family expenses.  Chourb has been in business since 2001.  Her husband helps his wife and earns the same amount of income.  Chourb wants a loan to expand her business and is requesting $1000 to purchase more ducks and chickens to sell.  This is her first loan from CREDIT. (Chourb's husband is pictured.)

loans.use: Buy more ducks and chickens to sell.

loans.name: Nicole

texts.fr: Z. Nicole est née en 1971 à Torri-Bossito au Bénin mais réside au quartier Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji depuis environs 2 ans.   Mariée à AGUEMON Donatien, un chauffeur, Nicole est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Nicole vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Nicole a eu quelques problèmes avec son mari mais malgré ce problème, le couple assure ensembles les charges de la famille.  Nicole n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Il y a 3 ans que Nicole mène comme activité, la vente d’oeufs devant la pharmacie Abattoir.  C’est à Dantokpa que Nicole s’approvisionne.  Nicole n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Abibath sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Nicole Z. was born in 1971 in Torri-Bossito in Bénin, but she has lived in the Agblangandan district of the municipality of Sèmè-Podji for the past two years or so. Married to Donatien AGUEMON, a driver, Nicole has five children, all of whom are at school and in her care. Nicole lives together with her husband and her children. She has had some problems with her husband but despite this, the couple cover the household expenses between them. Nicole has never been to school. For the past three years she has had a business selling eggs in front of the Abattoir pharmacy and she stocks up at Dantokpa. Nicole has never had a loan from ALIDé before. However, in order to expand her business and to meet heavy customer demand, she is applying for a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of eggs

loans.name: Manilyn

texts.en:
Manilyn A. is from the village of Pugaro Balungao, Pangasinan. She is 23 years old and single. To make a living, Manilyn owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Manilyn is just starting this business.

In 2010, Manilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Manilyn is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Manilyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Marcelina Undag's Group

texts.en:
Marcelina U. is from the village of Toril. She is 71 years old and the leader of a two member group loan offered by PMPC.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marcelina is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Marcelina owns and operates a hog raising and selling business. Marcelina has been in business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Marcelina joined PMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Marcelina has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC.  Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP to purchase livestock feed and supplies.  This loan will be the 10th from PMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue to supplement her family's income. 
----------------------------------
About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.use: Purchase livestock feed and supplies.

loans.name: Allen

texts.en:
Allen is 42 years of age, married with four children between 11 and 15 years of age.  Three go to school.  Her family rents a three roomed house where she stays with six people.  She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and piped water at home.  They eat three meals a day.

Allen operates owns a stall selling bananas in Namungoona market one of the city suburbs  She receives about 20 customers a day and has been in business for over five years.  Her main challenges are transportation and the increasing prices of food.  She sells on retail basis only and has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her fourteenth loan working with the same group mates.  She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas to sell.
.

loans.use: Buy more bananas.

loans.name: Rufia

texts.en:
Rufia is a carpenter and he makes lovely furniture for his customers. He hopes to own a big furniture stall in the future. 

He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 160,000 to purchase more materials to make more furniture to sell.  Rufia is determined to lift his business and family above poverty.  He is 35 years old and married with 2 children. His wife sells tailoring materials to support their family.  He has a good relationship with LAPO. He duly thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more materials to make more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Obidon

texts.fr: B. Obidon est née le 10 décembre 1978.  Il y a neuf ans que Obidon vit à PK10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, au Bénin.  Mariée à TOVIHOME Jacob, un plombier, Obidon est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Obidon vit ensemble aven son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Obidon n’a fait que l’école primaire.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Obidon vend des produits divers (savon, lait, bombons, cubes, enveloppes, etc) à son domicile.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Obidon s’approvisionne.  Obidon exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé.  Obidon sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer son activité et pour augmenter son profit.
texts.en:
Obidon B. was born on 10th December 1978. For the past nine years she has been living in PK10 in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. Married to Jacob TOVIHOME, a plumber, Obidon has three children, all of whom are at school and in her care. Obidon lives with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Obidon has been to primary school only. In order to cover her needs, she sells a variety of products (soap, milk, sweets, stock cubes, envelopes etc.) from home. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Obidon has been carrying out this activity for five years and has already had one loan from ALIDé. She is applying for a second loan in order to strengthen her business and increase her profit.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various products

loans.name: Chan

texts.en:
Chan S., age 30, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Takeo Province, Cambodia.  She sells groceries at home in her province, earning approximately $3 per day.  By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses.  She has been with this business since 2000. 

Her husband helps his wife in the business and earns the same amount of income. Chan wants a loan to expand her business and is requesting $1200 to purchase motorbikes for resale to make a profit. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: Buy motorbikes for resale.

loans.name: Channary

texts.en: T. Channary is 26 years old and resides with her husband and one young child in the Takeo province.  She stays at home looking after her young child and cooking food for her husband.  Her husband is a taxi driver who is able to make $6 per day. To earn more income to help support the family, T. Channary is asking for a loan of $1200 to open a fruit store.

loans.use: Open a fruit store.

loans.name: Ronelyn

texts.en:
Ronelyn J. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 29 years old. Ronelyn is married and has 1 school-aged children. To make a living, Ronelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. Ronelyn has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ronelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ronelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.  Ronelyn is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Ronelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 
-------------------------
About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Eseri

texts.en:
Eseri is 44 years of age, widowed, and has four children: aged between 11 and 15 years. Three of her children go to school. The family resides and rents a three-roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped-in water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include, paying utility bills, school fees for children, medication and feeding the family and rent for her business and residence. 

Eseri operates and owns a food stall in Nakulabye market in the city suburbs. Eseri sells all types of food and vegetables at the market. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over five years. She incurs the transport costs from buying food items from villages of Kiboga, about 55 miles from Kampala. Her main challenges are seasonality and the continually increasing prices of food items. She sells on a retail basis only and has been with MCDT for over seven years, servicing her fourteenth loan. She has been working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, sacks of cassava, sweet potatoes and cabbages. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to sell by wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of food items.

loans.name: Pascaline

texts.fr: B. Pascaline est née en 1970 à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique. Depuis 21 ans, Pascaline vit dans le quartier Dandji à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à ZANNOU Jean, un boucher, Pascaline est mère de trois enfants. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés.  Pascaline vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Pascaline n’a jamais fréquenté l’école.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Pascaline vend de la bouillie «Akpan » (nourriture fait à base d’amidon de maïs). Pascaline exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pascaline a déjà bénéficié d’un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. Pascaline sollicite un deuxième crédit pour renforcer ses activités et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Pascaline B. was born in 1970 in Allada in the "département" (administrative division) of Atlantique. For the past 21 years she has lived in the Dadji district of Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. Married to Jean ZANNOU, a butcher, Pascaline has three children. Not all the children are at school. Pascaline lives with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Pascaline has never been to school. In order to meet her needs, she sells "Akpan" cereal (made of corn starch). She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years and gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Pascaline has already had one loan from ALIDé which she repaid without incident. She is applying for a second loan in order to strengthen her business and better satisfy customer demand.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn, sugar and milk

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora D. is from the town of Zone IV Rosales, Pangasinan. She is 45 years old. Flora is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Flora owns & operates a butcher shop, butchering and selling a variety of meats in the local community. Flora has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 12000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Flora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Flora is requesting a loan of 20000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Flora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en: Chhem T., age 48, is a widow and resides with her children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. She has young child. She is engaged in a business of selling fruits and vegetables in her province, earning an approximate income of US$ 5 per day. By doing so, she is able to cover her family expenses, especially on the children’s education. She has been with this business since 1999. The family’s standard of living has been improved since T. has been with this business, so she wants to have a loan to expand her business. T. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase fruits and vegetables for resale to make more profit. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables for sale.

loans.name: Pélagie

texts.fr: V. Pélagie est née le 31 août 1963 à Cotonou. Pélagie est veuve et mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Pélagie vit seule avec les enfants à Djeffa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 20 ans.  Pélagie a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Pélagie mène comme activité, la vente des objets de piété (livrets de prière, chapelet, images, etc.) ainsi que des pots de fleurs devant l’Eglise catholique de Djeffa. Pélagie exerce cette activité depuis 15 ans et s’approvisionne au Bénin et au Nigeria, état voisin du Bénin.  Pélagie n’a encore jamais bénéficié de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dans le but d’agrandir son activité afin de mieux satisfaire la demande nombreuse des clients, Pélagie sollicite un premier prêt auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Pélagie V. was born on 31st August 1983 in Cotonou. She is a widow and has three children, all of whom are at school and in her care. Pélagie has lived alone with her children in Djeffa in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji for the past 20 years. She went to school up until secondary school level. In order to meet her needs, Pélagie has a business selling religious objects (prayer booklets, rosary beads, pictures etc..) as well as pots of flowers in front of the Catholic church in Djeffa. She has been carrying out this activity for 15 years and gets her supplies in Bénin and in the neighbouring country of Nigeria. Pélagie has never had a loan from ALIDé before, but with the aim of expanding her business in order to satisfy heavy customer demand more readily, she is applying for a first loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of religious objects and pots of flowers

loans.name: Rubelyn

texts.en:
Rubelyn A. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 27 years old. Rubelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Rubelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Rubelyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rubelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Rubelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Rubelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of soya

loans.name: Chori

texts.ru: Пайгамов Чори проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 56 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Клиент не имеет высшего образования. Подрабатывает строительными работами по найму. Кроме того занимается растениеводством. Он в основном сажает пшеницу и оващи. Занимается этим видом деятельности уже 6 лет. Урожай который он получает, вывозит на рынок. А часть оставляет своей семье. Сейчас посевной сезон и клиент планирует купить качественные семена. Это поможет ему получить хороший урожай, что привлечет новых клиентов. Кредит берет для закупа семян.
texts.en:
Chori P. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 56 years old. He is married, with six children. He does not have a higher education. He earns some money as a construction worker for hire. In addition, he cultivates crops, mainly wheat and vegetables. He has been growing crops for over six years. Some of the produce is for consumption by his family, and the rest is sold at the market. It is now planting season and he is planning to purchase high quality seeds. This will help him achieve a plentiful harvest and attract new clients. He is applying for a loan to purchase seeds.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds

loans.name: Prossy

texts.en: Prossy is 55 years of age, widowed, and has nine children between 15 and 36 years of age. Three of her children go to school. The family resides and rents a three-roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include, paying utility bills, school fees for children, medication and feeding the family and rent for her business and residence. Prossy operates a food stall in Nakulabye market in the city suburbs. Prossy sells all types of food items and vegetables at the market. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over five years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying food staff from villages of Kiboga about 55 miles from Kampala. Her main challenges are seasonality and the ever-increasing prices of food items. She sells on a retail basis only and has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her fourteenth loan working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, sacks of cassava, sweet potatoes and cabbages. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow bigger and selling on wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, sweet potatoes .

loans.name: Juanita

texts.en: Juanita is 61 and has a shop for repairs and vulcanizing. This is the only way she can provide for the needs of her family and send her children to school. She is the mother of five children. She requested a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to have additional capital to run her business. This loan will help her a lot in sustaining her family.

loans.use: Repair supplies

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en:
Anthony S. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and cooking oil in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell. Anthony is 40 years old and married to a doctor. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for settlement.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Buy more jerrycans of cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Sengly

texts.en: R. Sengly, 24, is a garment factory worker, making US$2 each day in the Takeo province. She is married but has no children yet. Her husband, pictured here, sells salt and makes approximately US$3 every day. R. Sengly would like a loan of US$1,000, which her husband needs to purchase a motorbike so that he can transport salt to sell from house to house.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for selling salt

loans.name: Nourn

texts.en:
Nourn K., age 34, is married and resides with his wife in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He has two children. He works in the agriculture sector, farming with his wife and earning an income of approximately US$3 per day. By doing so, he is able to cover his family expenses, especially for the children’s education. He has been farming since 2000.

The family's standard of living has improved since K. has been in this business, so he wants to have a loan to expand his business. K. is requesting a loan of US$500 to purchase a motorbike to transport fruits and vegetables for sale at the market when they are available from the fields. This is his first loan from CREDIT, Kiva's partner. (K.'s wife is pictured)

loans.use: buy a motorbike to sell fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Arien

texts.en:
Arien B. is from the village of D Ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old. To make a living, Arien owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector selling a variety of specialized food products in the local community. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products in the local community. Arien has been engaged in her business for 5 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Arien joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Arien is availing her first cycle loan in the amount of 3,000.00 PHP from PMPC which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Monica Birungi ‘S Group

texts.en:
Monica is 40 years old and married, with eight children aged between 5 and 18 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and rents a three-room house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home, and eats three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include: paying utility bills, school fees for the children, medication and feeding the family, and rent for her business and residence.

Monica operates and owns a food stall in Nakulabye market of the city suburbs. She sells all types of food available at the market and vegetables. On average of she receives 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over five years. She incurs transport costs buying food stuffs from the village of Kiboga, about 55 miles from Kampala.

Her main challenges are seasonality and the ever increasing prices of food stuffs. She sells on a retail basis only and has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her fourteenth loan, working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, sacks of cassava, sweet potatoes and cabbages. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to sell wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more food stuffs like bananas, sweet poatatoes and cassava

loans.name: Bless

texts.en:
Bless T. is from the village of Mitacas, Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 41 years old, married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Bless owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products in the local community. Bless has been engaged in her business for 3 years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Bless joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Bless has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Bless is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the twelfth loan taken out by Bless from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her retail business

loans.name: Pélagie

texts.fr: Z. Pélagie est née en 1968 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Il y a huit ans que Pélagie habite à Agblangandan dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji.  Pélagie est mariée à BONOU Basile et mère de deux enfants. Pélagie a un autre enfant à sa charge.  Pélagie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Pélagie n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a 10 ans, Pélagie s’est mise dans la vente de pâte de maïs et de l’igname frite de façon secondaire.  C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Pélagie s’approvisionne.  Pélagie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant bénéficié de six crédits auparavant. Les crédits ont été bien remboursés. Pélagie sollicite un septième crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement et élever le niveau de son activité ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Pélagie Z. was born in 1968 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. For the past eight years she has lived in Agblangandan in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji. Pélagie is married to Basile BONOU and has two children of her own. She also has another child in her care. She lives with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Pélagie has never been to school. Ten years ago she set herself up in the sale of corn dough, and she also sells fried yam as a secondary activity. She gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Pélagie is an old client of ALIDé having already benefited from six loans in the past. The loans were all repaid without incident. Pélagie is applying for a seventh loan from ALIDé to strengthen her working capital and expand her business; this will allow her to satisfy customer demand more easily.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of corn and condiments

loans.name: Yvette

texts.fr: A. Yvette est née le 12 janvier 1973 à Pobè, mais habite depuis 11 ans à PK10 dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin.  Mariée à BOCO Toussaint, un instituteur, Yvette est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés et tous à sa charge.  Yvette vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants.  Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Yvette n’a fait que l’école primaire.  Pour faire face à ses besoins, Yvette vend des produits de beauté de façon ambulante. Yvette exerce cette activité depuis 13 ans et s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin.  Yvette a déjà obtenu quelques crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Yvette sollicite un nouveau crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer son activité ; ce qui lui permettra de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle et de se faire plus de revenus.
texts.en:
Yvette A. was born on 12th January 1973 in Pobè, but has been living for the past 11 years in PK10 in the municipality of Sèmè-Podji in Bénin. Married to Toussaint BOCO, a primary school teacher, Yvette has three children, all of whom are at school and in her care. Yvette lives with her husband and children. The couple cover the household expenses between them. Yvette went to primary school only. In order to meet her needs, Yvette is an itinerant vendor, selling beauty products. She has been carrying out this activity for 13 years and gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. Yvette has already had several loans from ALIDé which she repaid without incident. She is applying for a new loan from ALIDé in order to strengthen her business; this will allow her to meet customer demand more easily and to make more money.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of beauty products

loans.name: Aceya

texts.en: Aceya M. is currently in the business of selling food in her hotel (restaurant) and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and sodas to sell. Aceya is 21 years old and is married to a mechanic. She has two children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Josephina

texts.en:
Josephina P. is from the village of Mauswagon, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 52 years old, is married, and has four adult children.

Josephina owns and operates a business venture in agriculture sector which is hog raising. She has been engaged in her business for eleven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Josephina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. 

Josephina is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional capital for her hog raising. This loan will be her 9th cycle loan from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional Capital for her hog raising

loans.name: Fatimo

texts.en:
Fatimo is a friendly and a hardworking woman. She sells cosmetics at retail prices in Ibadan and has been in this business for a long time. She uses her years of experience in business to attract and retain more customers.

Fatimo hopes to expand her business and hopes for a loan of NGN 40,000 to purchase more cosmetics to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

Fatimo is married with two children. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports their home.

Fatimo has a good relationship with LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization). LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Juvy Lynne's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Juvy Lynne P. is from the village of Magsaysay, Sibutad, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 23 years old and has only one infant child.

She owns and operates a business providing transportation services in the local community. Her source of income comes primarily from the income of her motorcycle, earning 7,000 PHP monthly.

In 2008, Juvy Lynne P. joined PMPC to gain access to its programs and services. Jovelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 Php  from PMPC. Jovelyn is requesting a new loan of 10,500 PHP which will be used to purchase housing materials for her house repair. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Rosalita from PMPC. 

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for purchase of materials for her house repair

loans.name: Irenia

texts.en: Irenia P. is from the village of Banlag, Valencia City. She is 57 years old, is married, and has eight school-aged children. Irenia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Irenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Irenia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 4th from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard A. is an individual client of Pearl Microfinance in Kyenjojo. He is a friendly and determined-to-work married man with 4 children all still in school as he takes care of 3 dependents.

Richard has operated a butchery in Kigunda Trading Centre for 3 years from which he is able to collect 70000 UGX as profits weekly. He attributes this to his good customer care and the quality meat that he sells from his butcher shop. He works so hard to ensure that he becomes a successful business man as well as have a stable and well established family.

Richard needs a loan to be able to increase his purchase of cows so as to increase his sales and hence income and profits.

loans.use: To buy more cows for his business.

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
Milagros C. is from the village of Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years old. Milagros is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Milagros owns & operates a general store selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Milagros has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Milagros joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Milagros from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is 42 years of age and married with 8 children aged between 8 and 23 years. All her children go to school. The family owns and resides in a 3-room house where she stays with 6 people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family has three meals a day.

Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children, medication, feeding the family and rent for her business premises.

Rose operates a ladies salon in Kanyanya and works upon all types of hair doing weaving, plaiting, relaxing, and hair cutting. On average she receives 10 customers a day. She has done this business for over 5 years.

She incurs transport costs to and from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city, where she buys cosmetics. Her main challenges are seasonality and the ever-increasing prices of cosmetics. She sells on retail basis only.

Rose has been with MCDT for over 7 years servicing her 14th loan working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more cosmetics and hair extensions. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and eventually to own a bridal salon.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of cosmetics and hair extensions.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Sao O. is 30 years old and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is a garment factory worker who is able to make about $2 per day, while her husband is a policeman with a salary of $80 per month.

Sao O. is asking for a loan of $1200 to make a new investment. She will purchase a taxi for her husband so that he can operate it to make additional income to help support their family.

loans.use: To purchase a taxi.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John A. sells bags of maize at retail prices to his customers. Maize in Nigeria is used for various food preparations. It can be eaten roasted, boiled, or ground. The demand for it is high. John hopes to be a major maize distributor in the future.

John hopes for a loan amount of NGN 60,000 to purchase more bags of maize to sell. He is itching for expansion in his business.

John is married and his wife sells tailoring materials and they are blessed with 4 children. The eldest child is 15 years while the youngest child is 6 years old. His children attend school and they are excelling in school.

John says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize to sell.

loans.name: Bella's Group

texts.en:
Bella D. is from the village of Villa Nuesa. She is 35 years old. Bella is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Bella D.'s group.

Bella is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Bella owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Bella has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Bella joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Bella has successfully repaid a previous loan of 35,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Bella is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the tenth loan taken out by Bella from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. is an individual client of Pearl Microfinance in Kyenjojo. He is a friendly and hard working man with a business of selling seedlings from a nursery bed for two years, as seen in the photo holding one of his plants.

Since Kyenjojo is a fertile area for farming, many people have resorted to planting trees and other crops inclusive of flower seedlings and it works well for David. He is able to make enough profits that keep him in business as well as help him take good care of his family.

David has worked from Ntonwa trading centre for two years and his biggest challenge is the lack of transport to collect the seeds for his bed. In the future, he would like to turn his bed into a leading nursery bed and seedling supplier as well as to have a well-established family.

David needs a loan to be able to expand his nursery bed by increasing the stock of seedlings. David is a father of six children and all are still in primary section.

loans.use: To buy more seeds for his nursery bed.

loans.name: Stewart

texts.en: Stewart L. is from the village of Sugarland, Valencia Bukidnon. He is 26 years old. Stewart is married. To make a living, Stewart owns & operates a retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling used clothing or ukay ukay, aside from that Stewart owns a motorcycle for transportation services in the local community. Stewart has been engaged in his business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $108 US) for these activities. He is shown with his wife in the photo. In 2009, Stewart joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Stewart has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Stewart is requesting a second loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Olaide

texts.en: Olaide loves her business of selling foodstuffs. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes to grow her business. She hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is married with 2 children. Her children attend school and they are making progress. Her husband sells stationery to help support the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Heng Chuong Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group, which consists of 21 people, is located I. Trapeang Angk village I. Takeo province.  All the members will use their loans I. different ways. Mrs. Heng C., the village bank president, will use part of her loan to buy fertilizers for her rice field, and will use the rest to buy fuel for her irrigation machine which waters the rice field.  Her husband, Mr. S. Sam, helps her with the farming. Mrs. Heng C. is a 46-year-old mother with three children, one of whom is working I. a garment factory, while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Akmurod

texts.ru: Гафуров Акмурод проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 45 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Акмурод занимается растениеводством. Он в основном сажает оващи. В этой деятельности более 10 лет. До этого он работал в мастерской, починкой автомашины. Акмурод хочет расширить свой бизнес. Он намерен посеить разные другие виды оващей. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Akmurod G. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 45 years old. He is married and has six children. His wife takes care of the household. Akmurod himself cultivates crops, mainly vegetables. He has been growing crops for more than ten years. Prior to this, he worked as a car mechanic at a repair shop. Akmurod would like to expand his business. He would like plant new types of vegetables. He is applying for a loan to purchase seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Irina Chakraborty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Ador

texts.en:
Ador A. is from the village of San Antonio, Talakag Bukidnon. He is 56 years old. Ador is married and has 4 adult children.  Ador operates a family member's taxi business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services through a "habal-habal" to the local community (a habal-habal is a motorcycle with an extended seat that carries 2-6 passengers).  Ador has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $65) for these activities.

In 2010, Ador joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business. Ador is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan Ador has taken out from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Serifat

texts.en: Serifat loves sarongs and that is why she sells them to make a living. Sarongs in Nigeria are worn mostly by women and young ladies. She hopes to own a boutique in the future where she will sell sarongs. She hopes for a loan amount of 60,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more sarongs to sell. She is 30 years old and happily married with 2 children. Her eldest child is 10 years old and the youngest is 4 years old. Her children attend school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Kigunda Tukwatanise Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
T. Colonel has a business of brick laying in Kiboti trading centre. He makes and burns the bricks. His customers are often unpredictable, although they keep coming to him because of his good customer care skills. He is a friendly and hardworking man, married with eight children between the ages of 2 and 15 years.

Colonel works hard to ensure that he expands regionally and has a steady supply. He works to have a stable family. He needs a loan to help him expand his business by enabling him to buy firewood for burning his bricks.

He is shown at the top left in the small photo and also appears in the group photo. He is the leader of his lending group.

loans.use: To buy firewood for burning his bricks

loans.name: Enhmaa

texts.en:
Enhmaa is 32 years old and lives with her husband and their three children in the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They operated a meat selling business from 2004 to July, 2009. If her husband is able to rent another counter, she will continue their meat selling business. 

During the day, she has been a renting counter with other people for her women's accessories business at the “Herlen” trading center. She is planning to rent a counter at a new trading center as well. Enhmaa is a very hardworking person and says, “ I would like to expand my business and I'm working hard to purchase my own plot of land with a house in the future.” She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of women's accessories to sell during the upcoming Mongolian New Year celebration.

loans.use: To buy women's accessories for resale

loans.name: Sumini

texts.en:
Sumini is 46 years of age and married with eight children between the ages of 10 and 30. Four of her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a three-roomed house, where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for the children, medication and feeding the family.

Sumini  owns  a mini bakery in Kitawuluzi, selling all types of fried items like chapati, samosas and donuts. She sells to all categories of people. On average, she receives 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. She incurs transport costs to and from the place where she buys cartons of baking flour and jerrycans of cooking oil. 

Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season, because she works from a muddy and open place. She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT, a Kiva partner, for over 10 years, servicing her 20th loan and working all this time with the same group mates. 

She wants to use this loan to buy more cartons of baking flour and cooking oil. She is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to start selling on a wholesale basis only.
.

loans.use: To buy more cartons of baking flour and jerycans of cooking oil

loans.name: Civelina

texts.en:
Livelina D. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 62 years old. Livelina is married and has 8 adult children. Livelina owns & operates a piggery. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Livelina has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month (about $76 US) for these activities.

In 2010, Livelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Livelina is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the first loan she has taken out from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en:
Abiola has a fish pond where she raises fingerlings into fish to sell. She loves this business because of the profits. She works hard to ensure that her fish-pond business expands. She hopes for a loan of 30,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more fingerlings to raise into fish to sell. She is a hardworking woman and she is so determined to excel in business and family life. 

She is married with two children. Her husband is a civil servant and he also supports their home. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more fingerlings

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa C. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. She is married and has 5 school-aged children.

To make a living Elsa operates a sari-sari (variety) shop where she sells food and daily use products to the local community. Elsa has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Elsa joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elsa successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI which she used to purchase additional products to sell. Elsa is requesting her second loan, of 8000 PHP, which she will invest in her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business.

loans.name: Batsetseg

texts.en:
Batsetseg J. is 44 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Tov province, Mongolia. Her husband owns and operates his own minibus in their province. They have been living in their current home for 20 years.

She and her husband are planning to buy a plot of land with a yard for their children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, in the future.

Batsetseg has operated a meat selling business with her husband at the “Bayanhaan” market since 1999. Her husband is very supportive of her and her business. He helps with the business in many ways, including purchasing and transporting large amounts of meat for the business.

Because of this couple's hard work and determination they were able to purchase their own minibus and have been paying for all three of their children's education fees.

Batsetseg says, “I would like to work hard to pay the loan on time and to be a reliable customer of the bank. Also, I would like to create a secure financial future for my family and for my three children's future life.” Batsetseg is a very hardworking and honest person. If she says that she will do something, she always reaches her goal.

Batsetseg is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to purchase a large amount of meat for her retailing business.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her butcher shop.

loans.name: Mrs. Sro Try Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nineteen people who live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province make up the village bank loan. They will use their loans for different purposes.

Mrs. Sro Try is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer and pig breeder. In her rice farming, she now faces a small problem because her field is infertile soil so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support her field and she would use the rest of the loan to buy pig food for her pigs.

Her husband, Mr. Tev Neang, is a bicycle rickshaw driver who can make a small income to support the family. Mrs. Sro Try is a mother of three children who all attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and also pig food for her pigs.

loans.name: Bwizi Livestock Marketing Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
Jackson M. is 45 years old and the leader of his lending group in Kyenjojo. He appears in the small photo at the top left just like in the big photo and he is a very hard working and friendly man with 7 children, 5 of them still in school as he takes care of two dependents.

Jackson is involved in the business of goat selling from Benga Bwizi subcounty and he is able to make weekly profits of 45,000. He believes that once his business expands, his income and profits will also rise. He hopes to become a strong business person and with the loan, he hopes to expand his business operations for more profit, by buying more goats for reselling.

loans.use: To buy more goats for resale.

loans.name: Ndéye

texts.en:
Ndèye B. is 35 years old, married and the mother of 6 children. She has been a member of the Village Bank "MBarry Gouytane" for eight years.

Her main activity consists of raising cattle and sheep and selling them on the market. This loan will allow her to buy more livestock.

loans.use: To Increase her working capital.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en: Mrs. Thorn S. is a villager in Ta Pov village in Takeo province. She is a rice middleman who buys rice to keep in stock and then re-sells for a better price. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to keep in stock. Her husband, Mr. Ngoy Chhorn, is a farmer. Mrs. Thorn S. is a 44-year-old mother of three children, one of whom is a laborer while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy rice

loans.name: Hadjah

texts.en:
Hadjah owns a bar in Kitawuluzi selling all types of beers. She sells to all kinds of people with an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. She incurs costs transporting crates of beer and jerrycans of alcohol. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy and open place. She sells on a retail basis only.

Hadjah is 51 years of age and married with eight children between the ages of 15 and 36. Three of her children go to school. Her family owns a three-room house where they live. Hadjah takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water at home and eats three meals a day. Her biggest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for children, medication and feeding the family.

Hadjah has been with MCDT for over ten years, now on her 20th loan working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more crates and jerrycans of alcohol. She hopes to own her business, see it grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and jerrycans of alcohol

loans.name: Elyn

texts.en: Elyn T. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Elyn owns and operates a business selling meat in the market, primarily butchering and selling pork. She has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Elyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Elyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Rolan

texts.en:
Rolan O.'s main source of income comes from providing transport services with his motor vehicle. He is 40 years old, married and has school-age children. They are from the village of San Antonio, Talakag, Bukidnon. Rolan has been in his business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2010, Rolan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Rolan is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide more better service. This will be his first loan from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue to improve his business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide more better  service

loans.name: Phav

texts.en:
Mrs. Phav T. is a villager who lives in Ta Pov Village in Takeo Province. 

She is a rice middleman, a person who buys large quantities of rice to keep in stock and then re-sells it later for a better price. Because her business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to keep in her stock. 

Her husband, Mr. Huy Heang, is a farmer. Mrs. Phav T. is the mother of five children who attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy more rice to keep in her stock.

loans.name: Meliza

texts.en:
Meliza M. is from the village of Pangantucan. She is 29 years old. Meliza is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Meliza owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Meliza has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Meliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Meliza has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Meliza is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Meliza's second loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Enhtsetseg

texts.en:
Enhtsetseg is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tov Province, Mongolia. 

Her husband operates a cell phone business at a counter in the Mobi Shop in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Cell phone businesses face high demand in Mongolia. Enhtsetseg and her husband have been planning to expand their cell phone businessand their counter at the Mobi Shop, which is one of the biggest cell phone shops in Mongolia. They started their cell phone business in 2009. 

Previously, Enhtsetseg had spent four years selling recycled raw materials with her husband at the center of the province. Enhtsetseg is a decent, very hardworking and honest person. If she says that she will do something, she always makes an effort and reaches her goal. She says, “I would like to have  a bigger counter for our business." 

She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large quantity of cell phones for her business at wholesales prices.

loans.use: To purchase a large quantity of cell phones for her business

loans.name: Sulton

texts.ru: Асоев Султон проживает в районе Дж. Руми. Возраст, 40 лет. Женат, имеет 8 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Султон более 7 лет занимается животноводством. Он в основном разводит скот у себя дома. Кредит просит для закупа скота. Султон хочет увеличеть их количество и весной продать по выгодной цене.
texts.en:
Sulton A. lives in the J. Rumy district. He is 40 years old, married and has 8 children. His wife is a homemaker. Sulton has been involved in animal husbandry for over 7 years. He primarily breeds livestock at home. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of livestock. Sulton wants to increase his livestock quantity and resell it in the spring at a profitable price.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar Sangaré est un homme marié de 30 ans qui vit avec sa femme et son enfant dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter le système scolaire, il s’intéressa très vite aux activités génératrices de revenus. C’est ainsi qu’il a mené pendant des années différentes activités dans le chef lieu de la  capitale régionale (Sikasso), mais sans succès, il décida alors de venir à Bougouni, au bercail, pour apprendre la menuiserie bois auprès  d’un de ses amis. Avec une expérience de 10 ans, il maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité.
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, Monsieur Boubacar Sangaré décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il est à son deuxième prêt individuel. Le premier a été remboursé sans aucune difficulté. 
Il compte acheter avec ce deuxième prêt,  25  planches en bois, 3 boites de colles et 10 kilogrammes de pointes.  Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Manankoro auprès des grossistes et producteurs. 
Il  compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 55 000 FCFA.  Avec ce bénéfice il compte améliorer son atelier et assurer les dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
Mr Boubacar Sangaré, aged 30, is married and lives with his wife and child in the neighborhood of North Hérémakono in the city of Bougouni, located in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Since he was not fortunate enough to attend school, he took very early an interest in income generating activities. He unsuccessfully tried for several years different activities in Sikasso, the capital city of the region, before deciding to return to his native Bougouni, where le learnt carpentry with a friend of his. Now, ten years later, he is a skilled and experienced carpenter and his work is in high demand. To meet the needs of his growing customer base, Mr Boubacar Sangaré decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is his second individual loan. He repaid his first loan without any difficulty. He wants to use his second loan to buy 25 planks, 3 boxes of glue and 10 kilograms of tacks. He gets his supplies from wholesalers and producers in Bougouni and Manankoro. He expects to make a profit of 55,000 CFA francs a month, which he will use to upgrade his workshop and provide for his family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carpentry materials

loans.name: Yor

texts.en: Mrs. Yor S. is a villager from Ta Ou Khang Cheung Village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Pich Ben, are farmers who try to work hard to support their family. Although they try to work hard, they still do not earn enough to support her family. To improve their living conditions, Mrs. Yor S. is asking for a loan to buy a cow to start a breeding business. Mrs. Yor S. is the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy a cow to start breeding business.

loans.name: Mbéne

texts.en: Mbéne N. is a 48-year-old woman from Diourbel, Senegal. She is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of the "MBarry Gouytane" village bank for eight years. Mbéne N. raises cattle and sheep and sells them in the market. With this loan, she will buy new cattle and sheep.

loans.use: To buy new livestock

loans.name: Arouna

texts.fr:
Monsieur Arouna S. est un homme marié de 38 ans et père de 2 enfants qui vit avec sa femme et ses enfants dans le quartier Massablacoura de  la ville de  Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté le système scolaire, très vite il commença les activités économiques notamment les travaux journaliers auprès des maçons. Finalement il décida de mener une activité d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de  boutique. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son grand frère.  Avec une expérience de 5 ans, Monsieur Arouna S. maîtrise son activité.
Après avoir correctement remboursé, le premier prêt Arouma est à son deuxième prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, des articles divers pour sa boutique (sucre, thé, laits, pâtes alimentaires, savons, bonbons, anti moustiques) afin de pouvoir attirer la clientèle.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bougouni et à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes et vend en détail, au comptant et à crédit. Sa clientèle est composée de toute la population locale.
 Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Arouna S. espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA  qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Arouna S. is a married 38-year-old man and the father of two children.
