He lives with his wife and children in the Massablacoura neighborhood of the city of Bougouni (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). Never having gone to school, he began working for money very quickly, chiefly as a day laborer for masons. He eventually decided to run a business buying and selling various grocery items. He learned this business from his older brother. With five years' experience, Mr. Arouna S. knows his business very well. After fully repaying his first loan, Arouna is on his second individual loan, which he plans to use to buy various articles for his shop (sugar, tea, milk, pasta, soap, candy, mosquito repellent) in order to attract customers. He gets his supplies in Bougouni and in Bamako (capital of the Republic of Mali) from wholesalers and retailers, paying with cash and on account. His customers come from the entire local population. With this loan, Mr. Arouna S. hopes to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA, which will be used essentially to enlarge his shop.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of articles for shop

loans.name: Mafouné

texts.fr:
Madame Mafouné Traoré est une femme mariée de 38 ans et mère de 4 enfants.  Elle vit avec son époux et ses enfants dans le quartier  Hérémakono-Nord de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 Mafouné  n’a pas eu  la chance de fréquenter l’école moderne, très vite elle commença les activités génératrices de revenus notamment la préparation et la vente des jus de boissons non alcoolisées. Elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une amie.  Avec 3 années d’expérience, elle maîtrise son activité et est très sollicitée.
Après 4 prêts  solidaires, elle est à son premier prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter un congélateur.
Ce congélateur indispensable à la bonne marche de ses activités qui a une demande de plus en plus forte, sera acheté sur place  à Bougouni. Elle vend  ses jus de façon ambulante dans le quartier et à domicile à une clientèle composée d’hommes de femmes et d’enfants, au comptant surtout.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 35 000 FCFA qui lui permettra  d’améliorer son entreprise et payer les intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mafouné Traoré is 38 years old, married and the mother of four children. She lives with her husband and children in the North Hérémakono district of Bougouni (in the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mafouné did not have the opportunity to attend a modern school; very early on she began working to earn money. In particular, she learned to prepare and sell non-alcoholic juice beverages. She learned this type of work from a friend. With three years of experience, she has become quite skilled at her work, and she is quite in demand. After four joint loans she is on her first individual loan, which she plans to use to buy a freezer. This freezer, essential to carrying out her work which is more and more in demand, will be bought in Bougouni. She sells her juices traveling around her district as well as from her home, to a clientele of men, women, and children who pay mostly in cash. With this loan, she expects to earn a monthly profit of 35,000 FCFA which will allow her to grow her business and pay interest on the loan through Soro Yiriwaso.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase a freezer

loans.name: Dulamjav

texts.en:
Dulamjav is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tuv province, Mongolia. Her husband is a laborer in Korea, and he comes to Mongolia once a year for a vacation. Her oldest daughter is a university student in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Dulamjav's youngest daughter attends a local secondary school. They have been living in their current home for ten years.

Because of her hard work and determination, Dulamjav bought a car this year with the profits from her business. During the day, she has been renting a counter for her toy-retailing business, which currently has working capital of 3,200,000 tugrugs (approximately 2,250 USD). Her daughter supports her mother in her free time.

Dulamjav started her business in 2006 with working capital of 500,000 tugrugs (approximately 350 USD). She purchases toys from Korea, and her revenue is quite good because she only sells high quality products. She has great business experience gained in previous years.

Dulamjav is a decent and very hardworking person. She says, “I would like to expand my counter and I am working hard to establish my own toy shop.” She is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to increase her working capital and to increase the inventory of her business.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Chetchie

texts.en: To make a living, Chetchie Q. owns and operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in her community. She is 26 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. Chetchie has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 7,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Chetchie joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to invest in expanding her business. Chetchie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will again be used to invest in expanding her business. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sophion

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophion K. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. She is the mother of two children, one of whom is attending school while the younger one is too young for school because this child is only 2 years old. Her husband, Mr. Chum Pros, is a motorbike taxi driver who earns a small income to support the family. They live in Ping Pong village in Takeo province. 

With the farm, Mrs. Sophion K. faces a problem because her field is far from an irrigation system, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy a water machine to pump water for her crop. She will use the rest of the money to dig a well for her family to use. 

Her husband is present on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a water machine to pump water for her crop

loans.name: Galina

texts.en: Galina is married and has two grown-up children. She sells clothing - mainly women's hats and scarves - at Krytiy market in Zaporozhye city. There is very little competition for the type of clothing she sells. Galina attracts her clients with the variety and good quality of her inventory. Galina would like to receive a loan of 12,100 hyrvnia to purchase spring inventory. She loves her business and gets help from her son, who makes trips to the Kharkov bulk market to purchase goods.

loans.use: To purchase spring inventory

loans.name: Kamal

texts.en:
El Nabi Elyas is a village in Jenin District where Kamal and his family live and his vegetables store is located. Kamal is a 47-year-old man who is married and has one daughter. His small store is located on the main street of El Nabi Elyas village where almost everyone coming to the area must pass by.

Kamal has requested a loan from FATEN to fill his store with a larger variety of vegetables and fruits as well as enlarging his space to be able to serve a larger number of customers. This will reflect on his financial situation and help him make more money.

Kamal tells us that his store faces one problem: being banned from selling his vegetables to those who are from Israel while Jenin is an area open to visitors from Israel.

loans.use: To purchase a larger variety of fruit and vegetables

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is 50 years old and married with five children aged between 15 and 25 years. All her children go to school. The family owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Margaret owns a stall where she sells charcoal in Makerere Kikoni and she is a policewoman attached to Kawempe police station. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 20 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying sacks of charcoal from suppliers in Kawempe. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy and open place.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over 10 years, taking her 20th loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and to start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mohamed Traoré est un homme marié de 30 ans et père de 1 enfant qui  vit avec sa femme et son enfant  chez son père  à Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord.
Après l’école coranique, il décida de partir à l’aventure, précisément en Côte d’Ivoire à la recherche d’une vie meilleure. Ses ambitions n’ont pas été réalisés, il décida de retourner à Bougouni auprès de son père pour apprendre le commerce, notamment l’achat et la vente d’articles divers tels les articles de fête, les cosmétiques, les mèches pour cheveux etc. Avec une expérience de 11 ans, Monsieur Mohamed Traoré maîtrise son activité et est très sollicité et apprécié.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il décide rejoindre Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son deuxième prêt individuel après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
Il compte acheter des articles de fêtes, des tissus pour pantalons et chemises,  des produits de beauté et des parfums.
Il s’approvisionne à Bamako,(capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes  Ses clients sont composés d’hommes et femmes. 
Les fêtes religieuses et les grandes cérémonies (baptême, mariages) sont les périodes où les ventes de ses articles sont intenses.
Avec ce prêt, il compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 70 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour subvenir aux besoins de famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
 Il ambitionne dans les années à venir agrandir sa boutique.
texts.en:
Mr. Mohamed Traoré is 30-year-old married man, father of one child. He lives with his wife and child at his father’s home in Bougouni (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali.) in the neighborhood of North Hérémakono. After attending Koranic School, he decided to venture in search of a better life, more precisely in Ivory Coast. His aspirations were not realized. He decided to return to his father in Bougouni to learn to trade, specifically the sale of various articles such as party items, cosmetics, hair extensions etc… Mr. Mohamed Traoré has 11 years of experience and he masters his trade, he is very much in demand and appreciated. In his search for additional financial resources, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. This is his second individual loan; the first one has been fully reimbursed. He is planning on buying party items, cloth for pants and shirts, cosmetic products and perfumes. He gets his supplies from wholesalers in Bamako (Capital of the Republic of Mali). His customers are men and women. The religious holidays and big occasions (baptism, weddings) are times when the sale of his articles is intense. With this loan he is planning on making a monthly profit of 70, 000 Franc CFA. It will be used to provide for the family’s needs and reinvested the rest in the business. In the coming years, he would like to expand his shop.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase processed products from neighboring villages to resell them in large towns.

loans.name: Dulmaa

texts.en: Dulmaa is 35 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Dulmaa sells wooden products made by her husband at the “Itgelt” market. They have been living in their current home for six years. Her husband started his carpentry business with a man named Namsrai in 1998, but they have worked separately since 2002. Since that time, his business has expanded and he has purchased electrical appliances and equipment for the business, which he runs from his own home. Dulmaa is an honest and decent person. She says, “I would like to create my own workplace for the business.” She is requesting a 1,500,000-tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of wooden planks for the business.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of wooden planks

loans.name: Lizel

texts.en:
Lizel L. is from the village of Pangantucan, Bukidnon. She is 22 years old. Lizel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lizel owns & operates a specialized retail store selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Lizel has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Lizel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lizel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lizel from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support needs of relatives and other family members. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sron

texts.en: Mr. Sron L. lives in Doung Khpos village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of loan to grow rice to earn a living. He is also a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Bun Vany, is a farmer. Although they try to work very hard, they still don't earn enough income to support the family. Thus, Mr. Sron L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a plowing machine to plow the villagers’ rice fields for income. Mr. Sron L. is a father of a child who too young to work or study. His wife is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a plowing machine

loans.name: Firuza

texts.ru: Юсупова Фируза проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 37 лет. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Фируза более 7 лет занимается растениеводством. Она в основном сажает картошку. В этом ей помогает муж. Кредит просит для закупа минеральных удобрений. Фируза хочет расширить свой бизнес. Она намерена получить хороший урожай и продать на рынке.
texts.en:
Firuza Y. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 37 years old, married and has 3 children. Firuza has been involved in agriculture for over 7 years. She mainly grows potatoes. Her husband helps her with this business. She is requesting this loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers. Firuza wants to expand her business. She intends to get a good harvest and sell it at the market.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Oluwatoyin

texts.en: Oluwatoyin sells motor spare parts and engine oil. With this combined business, she hopes to make her business sustainable. She is happy about her business because she is the only female in this business in her community. She hopes for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. She is itching for progress in her business. She is 38 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a painter and he supports their home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Afouchata

texts.fr:
Née le 31 Août 1987  à Sikasso, Afouchata B.est une femme mariée et mère de 2 enfants qui  réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Bougoula Ville, Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après mener beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Afouchata s’est initiée  aux activités d’achat et de vente de pagnes et d’encens  il y a environ 7 ans. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans. Après un prêt solidaire (prêt du groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son premier prêt individuel. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 2 balles de pagnes et des sacs d'encens.                                                                                                Elle s’approvisionne à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) ensuite elle les revend de façon ambulante, en détail au comptant et à crédit, dans les différents quartiers de la ville de Sikasso, à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Afouchata B.was born on August 31, 1987 in Sikasso. She is married and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional extended family in Bougoula Town, Sikasso (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) After having unsuccessfully tried a lot of activities, seven years ago Afouchata trained herself in the business of trading incense and pagnes [bright colorful West African cloth]. With the objective to better meet the needs of her ever increasing customers, two years ago she joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. After a group loan in a women’s association of her neighborhood, this is her first individual loan. With this loan she is planning to buy to two bales of pagnes and bags of incense. She gets her supplies in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). She then retails them as an itinerant vendor, for cash or credit in the different neighborhoods of Sikasso town to customers who are mostly women. With this loan, she is planning to make a monthly profit of 75, 000 Francs CFA that will be used mostly to increase her working capital, contribute to the family’s expenses, pay her loan and invest the rest in her activity.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of various items

loans.name: Fidelis

texts.en: Fidelis is an ambitious 28-year-old man who operates a boutique that sells ladies’ shoes.  He has been in the business for six years. His wife is employed as a saleslady.  He is a member of Faulu Kenya and since he learned customer care skills, his client base has increased and his business has expanded.  He dreams of owning a wholesale shop in the future and import shoes.  He has requested Kes. 80,000 to add to his stock of ladies’ shoes.

loans.use: To buy more shoes

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph M. is a 33-year-old married father of one son, Alvin. Joseph is a mechanic who repairs motor vehicles. He has been in this business for two years now.

Joseph joined KADET recently and is now accessing his first loan. With the money, Joseph plans to buy motor vehicle spare parts in order to meet the needs of the market around him and to keep his business ready for any mechanical problems that need his attention. He was introduced to KADET by a neighbor.
 
He dreams and hopes to one day own a big garage with several employees.

loans.use: To purchase vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Drissa

texts.fr:
Agé de 36 ans, Monsieur  Drissa Traoré est marié et réside  avec sa femme dans une  grande famille traditionnelle élargie  Wayerma II, un des populaires de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école, Drissa s’intéressa très vite aux activités génératrices de revenus, notamment à l’achat vente des vêtements de “friperie” depuis près de 20 ans. Il appris cette activité, auprès de son père qui était un grand  vendeur de la place. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant deux ans et avec laquelle il est à son troisième prêt individuel.  Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
 Il compte acheter avec ce troisième prêt de la friperie : 1balle de Maillot de bain, 1 balle de culottes, 1 balle de chemises, 1 balle de soutiens gorge  et 1 balle de chaussettes. 
Les balles de friperies sont achetées sur places auprès des grossistes de la place  et revendues en détail et surtout au comptant  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 150 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Drissa Traoré is 36-year-old married and lives with his wife in large traditional extended family in Wayerma II, one of the popular neighborhoods of Sikasso (Third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having not had the opportunity to attend school, Drissa developed an early interest for income-generating activities, particularly the retail of second-hand clothes that he has done for nearly 20 years. He learned this business from his father who was a known seller there. He is very much in demand by his customers because of the quality of his articles. In order to meet the ever-increasing demand of his customers, two years ago he decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. This is his third individual loan with them. All his previous loans have been fully reimbursed. With this third loan he is planning to buy second hand clothes: 1 bale of bathing suits, 1 bale of underpants, 1 bale of shirts, 1 bale of bras, 1 bale of socks. The bales of clothes are bought on the spot from wholesalers and sold retail mostly for cash to customers who are women and men. With this loan he is planning to make a monthly profit of 150, 000 Francs CFA which will be used mostly to increase his working capital, contribute to the family’s expenses and invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pour acheter de la  friperie.

loans.name: Kiilu

texts.en: Kiilu is a 45-year-old diligent and visionary man who operates a barber shop.  He has six employees and has been in the business for 18 years.  He also earns extra income from farming.  He hopes to create more employment opportunities to meet the high customer demand, thus increasing his income.  He requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 to buy more chairs, shampoos and machines for his barber shop.  He sees himself opening other barber shops in the future.

loans.use: To buy more chairs, machines & shampoos

loans.name: Marguérite Agnès

texts.fr: T. Marguérite Agnès est née le 28 Avril 1959 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Mariée à MEVI Noël un comptable, Marguérite Agnès est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Marguérite Agnès a deux autres enfants à charge, en plus de ses enfants. Marguérite Agnès vit avec ses enfants au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l'Atlantique. C'est depuis 8 ans que Marguérite Agnès s'est installée dans ce quartier. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Marguérite Agnès a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire. Il y a environs 5 ans que Marguérite Agnès vend des tissus à son domicile et aussi par le système de distribution. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin et au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Marguérite Agnès s'approvisionne. Marguérite Agnès a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. La clientèle de Marguérite Agnès s'accroît au jour le jour et elle n'arrive plus à tous les satisfaire compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose. En vue d'augmenter le stock de ses produits, pour de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire, Marguérite Agnès sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Marguérite Agnès T. was born on April 28, 1959 in Ouidah, historic town of Benin. She is married to Noël Mevi, an accountant; Marguérite Agnès is the mother of four children, all in school. In addition to her own children, she is financially responsible for two other children. She lives with her children in the neighborhood of Dogoudo in Allada, in the department of the Atlantic. Marguérite Agnès settled in this neighborhood eight years ago. Together the couple provides for the family. Marguérite Agnès stopped attending school at the secondary level. She has been selling fabric from her home and through the distribution system for about five years. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and in Nigeria, a neighboring state of Benin. Marguerite Agnès has already obtained two loans from ALIDé that she has fully reimbursed. Her clientele is increasing from day to day and she can no longer meet their needs given the few financial means that she has. Marguérite Agnès is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. in order to increase her stock, to better meet her customers’ demand and to increase her turnover.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of 25 bolts of cloth

loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Badenya sont des femmes, mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en  moyenne 40 ans et 5 enfants. Elles  habitent toutes  à Togo, un des villages de la préfecture de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce  tout en diversifiant leurs activités génératrices de revenus, elles ont décidé de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après 5 prêts solidaires tous correctement remboursés, elles sont à leur 6ème  prêt, qu’elles comptent utiliser pour acheter, 200 mortiers, 10 chargements de charrettes en bois de chauffe et 289 sacs de charbon de bois. Elles s’approvisionnent en charbon de bois et bois de chauffe auprès des jeunes du village, en mortiers avec les forgerons du village et de ceux de Noumou Wêrê un village situé à 7 km. Elles revendent au comptant et à crédit à domicile, en ambulant et au grand marché de Ségou à une clientèle mixte. 
Elles envisagent  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 25.650FCA qui sera utilisé dans le remboursement du prêt et les petits besoins de la famille. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter des bœufs de labour afin d’augmenter leurs parcelles de culture.
texts.en:
The members of the Badenya group are women, married for the most part in polygamous families, and on average 40 years old with five children. They all live in Togo, one of the villages in the Segou prefecture (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got to know each other as neighbors or through family ties, and are retailers of various products. To increase their working capital and diversify their revenue-generating activities, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso. After five group loans all correctly reimbursed, they are now requesting a sixth loan, which they will use to buy: 200 mortars, 10 cartloads of firewood, and 289 bags of charcoal. They get the charcoal and firewood from village youths, and the mortars from blacksmiths in the village or from Noumou Wéré, a village seven kilometers distant. They retail their products for cash or on credit, from their home, as itinerant vendors or at Segou’s main market, to both men and women customers. They hope to attain average monthly earnings of 25,650 FCFA each, which will be used to reimburse the loan, and for minor household expenditures. Their ambition is to buy oxen to enlarge their cultivated land-plots

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Léa

texts.fr: O. Léa est née le 23 Mars 1966 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin.  Léa habite le quartier Gbowèlè à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, depuis 6 ans. Mariée à SOGLI Epiphane, un commerçant, Léa est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Léa a un autre enfant à sa charge. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges familiales. Léa a arrêté les classes au cours secondaire. Il y a environs 7 ans que Léa a commencé la vente de boissons de SOBEBRA (Société Béninoise de Brasserie). Parallèlement à cette activité, Léa vend également des yaourts et des tissus à Allada. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et à Allada, que Léa achète ses produits.  Léa avait bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés à ALIDé. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire, Léa sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Léa O. was born March 23, 1966, at Ouidah, a historic town in Bénin. Léa For six years she has lived in the Gbowèlè neighborhood in Allada, inthe Atlantic Department, with her husbaand Epiphane Sogli, a businesssman. She has one child of her own who is in school, and she cares for another child. Together, she and her husband take care of household expenses. , Lea dropped out of secondary school. About seven years ago she began selling drinks manufactured by a local brewery, and she also sells yogurt and yard goods. She buys these products in Cotonou, the economic capital of Bénin. She has had two loans from ALIDé that have been repaid. She seeks a third loan, with the goal of increasing her turnover.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 20 cases of soft drinks and six rolls of material.

loans.name: Eugénie Rufine Aimée

texts.fr: G. Eugénie Rufine Aimée est née le 10 Août 1956 au Congo, pays voisin du Bénin. Il y a 8 ans environs que Rufine Aimée s’est installée à Sékou à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, où elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Rufine Aimée est en effet mariée à NASSARA Florentin, un comptable retraité, et est mère de deux enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Rufine Aimée a trois autres enfants à sa charge. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Rufine Aimée a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Rufine Aimée vend des boucles d’oreille à Sékou. Parallèlement à cette activité, Rufine Aimée vend également des foulards, ce qui lui permet d’avoir plusieurs sources de revenus. Rufine Aimée s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Rufine Aimée souhaite augmenter le stock de ses produits pour mieux faire face à la demande des clients. C’est pourquoi Rufine Aimée sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Eugénie Rufine Aimée G. was born August 10, 1956 in Congo, a country adjacent to Benin. About eight years ago she settled in Sékou in the Allada area, part of the Department of the Atlantic, where she lives with her husband and children. Rufine Aimée is indeed married to Florentin NASSARA, a retired accountant, and is the mother of two children, both of whom have had schooling. Rufine Aimee has herself attended school up to secondary level. She has three other children under her care, and the couple share responsibility for household expenses. To meet her needs, Rufine Aimée sells earrings in Sekou. As a side business, she also sells scarves, which provides her with several sources of income. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Faced with an ever-increasing customer demand, Rufine Aimée wants to increase her stock of supplies and improve her response to customers. This is why she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 10 jewelry assortments and 20 scarves

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a 34-year-old lady who runs a salon and a kinyozi (barber shop). She employs two people and serves residents of Mwala in Machakos.  She has been in the business for over five years and also earns a living from her transport business.  She is the mother of two children and married to a teacher.  Mary has requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 to buy materials for her salon.  Her dream is to buy a piece of land in the future.  She sees herself owning a high class salon in 10 years.

loans.use: To buy salon materials

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouman est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 50 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Togo dans la préfecture de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leurs à leur  6ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé les cinq précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 150 mortiers, 200 sacs de charbon de bois, 5 sacs de riz, 10 sacs de mil et 15 sacs de farine de blé. 
Elles s’approvisionnent dans le grand marché de Ségou, à Noumou Wêrê et dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont revendus à domicile, dans la foire de Ségou et en ambulant, en espèce ou à crédit à une clientèle  composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt de Soro Yiriwaso et subvenir aux besoins de la famille. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter des bœufs de labour qui leurs permettront de cultiver une grande surface d’arachide et d’haricot.
texts.en:
The Dembagnouman group comprises six married women, mostly from polygamous families. On average, they are 50 years old and have six children. They live in the village of Togo in Ségou prefecture in Mali's 4th administrative region. They have ties to their neighbors and with their birth families and their families by marriage, and are in the business of selling various products. To increase working capital, they have had five loans from Soro Yiriwaso (all properly repaid) and have applied for a sixth. They want to buy 150 mortars, 200 bags of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 10 sacks of millet and 15 sacks of wheat flour in the big market in Ségou, at Noumou Wêrê, and in neighboring villages. The goods would be sold from their homes, at the fair in Ségou, and by going door to door, for cash or credit, to both men and women. They hope for income of 28,000 CFA a month, with which they will pay back Soro Yiriwaso and take care of family expenses. Their ambition is to buy oxen so that they work a large field, growing peanuts and beans.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items for retail sale.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old and married with five children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Sarah owns a mini-bakery selling chapatti, samosas and pancakes in Mengo Kitawuluzi. She works seven days a week. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. She incurs transport costs to and from buying cooking oil, baking flour and cowpeas at Owino market. Her main challenges are seasonality and the rainy season because she works from a muddy and open place.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over seven years servicing her 13th loan working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more jerry cans of cooking oil, cartons of baking flour and sacks of cowpeas. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy more flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Akouavi

texts.fr: D. Akouavi est née le 01 Juillet 1959 à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. C’est depuis 51 ans environs que Akouavi vit au quartier Gbowèlè à Allada. Akouavi est mariée à FANDY Thomas, un maçon, et est mère de quatre enfants. Akouavi a un autre enfant à sa charge. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure  les différentes charges familiales. Akouavi n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses différents besoins, Akouavi vend depuis 35 ans, divers produits (pâtes alimentaires, conserves de tomates et de sardines, des condiments, de l’huile d’arachide et de l’huile de palme, etc.). Parallèlement à cette activité, Akouavi vend également des produits vivriers (riz, haricot,  etc.). Akouavi s’approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. C’est dans les marchés de Houègbo, Sékou et Allada, que Akouavi vend ses différents produits. Akouavi est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant obtenu antérieurement, trois crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés.  Akouavi voudrait renforcer davantage son activité pour mieux répondre à sa clientèle et augmenter son chiffre d’affaire. C’est pour cette raison que Akouavi sollicite un quatrième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Akouavi was born on July 1, 1959 in Allada, in Atlantique County.  For about 51 years, she has been living in the Gbowèlè district in Allada.  She is married to FANDY Thomas, a mason, and is the mother of four children. And she has another child to support.  Only some of the children have had schooling.  The family lives together, and the couple are meeting the various family expenses.   Akouavi did not attend school.  To meet her different needs, she has been selling a variety of goods (pasta, canned tomatoes and sardines, condiments, peanut oil, and palm oil, etc.) for 35 years.  Along with his business, she also sells staple foods (rice, beans, etc.).  She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She sells her various goods at the markets of Houègbo, Sékou, and Allada. Akouavi is a past client of ALIDé having previously obtained three loans, which have all been repaid.  She would like to bolster her business further in order to respond better to her customers and to increase her sales.  For these reasons, Akouavi is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 3 sacks of rice and 100 liters of peanut oil

loans.name: Adam

texts.fr:
Madame Adam B.  est âgée de 54 ans, mariée  et mère  de 6 enfants. Elle  vit chez son mari  dans une famille nucléaire   au 3ème quartier de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Adam n’a pas fréquenté  l’école moderne pour des raisons sociales. Elle fréquenta plutôt l’école coranique qu’elle abandonna juste après avoir maîtrisé quelques sourates pour la prière. 
En vue de s’insérer dans la vie économique, Adam commença  à  mener plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus  auprès de sa grande sœur qui était une grande commerçante de Ségou. Riche de ces années expériences, elle finit par évoluer seule pour continuer la même activité que sa sœur et cela depuis 20 ans. Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété, sa force de vente est due à la qualité des marchandises et à son prix abordable.
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 42 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels  tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 20 complets tissus (costumes+pantalons) pour homme au Burkina Faso. Madame Adam B. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de faire de l’embouche bovine et ovine. 
Son ambition est d’acheter un terrain nu à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Adam B. is 45 years old, married, and the mother of six children. She lives with her husband in a nuclear family in the 3rd district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She did not attend a modern school due to societal reasons. She instead attended a Koranic school, but she dropped out after having mastered a few suras for praying. With the aim of participating in the economy, Adam started with several revenue-generating businesses along side her older sister, who used to be a major shopkeeper of Ségou. Rich with these years of experience, she eventually advanced on her own, continuing in the same business as her sister for the past twenty years. She enjoys a large customer base and recognition. Her sales capacity is due to the quality of her merchandise and her affordable prices. With plans to increase her business capital, in order to make more profit, she turned toward the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has had an association with it for 42 months. After three solidarity loans and two individual loans, all repaid, she is now on her third individual loan. She intends to use this new loan to buy 20 men's outfits (suits with pants) in Burkina Faso. She accepts cash or credit from customers composed of women and men. With this loan, she envisions making a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA. This profit will enable her to fatten cattle and sheep. Her ambition is to buy a bare plot of residential land.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr: C. Germaine est née le 19 Juin 1965 au quartier Dogoudo à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, où elle vit depuis sa naissance. Mariée à OLORITOGBE Dieu-Donné, Germaine est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Germaine vit seule avec un enfant à sa charge. Germaine a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au secondaire. Mais depuis une dizaine d’année, pour assurer ses besoins, Germaine vend des glacières, des bassines, des seaux à son domicile mais aussi par le système de distribution. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Germaine se ravitaille. Germaine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Germaine sollicite un autre crédit, en vue de rehausser son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
C. Germaine was born on June 19, 1965 in the Dogoudo district in Allada, in Atlantique County, where she has lived since birth. Married to OLORITOGBE Dieu-Donné, she is the mother of three children, who have all had schooling. She lives alone with one child in her care. Germaine has had secondary schooling. For about ten years, to meet her needs, she has been selling insulated containers, tubs, and buckets out of her home and by the distribution system, too. She resupplies herself in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has already benefited from two ALIDé loans, which she repaid. She's requesting another loan for boosting her business and satisfying her customers further.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying 2 dozen coolers, and 2 dozen tubs

loans.name: Assitan

texts.fr:
Madame  Assitan G. est âgée de 31 ans, mariée  et mère  de 2 enfants. Elle  vit chez son mari  au camp militaire de  Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté  l’école pour des raisons sociales (adoptée par ses grands parents qui voyaient en l’école une porte de déperdition des jeunes filles), elle ne s’intéressa alors qu’au commerce qu’elle appris sur le tas, toute seule. Aujourd’hui, elle jouit d’une grande expérience dans le domaine.  
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est en relation depuis 48 mois. Après 8 prêts solidaires  tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 1er  prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 6 tonnes de mils. Elle s’approvisionne auprès des producteurs et  sur place. Madame  Assitan G.  vend toujours  au comptant à des revendeurs de la place et venant d’autres grandes villes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100. 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de satisfaire ses propres besoins et de participer à des événements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes etc.). 
Son ambition est d’acheter un terrain  à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assitan G. is 31 years old, married and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband in the military camp in Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Never having been to school for social reasons (she was adopted by her grandparents who viewed school as a road to perdition for girls), she then only occupied herself with business, which she learned on the job, on her own. Today, she has a great deal of experience in this area. With the idea to increase her working capital, in order to make more profits, she approached Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has worked for 48 months. After eight group loans, all fully repaid, she is on her first individual loan. She plans to use the loan to buy six tons of millet. She gets her stock from farmers and locally. Mrs. Assitan G. always sells for cash to local resellers and those from other large cities. With this loan, she plans to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA. These profits will allow her to satisfy her own needs and participate in social events (weddings, baptisms, etc.). Her goal is to buy a plot of land to live on.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of grain

loans.name: Francis

texts.en: Francis is a 31-year-old married man with three children. Two of his children attend school.  He has been running a grocery shop for seven years in the Kibera slums.  He employs one person.  He earns extra income from building contracts.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has learned how to save his money and he now plans to take his first loan through Faulu Kenya to buy crates of onions and tomatoes.  Therefore, he requested a loan of Kes. 60,000. He hopes to expand his business and acquire a vehicle for transporting fresh produce to the market.

loans.use: Buy crates of onions & tomatoes for sale

loans.name: Aïssata Tita

texts.fr:
Madame Aïssata Tita Dembélé est âgée de 47 ans, mariée, elle vit dans une famille nucléaire avec son mari et  leurs 6  enfants  à Banankoro, un village situé à 10km de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas  fréquenté l’école  pour  des raisons, elle commença très tôt à mener des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa maman qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après  plusieurs années d’apprentissage et riche de cette expérience, elle opta pour la préparation et la vente des jus de boissons non alcoolisées, et la préparation de l’encens depuis maintenant 18 ans. Elle  jouit d’une grande clientèle dans le village et environs.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle a fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 42 mois. Après 5 prêts solidaires et 1er prêt individuel  tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème   prêt individuel.
Elle compte l’utiliser pour acheter, 6 sacs de guéni, 3 kg de magnonkiséni, 2 kg de sarakatané (écorce d’un arbre venant de l’Arabie) et des flacons de parfums. 
Elle s’approvisionne en matières premières au grand marché de Ségou et vend très généralement au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice de 35 000FCFA, qui  servira à payer les charges scolaires de ses enfants qui sont au lycée de Ségou (frais de carburants). 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssata Tita Dembélé is 47 and married. She lives as a family with her husband and their six children in Banankoro, a village located 10 kilometers from the city of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Never having been to school, she began money-making activities very young with her mother, who sold condiments. After several years' apprenticeship and having learned much, she chose to make and sell juice and non-alcoholic drinks, and also incense, which she has been doing for eighteen years. She has a large clientele in and around the village. In order to satisfy her customers, she approached Soro Yiriwaso, with whom she has been involved for 42 months. After five group loans and one individual loan, all fully repaid, she is on her second individual loan. She plans to use the loan to buy six bags of guéni (root used for making incense), three kilos of magnonkiséni (a plant), two kilos of sarakatané (bark from an Arabian tree) and perfume bottles. She gets her ingredients from the large market in Ségou and generally sells for cash to her customers, who are chiefly women. She plans to make a profit of 35,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay gas expenses for her children's school, the lycée (high school) in Ségou. Her goal is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients for incense

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of forest products and preparation of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Reine

texts.fr: F. Reine est née le 16 Septembre 1967 au quartier Gbowèlè à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, où elle vit depuis sa naissance. Mariée à HOUNGNIBO Anatole, un imprimeur, Reine est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Reine a un autre enfant à sa charge. Reine vit seule avec ses enfants à Gbowèlè. Mais le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Reine a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis 20 ans environs, Reine vend des chaussures et divers autres produits (savons, bougies, conserves de tomates et de sardine, sachets, lait, pâtes alimentaires, couscous, etc.) à Allada. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Reine s’approvisionne. Reine a bénéficié déjà de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a tous bien remboursés. Reine voudrait augmenter le stock de ses produits et accroître sa clientèle, ce qui lui permettra de se faire plus de revenu. C’est pourquoi Reine sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé. Reine ambitionne plus tard acquérir une parcelle.
texts.en:
Reine F. was born September 16, 1967 in the Gbowélé area of Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic, where she has lived ever since. Married to Anatole HOUNGNIBO, a printer, Reine is the mother of five children, all having had schooling. She has another child under her care. Reine lives alone with her children in Gbowélé, but she shares family expenses with her husband. Reine interrupted school at the secondary level. For the past twenty years, Reine has sold shoes and other products (soap, candles, canned tomatoes and sardines, water pouches, milk, pasta, couscous, etc.) in Allada. She resupplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Reine has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, which she duly reimbursed. She would like to increase her stock supply and her number of customers, to generate more revenue. For this reason she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé. Her ambition is to eventually buy a plot of land.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 20 dozen pairs of shoes and various food products 'canned tomatoes and sardines, milk, pasta)

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy is 45 years of age and married with seven children aged between 10 and 20 years. All her children go to school. The family resides and owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Cissy owns a retail shop in Makerere Kikoni selling all types of merchandise like soap, sugar, salt, paraffin, matchboxes and all other home products.   Cissy buys her merchandise from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala city and incurs transport costs to and from shopping.  She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season because she works from a muddy and open place, and the increasing prices of merchandise.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over 12 years servicing her 25th loan working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more merchandise like salt, bags of sugar, cartons of baking flour, and boxes of soap. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy more products to sell

loans.name: Mainouna

texts.fr:
Madame  Mainouna T.  est âgée de 41 ans, mariée  et mère  de 2 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari  dans une famille nucléaire au quartier Somono de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Mainouna a abandonné l’école en classe de 3 ème  année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien)  pour faire le petit commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des friandises. Après plusieurs d’apprentissage auprès de cette dernière pour mieux maîtriser les rouages du commerce,  elle finit par évoluer seule en faisant  le commerce de mil et de riz,  depuis maintenant 7 ans. 
Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle et tient son commerce au marché Somono de la ville de Ségou.  
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48 mois. Après 4 prêts solidaires et 2 prêts individuels correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel  qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 800 kg de riz. Elle s’approvisionne dans la zone office du Niger précisément à Dougabougou et Séribala.
Madame   Mainouna T.  vend  généralement au comptant à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet d’aider son mari et de participer aux événements sociaux (baptême, mariage etc.…). 
Son ambition est d’avoir un terrain  à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Mainouna T. is 41 years old, married and has two children. She lives with her husband in a nuclear family in the Somono district of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mainouna left school in the third grade of elementary school (according to the Mali education system) in order to set up a small business at her mother's to sell sweetmeats. After several years' apprenticeship with her mother in order to master the mechanics of business, she ended up developing her own business selling millet and rice, which she has been carrying out now for seven years. She benefits from a large customer base and carries out her business on the market of Somono in the town of Ségou. With the aim of increasing her working capital in order to make more profit, she resorted to Soro Yiriwaso. She has been in relations with this company for the past 48 months. After four group loans and two individual loans which have all been paid without incident, she is now on her third individual loan which she plans to use to buy 800kg of rice. She gets her supplies in the Office zone of Nigeria, more precisely in Dougabougou and Séribala. Mrs. Mainouna T. generally sells for cash to a customer base made up of both women and men. With this loan she expects to make a monthly profit of 75,000 FCFA. This profit will allow her to help her husband and to contribute to social events (baptisms, marriages etc.). Her ambition is to have a piece of land to live on.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cereals

loans.name: Julius

texts.en: Julius is a 53-year-old married man with nine children. Three of the children attend school.  He was formerly employed by the government of Kenya before he ventured into running a retail shop for a decade.  He is also a farmer. He is an active member of Faulu Kenya and has taken three loans of Kes. 60,000 in the past.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 60,000 to buy crates of soda, bales of maize and wheat flour, and bags of sugar.  He hopes to buy a tractor for farming and for hiring.  He sees himself expanding his business into wholesale.

loans.use: Add to his stock of soda, maize flour, wheat flour and sugar

loans.name: Ousmane

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Ousmane  Cissé  est marié et âgée de 24 ans. Il vit chez son père dans une grande  famille traditionnelle avec sa mère et ses 5 frères dans le quartier Sébougou de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ousmane a abandonné l’école en classe de 8ème  année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour faire le commerce auprès de son grand frère qui tenait une boutique de vente d’articles divers. Après  2 années passées avec ce dernier, il maîtrise bien les rouages du commerce. Depuis maintenant trois ans, il mène seul son activité d’achat et de vente d’articles divers de boutique au quartier Angoulême. Sa boutique située auprès du   boulevard CAN 2002 est le lieu des affaires  par excellence à Ségou. 
Pour augmenter son fonds de commerce il a  fait recours à     Soro Yiriwaso avec qui, il est en relation  depuis 24 mois. Après 2  prêts individuels tous bien remboursés, il est à son 3ème prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, ½ tonne de sucres et 1 barrique d’huile alimentaire. 
Il s’approvisionne  à Bamako et sur place auprès des grossistes.
Monsieur  Ousmane  Cissé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Il envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’aider son père dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est de diversifier ses activités en  ouvrir une station d’essence.
texts.en:
Mr. Ousmane Cissé is married and 24 years old. He lives in his father's house in a large traditional family with his mother and five brothers. This is in the Sébougou district of Ségou (the third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Ousmane left school in the eighth grade of elementary school (according to the Mali education system) to work with his older brother who had a shop selling various items. Having spent two years there, he had mastered the mechanics of business. For the past three years he has been carrying out his own business purchasing and selling a variety of items in a shop in the Angloulême neighborhood. His shop lies close to Boulevard CAN 2002, a strategic business area of Ségou. In order to increase his working capital, he turned to Soro Yiriwaso, and he has had relations with this company for the past 24 months. After two individual loans which were repaid without incident, he is on his third individual loan with which he plans to buy half a ton of sugar and a barrel of (edible) oil. He gets his supplies in Bamako and locally from wholesalers. Mr. Ousmane Cissé sells for cash and on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. He expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA. This profit will allow him to help his father cover the household expenses. His ambition is to diversify his activities and open a petrol station.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs

loans.name: Mariamou

texts.fr: K. Mariamou est née le 28 Août 1962 à Natitingou au Nord du Bénin. Mariée à BABOCCO Gousséyo, Mariamou est mère de sept enfants. Mariamou a un autre enfant à charge. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, depuis 15 ans environs. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Mariamou a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis un vingtaine d’année, Mariamou vend des bassines et des bols en séries au marché de Allada. De façon seondaire, Mariamou vend des chaussures et des sacs. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Mariamou s’approvisionne. Mariamou a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Face à la demande croissante de sa clientèle, Mariamou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Mariamou ambitionne plus tard acquérir une parcelle et construire une maison.
texts.en:
Mariamou K. was born on 28th August 1962 in Natitingou in the north of Bénin. Married to Gousséyo BABOCCO, Mariamou is mother to seven children. She also has another child in her care. Only some of the children are at school. The family has lived in Allada in the "département" (admnistrative division) of Atlantique for around 15 years. The couple cover the various household expenses between them. Mariamou left school at secondary level. For around 20 years she has sold basins and sets of bowls on the market in Allada. As a secondary activity, she sells shoes and bags. Mariamou gets her supplies in Dantokpa, Bénin's international market. She has already had two loans from ALIDé both of which she repaid without incident. In order to meet increasing customer demand, Mariamou is applying for a third loan from ALIDé. This will allow her to strengthen her business and satisfy customer demand more readily. Mariamou's longer term ambition is to acquire a piece of land and build a house.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of one carton of bowl sets and two dozen basins

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
El Sr. Oscar N., paraguayo soltero de profesión comerciante se dedica a la fabricación de muebles rústicos, el mismo cuenta su propia carpintería y se dedica a este rubro hace más de diez años, cuenta dos personales permanentes y otros que contrata por destajo.
 
        Actualmente esta inaugurando su salón de exposición sobre la Ruta III Elizardo Aquino, el mismo contará con un salón, vivienda y carpintería. El mismo cuenta con clientela formada y también realiza trabajos para mayoristas y estancieros, su trabajos son también muy apreciados por turistas y extranjeros.

            El Sr. N. solicitó nuestra asistencia terminación de la fachada de su nuevo local.
texts.en:
Oscar N. is a single Paraguayan whose profession is manufacturing rustic furniture. He has his own workshop and has worked in this area for more than ten years. He has two full-time employees and others who work for him contractually. He is currently opening a showroom on Route Elizardo Aquino III, which will have a lounge, living space, and workshop. Right now he has a loyal clientele and also does work for wholesalers and ranchers. His work is also popular with tourists and foreigners. Mr. N. has asked for assistance so that he may finish the front of his new showroom.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy construction materials to build a new showroom

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes, mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames avec en moyenne 39 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Chiola dans la préfecture de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage, de parenté et font le commerce de produits alimentaires.
Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de diversifier leurs marchandises à vendre, elles décidèrent d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 4ème  prêt solidaire après avoir remboursé sans aucune difficulté, les trois précédents.
Ce quatrième prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 20 sacs de sel iodé, 16 sacs d’arachide, 4 sacs de mil et  1/2 sac de riz. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  exclusivement dans les foires de Ségou et de Konodimini. Elles effectuent leur vente à domicile et dans les foires des villages environnants au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 18.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso et satisfaire les petits besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
The members of the Danaya group are women, the majority of whom are married and living in monogamous families. Their average age is 39 years old and they have an average of four children. They live in the village of Chiola in the "prefecture" of Ségou (the fourth administrative region of Mali). They got to know each other through their neighbors, their marriages and their relatives, and they sell foodstuffs. With the aim of increasing their working capital and diversifying the range of goods they sell, they decided to join Soro Yiriwaso's loan program and they are on their fourth group loan from this company, having repaid without any difficulty the three previous loans. This fourth loan will be used to buy 20 bags of iodized salt, 16 bags of peanuts, four bags of millet and half a bag of rice. They get their supplies exclusively from the fairs in Ségou and Konodimini. They make their sales at home and at the fairs in surrounding villages, for cash or on credit to a customer base made up of men and women. They expect to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the interest on their loan from Soro Yiriwaso and to meet minor family needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of foodstuffs

loans.name: Berth

texts.fr: F. Berth est née le 20 Décembre 1958 au quartier Allomey à Allada, dans le département de l’Atlantique, où elle réside depuis sa naissance. Mariée à DASSI Michel, un instituteur retraité, Berth est mère de six enfants, mais cinq restent encore à sa charge. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. Berth vit avec ses enfants à Allomey. Mais le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Berth a fréquenté jusqu’au secondaire. Il y a 18 ans environs que Berth mène comme activité, la vente des canaris, de l’oignon et des épices au marché de Allada. C’est à Bohicon et à Malanville que Berth se ravitaille. Berth a bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Berth sollicite un troisième crédit pour renforcer surtout son activité de vente d’oignons et d’ails, et mieux faire face à la demande des clients. Berth ambitionne plus tard construire sur sa parcelle.
texts.en:
Berth F. was born December 20, 1958 in the Allomey neighborhood of Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic, where she has lived since her birth. Married to Michel DASSI, a retired schoolteacher, Berth is the mother of six children, of whom five are still under her care. Only some of the children are in school. Berth herself has attended school up to secondary level. She lives with her children in Allomey, and shares family expenses with her husband. Some 18 years ago Berth began selling canaris (pottery containers), onions and spices at the Allada market. She gets her supplies from Bohicon and Malanville. Berth has been granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both of which were repaid in full. She is now requesting a third loan, to strengthen in particular her sales of onions and garlic, so she can better respond to customer demand. Berth’s ambition for the future is to build on her plot of land.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy canaris (pottery containers) and one bag of onions and garlic

loans.name: Rosine

texts.fr: D. Rosine est née le 12 Décembre 1960 et vit depuis 6 ans au quartier Allomey à Allada dans le département de l’Atlantique. Mariée à DJIDO Jocelyn, un chauffeur, Rosine est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Mais trois seulement des enfants vivent avec Rosine au quartier Allomey. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges familiales.  Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Rosine vend des cures dents, des chaussures et des bijoux au marché de Allada. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et aussi à Lomé au Togo que Rosine achète ses produits. Rosine exerce cette activité depuis quatre ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Rosine sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé, pour augmenter le stock de ses produits et se faire plus de revenu.
texts.en:
Rosine D. was born December 12, 1960, and has been living for the past six years in the Allomey area of Allada, in the Department of the Atlantic. Married to Jocelyn DJIDO, a driver, Rosine is the mother of five children, all having had schooling. Only three of the children live with her in the Allomey area, and the couple shares the various household expenses. To meet her needs and those of her children, Rosine sells dental care sticks, shoes and jewelry at the Allada market. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market, and also from Lomé in neighboring Togo. Rosine has been pursuing this activity for the past four years, and has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both of which were duly reimbursed. She is now requesting a third loan, to increase her stock of supplies and generate more income.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy jewelry and two bags of dental care sticks

loans.name: Hiram

texts.en: Hiram is a 29-year-old man who runs a studio and employs one person.  He has been in the business for four years.  Previously, he was operating a green grocery.  He earns extra income from farming horticultural crops and dairy farming. His wife is a teacher.  Hiram previously took a loan of Kes. 35,000 from Faulu Kenya and he claims that since then he has become financially stable.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 40,000 to purchase carpets, cables, speakers, films and digital cameras for his studio.  He hopes to open several other shops in Limuru town.  He sees himself owning a film-processing studio in Nairobi and importing cameras in the future.

loans.use: Buy carpets, cables, speakers, films and digital cameras

loans.name: Florence Zalwango‘S Group

texts.en:
Florence is 45 years old and married with seven children aged between 10 and 15 years. All her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-room house where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include paying utility bills, school fees for her children, medication and feeding the family. Florence owns a hardware shop in Nakulabye selling cement, nails, iron sheets and paint. Florence buys her paint from factories and cement from depots within Kampala city, and so incurs transport costs to and from shopping. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 12 years. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season because she works from a muddy open area, and the increasing prices of merchandise.  She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over six years, servicing her 25th loan, working all along with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of cement, tins of paint and iron sheets. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and start selling at wholesale only.
.

loans.use: To buy cement, nails, iron sheets and paint

loans.name: Bintou's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Sinignèssigui est composé de six  femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles monogames  avec en moyenne 40 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Chiola dans la préfecture de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de parenté et font le commerce d’articles divers.
 Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce et de diversifier leurs marchandises à vendre, elles ont  adhéré au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elles sont à leur 4ème prêt solidaire.  Tous les trois précédents ont été remboursés sans difficulté.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter,  60 sacs de charbon de bois, 10 pièces de pagnes wax et 2 sacs de riz.  Elles s’approvisionnent dans les foires de Ségou et de Konodimini en céréales et en pagnes wax, en charbon de bois dans les villages environnants. La revente des marchandises se fait à domicile, dans les foires de Konodimini et à Ségou au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt de Soro Yiriwaso et faire de l’épargne. 
Elles ont pour ambition de  diversifier les sources de revenus en embrassant  l’embouche des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The Sinignèssigui group is made up of six married women, for the most part from monogamous families, on average 40 years old with four children. They live in the village of Chiola in the Ségou prefecture (4th administrative region of Mali). They know each other through family links and as neighbors, and retail various products. To increase their inventory and diversify the products they sell, they have joined the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, where they are now requesting a fourth group loan. All three previous loans were reimbursed without problems. This new loan will be used to buy: 60 bags of charcoal, 10 pieces of pagne wax fabric, and two bags of rice. They get cereal and pagne wax from the Segou and Konodimini markets, and charcoal from villages in the area. They resell their products either from their home, or in the Ségou and Konodimini markets, for cash or on credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the Soro Yiriwaso loan and put into savings. Their ambition is to diversify their sources of revenue and invest in the fattening of small ruminants.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Zulaikho

texts.en:
B. Zulaikho is 43 years old. She is married with four children. About 14 years ago, the economic situation of the family forced Zulaikho to start her own business. She decided to sell fabric for national dresses in the market. Zulaikho tries to diversify her range of goods to meet the demands of the clients with various tastes and levels of income. As a rule, she purchases fabrics from the wholesale markets. Today Zulaikho requests $2,000 US to purchase fabrics for the national dresses. Having shown herself as a reliable client, Zulaikho promises to pay this loan on time.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy more fabric

loans.name: Bwagonga Eco Bakyara Group, Ibanda

texts.en: K. Gladys, in a small photo at the top left, also appears in the big photo and she is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 40 years old and married with nine children. She takes care of four dependants also in school. Gladys is so welcoming. She has been involved in the business of selling produce at Bwagonga Trading Centre for 15 years and the experience she has enables her to make 300,000/= profits every month. She hopes to develop her business further so that she can sell a variety of products ranging from bananas, Irish potatoes and cassava. She hopes as well as to educate her children since this keeps her going. She needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke and other produce for resale.

loans.use: To buy more matooke for resale.

loans.name: Abdrahamane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Abdrahamane B. est âgé de 26 ans, célibataire et sans enfant. Il vit chez sa mère dans une   famille nucléaire au 3ème quartier de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 8ème  année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), il opta pour le métier de tailleur. 
Après 3 années d’apprentissage auprès de son grand frère, il évolue en solo depuis maintenant 3 ans dans son atelier se trouvant au quartier Alamoussala. 
Il est très sollicité pour  son génie de création.
