Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices. Il  a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son 1er  prêt individuel qu’il compte utiliser pour acheter, une machine à coudre. 
Il  s’approvisionne sur place. Monsieur Abdrahamane B. fait ses prestations au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, il envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 65 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra d’entretenir sa maman et de bien mener son activité.  
Son ambition est d’ouvrir un second atelier.
texts.en:
Mr. Abdrahamane B. is 26 years old, unmarried without children. He lives with his mother in a nuclear family in the 3rd area of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Having left school in the 8th grade (Mali educational system), he chose to become a tailor. After three years as an apprentice to his older brother, he now works on his own, in a workshop located in the Alamoussala neighborhood. He is very much in demand due to his creative genius. To increase his working capital and generate more income, he is requesting a first individual loan from Soro Yiriwaso, with which he will buy a sewing machine. He gets his supplies from the area. Mr. Abdrahamane B. provides his services for cash or on credit, to a customer base of both men and women. With this loan, he hopes to attain monthly earnings of 65,000 FCFA. The profits will allow him to take care of his mother and run his business smoothly. His ambition is to open a second workshop.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret has been running a beauty salon and beauty products business for four years.  She sells hair beauty products in her salon. She says that Faulu Kenya has helped her learn how to manage her business and have good customer service from their trainings.  She previously took a loan of Kes. 20,000 from Faulu and now she plans to take a loan of Kes. 40,000 to buy four blow dryers, mirrors, chemicals and cosmetics.  She hopes to open other beauty shops to increase her sources of income and create employment.  She sees herself owning a beauty college in the future.

loans.use: To buy hair dryers, mirrors, chemicals & cosmetics

loans.name: Oumou Mamadou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Mamadou T. est âgée de 29 ans, mariée  et mère  de 3 enfants.  Elle  vit chez son mari  dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Pelengana village de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant fréquenté  l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à faire des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui faisait le commerce d’articles divers. Nantie des années expériences passées à côté de cette dernière, elle évolue seule depuis maintenant 10 ans. Oumou  opta pour le commerce de condiments alimentaires.  Elle jouit d’une grande clientèle due à la qualité des condiments qui sont de première qualité et bien conservés.   
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce, afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 48 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts individuels  tous correctement bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 4 sacs de poudre de feuilles de baobab. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants de Ségou tels que Konodimini, Gassela etc.
Madame Oumou Mamadou T. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permet de payer les cotisations de tontines et de rembourser les intérêts du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Oumou Mamadou T. is 29 years old, married, and the mother of three children.  She lives with her husband in a large traditional family in the Pelengana district, Ségou City (4th  administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having attended school for societal reasons, she very soon started to earn in income along with her mother, who used to do commerce in various goods.  Privileged with years of previous experience at her mother's side, Oumou has been advancing on her own for ten years now.  She opted for commerce in condiments.  She enjoys a large customer base due to the quality of her condiments, which are top grade and well-kept.  With plans to increase her business capital in order to make more profits, she turned toward micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  She has had an association with it for 48 months.  After three solidarity loans and three individual loans, all properly repaid, she is now on her fourth individual loan, which she intends to use for buying four sacks of powdered baobab leaves.  She gets her supplies from the villages surrounding Ségou, such as Konodimini, Gassela etc.  She accepts cash or credit from customers composed of women and men.  With this loan, Oumou envisions making a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA.  This profit will enables her to pay her tontine dues and to repay the Soro Yiriwaso loan.  Her ambition is to build a house in which to live.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying powdered baobab leave

loans.name: Tamarsu Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'Tamarsu' group from Magburaka town in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person for the purpose of strenthening their businesses, both in terms of size and quality. In this way, they can make more sales, better profit and consequently improve their living standard. 

Forty-year-old Mariatu T. is the leader of this group. She was born in Magburaka and is married to a businessman. They 4 children who are attending secondary school. For 15 years now, Mariatu has been selling toothpaste, toothbrushes, bars of soap, books, etc. With her share of the loan, she will expand her business by buying these items wholesale. 

(On the right in the photo is the Loan Officer, Abdul Karim Conteh, handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy toothpaste, toothbrushes, soaps, and books wholesale

loans.name: Melania

texts.es:
La Sra. Melania García tiene 55 años y es dueña de un comercio en Emboscada, la misma es oriunda de Asunción.
La Sra tiene 3 hijos en edad escolar, y anteriormente trabajaba en la Argentina y su marido tiene una moto que trabaja como taxi, hace como 6 años que regreso de la Argentina y su sueño es abrir un Autoservice ya que en la zona no hay, y así dejarles a sus hijos un buen negocio.
Solicitó nuestra asistencia para compra de Bebidas, y agradece a la Fundación por haberle dado la oportunidad de un crédito.
texts.en:
Melania García is 55-years-old and owns a shop in Emboscada, although she is a native of Asunción. She has three school-aged children and previously worked in Argentina. Her husband has a motorbike that he uses as a taxi. She returned from Argentina six years ago and she dreams of opening an AutoService, because there are none in the area. She hopes to be able to leave her children a successful business. She has requested assistance to buy drinks, and she is thankful to Fundación Paraguaya (Kiva Field Parnter) for giving her the opportunity of a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Sindewald, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, cigarettes, and drinks

loans.name: Ta Marr Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Ta Marr' group from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesswomen who have applied for a loan from SMT/Kiva lenders of SLL 500,000 for each person in order to expand their businesses in size and quality. 

Forty-five-year-old Kumba T. is the leader and head of this group of entrepreneur. Born in Magburaka town, she is married to a subsistence farmer and they have 6 children. Two of her children are already married and 4 are attending secondary school. For many years now, Kumba has been selling chains, earrings, and cosmetics. With her share of the loan, she will invest in jewelry and cosmetics. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer, Abdul Karim C., handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy jewelry and cosmetics for resale

loans.name: Tamuyu Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Tamuyu' group from the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They are petty businesspeople who have come together to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person in order to expand their businesses. 

The leader of the group is Fatmata K.. She is 30 years old, married to a businessman, and they have 3 children – 1 in primary school and 2 who are not of school-going age. For 5 years now, Fatmata has been a businesswoman; she sells clothes, shoes, and bras. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items wholesale and retail them in Magburaka town. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer, Abdul Karim C., handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy clothes, shoes and bras for resale

loans.name: Pampana Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Pampana' group. Members of the 'Pampana' group are small-scale businesspeople in Magburaka town who want a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person in order to promote their businesses, both in terms of size and quality. In this way, they can attract many customers into their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions.

Forty-five-year-old Pa Alpha T. is the leader of this group. Pa Alpha, who was born in Matotoka, is married and is the father of 5 children – 3 in secondary school and 2 in primary school. For many years now, Pa Alpha has been selling medicines. With his share of his loan, he will buy medicines wholesale to add to his current stock. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer, Abdul Karim Conteh, handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy essential drugs like penadol, chloroquine, etc. for resale

loans.name: Orfinor Daru Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are members of the 'Orfinor Daru' group. Their leader is Fatmata K.. They are petty businesswomen in the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. For the first time, they have applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person from SMT/Kiva lenders in order to improve their businesses, both in terms of quality and quantity. 

The 40-year-old Fatmata was born in a village called Mile 91 and she is married to a businessman. They have 5 children in primary and secondary school. For many years now, she has been selling peppers, salt, palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by adding more of the above mentioned goods to her business stock. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer, Abdul Karim Conteh, handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy peppers, salt, and palm oil for resale

loans.name: God Gee Group

texts.en:
These are members of the 'God Gee' group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs from the township of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. These entrepreneurs want a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person to further strengthen their businesses.

Aminata T. is the leader of this group of  entrepreneurs. Born in Bo city in southern Sierra Leone, the 45-year-old Aminata is married in Magburaka to a businessman and they have 9 children, 7 of whom are attending school – 3 in primary school and 4 in secondary school. Aminata has been a businesswoman for 5 years now. She sells Maggi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), flour, pepper, salt, oil, etc. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business in size and quality by buying the above-mentioned items wholesale and retail them in Magburaka. 

(On the right of the photo is the Loan Officer, Abdul Karim Conteh, handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy Maggi, flour, pepper, salt, oil, etc.

loans.name: Fast Movement Group

texts.en:
Hawanatu M. is the leader of this group of entrepreneurs from the township of Magburaka, northern Sierra Leone. Hawanatu has been selling firewood and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) for over 3 years now. 20-year-old Hawanatu was born in Magburaka; she is married to a driver and they have 2 children. With her share of this loan, she will expand her business by buying piles of firewood and gallons of palm oil.

(On the right in the photo is the Loan Officer, Abdul Karim C., handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy piles of firewood and gallons of palm oil for resale

loans.name: Tamaraneh Social Club Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are members of the 'Tamaraneh Social Club' group. They are small-scale petty businesspeople from the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. The leader of this group of entrepreneurs is Kassim M. J.. The 23-year-old is married to a businesswoman and they have 1 infant child. For a year now, Kassim has been selling palm oil (the most popular cooking oil), rice and “benne” (sesame seeds). With his share of this loan, he will buy palm oil, rice and 'benne'. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer Abdul Karim Conteh handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy palm oil, rice and 'benne'

loans.name: Nazar

texts.en:
D. Nazar is 50 years old. He was born in Dushanbe, Tajikistan. He is the father of six children and his main work consists of breeding cattle. This very remunerative activity enables him to provide for the needs of his family. A very ambitious man, Nazar would like to buy a greater number of cattle and to build a farmhouse to house them in order to ensure their safety. Due to a lack of finances, he is asking for a loan of 4,500 Somoni for the realization of this project. When his dream is carried out, Nazar will be able to have a greater source of revenue for his growing family. With your help, this will be possible.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase more cattle

loans.name: Bisheshe Kweterana Group, Ibanda

texts.en: A. Patience is a good person. She appears at the top left and in the group photo. She is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 47 years old and married with two children aged 8 and 3 years. She also takes care of three other children. Patience has had a retail shop in Bisheshe Trading Centre for five years now. She sells general merchandise that helps to bring in an income for business growth and enables her to save. She works so hard to ensure that her children attain the best education so that they become self-sustaining in the future. She needs a loan to be able to recapitalize her shop with more goods for increased sales.

loans.use: To purchase more goods for her store.

loans.name: Honest Traders Group

texts.en:
Zainab K. is the leader of this group of local entrepreneurs who named their group 'Honest Traders'. They have come to SMT/Kiva lenders for the first time to seek a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person for the purpose of expanding their businesses. Thirty-two-year-old Zainab has been selling soap and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) for 10 years now. 

Zainab was born in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone. She is married to an engineer and they have 7 children – 3 in secondary school, 3 in primary school and 1 still nursing. Zainab wants this loan in order to expand her business by buying soap-making materials like caustic soda and oil. She will also buy gallons of palm oil.  

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer Abdul Karim Conteh handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy soap-making materials like caustic soda, oil. She will also buy gallons of palm oil.

loans.name: Hotel Lane Traders Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Hotel-Lane Traders' from Magburaka town, northern Sierra Leone. They have formed themselves into a group to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person from SMT/Kiva lenders. They made Isatu K. the group’s leader. Isatu is 36 years of age, married to a businessman, and they have 3 children. Two are in secondary school and one is still not of school-going age. For 2 years now, Isatu has been selling clothes – shirts, skirts, bras, etc. With her share of the loan, she will invest in her business by buying shirts, skirts, and bras wholesale to add to her current stock. 

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer Abdul Karim Conteh handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy shirts, skirts, and bras wholesale to add to her current stock

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 52 years of age and married with six children between the ages of 10 and 28. Three of her children go to school. The family resides in and owns a two-roomed house, where she stays with eight people. She takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity but no piped water at home. The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses include utility bills, school fees for children, medication and feeding the family. 

Grace owns stall in Owino Market selling bananas. Grace buys her paint from factories and cement bananas from delivery vans which get them from villages and so she doesn’t incur any  transport costs to and from shopping as she buys from her place of work. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has done this business for over 20 years. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season (because she works from a muddy place),  and the ever increasing prices of bananas. She sells on a retail basis only. She has been with MCDT for over 10 years and is servicing her 26th loan, working all this time with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She aspires to see her business grow bigger and to start going to farmers directly.
.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Young Carpenters Group

texts.en:
Mansah Sayo T. is the leader of this group. The 45-year-old Mansah was born in a place called Samaya; he is married to a businesswoman and they have 4 children – 1 in secondary school and 3 in primary school. For 5 years now, Mansah has been a carpenter – he makes beds, chairs, benches, tables and several other sorts of furniture.  With his share of this loan, he will buy working materials – nails, timber, polish, etc. to make pieces of furniture to sell.

(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer Abdul Karim Conteh handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy working materials – nails, timber, polish, etc. to make pieces of furniture to sell

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy is 31 years old and married with three children. She has been running a shop for four years in the Kibera slums, where she sells a variety of goods. Through Faulu Kenya, she has learned business discipline and record-keeping skills. She plans to add more stock with the loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings that she is requesting. She hopes to open a shop for selling clothes in the future. Mercy is very committed.

loans.use: Add stock

loans.name: Vicenta Irene

texts.es:
La Sra. Vicenta Chera tiene 55 años y es dueña de un comercio en la zona del Barrio Trinidad Mariano Roque Alonso , la misma es oriunda de Asunción.
Anteriormente ella trabajaba como empleada domestica y poco a poco fue ahorrando el capital y empezó a vender cervezas, y en salón que tiene en su casa utilizando su heladera.
Luego su negocio fue creciendo y compra mas productos para vender no solo bebidas ya contaba con mercaderías de uso doméstico.
Y con el tiempo mandó hacer un pequeño salón frente a su casa  donde ofrece sus productos.
texts.en:
Vicenta Chera, 55, owns a store in Trinidad Mariano Roque Alonso neighborhood; she is originally from Asunción. She used to work as a domestic employee. Gradually, she had enough savings to start selling beer from a room in her house where she had a refrigerator. The business grew and she began to stock items besides beverages; she now had home use products. In time, she had a small room built in front of her house that she uses as a store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beverages like: sodas, wine, beer, soft-drinks.

loans.name: Kono Lorry Park Group

texts.en:
Here are members of the 'Kono Lorry Park' group. They are small-scale businesspeople in the town of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. They have come to SMT/Kiva Lenders to apply for a loan of SLL 500,000 for each person for the very first time. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses both in size and quality, attract more customers, make more sales, and consequently improving on their living conditions. 

The leader of this group is Abu Bakarr K.. Abu Bakarr has been selling shoes, clothes, vests, bras, etc. for many years now. With his share of this loan, he will invest it into his business by purchasing the above-mentioned items in wholesale. Abu Bakarr is 35; he was born in Magburaka, he is married to a businesswoman, and they have 5 children. Four of his children are in primary school and 1 is still not of school-going age. 


(On the right in the photo is Loan Officer Abdul Karim Conteh handing over the loan during disbursement.)

loans.use: Buy shoes, clothes, vests, bras, etc. for resale

loans.name: Nyakatookye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
S. Florence is in the small photo at the top left. She missed the group photo, but she is the leader of this lending group. She is 40 years old and married with six children between the ages of 10 and 22, including three dependents in her care. 

Florence deals in the sale of produce from Nyakatookye and just like the name of her business location, banana growing is the major activity that she has been dealing in for 10 years. She sells matooke (plantains) and hopes to expand her business by buying more from fellow farmers in case her stock is not enough so as to increase her income and sustain her customers. Florence needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke for resale.

loans.use: Buying more matooke for resale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Palm kernel in Nigeria is used for a lot of things like body cream and local soap. Eunice sells palm kernel to make a living. She is happy in business because of the profits and the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She hopes for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more palm kernel to sell. She is itching for expansion in her business. She is 40 years old, married, and has 4 children. Her husband sells spare motor parts to support their family. She duly says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To pay off the cost of his cooking equipment

loans.name: Olukehinde

texts.en: Olukehinde is married to a teacher and they are blessed with 2 children. Their children are doing great in school. He is a businessman. To make a living in Ibadan, he sells phone accessories. He has been in this business for a long time. His greatest challenge in his business is funds and he hopes to overcome this challenge. He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 40,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He hopes to expand his business. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell.

loans.name: Teresiah

texts.en: Teresiah is a 28-year-old married lady with two children. One child attends school.  She has been practicing poultry farming for three years but she was previously selling cereals. She has been a member of Faulu Kenya and has previously taken a loan of KES 20,000. She appreciates Faulu for helping her increase a stock to over 100 layers. Her dream is to rear over 1000 layers in the future. As a result, she has requested for KES 30,000 to add more hens and to buy chickmash for feeding the chickens. She hopes to own a home within Dagoretti in Nairobi city.

loans.use: To add more chicken & feeds.

loans.name: Determiners Group

texts.en:
Samuel G. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Determiners.  He married and has 4 children who are 5, 7, 10 and 14 years old.  In addition to his children, Samuel supports three siblings.

For 5 years, Samuel has been running a drugstore on Cooper Road, which is located just south of downtown Monrovia on Cooper Road.  He says that he provides his medicine at a reasonable price, which keeps customers returning.

Samuel plans to use his 12,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 60,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase additional medicine. His goal is to expand his business and, most importantly, to help support his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Samuel is the one holding the sign.  Dorothy K. is inset at the lower left of the photo.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine.

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is a 38-year-old father of two children who attend school.  He has been operating an electronic shop for seven years. He was previously operating a shop and a hotel. He also earns income from his motorbike, which he uses for transport.  He has been a member of Faulu Kenya and he wants to take his first loan from Faulu Kenya.  He has requested for a loan of KES 20,000 to add more stock of electronics and spare parts.  He hopes to buy a piece of land and build his own home and buy a vehicle in the future.

loans.use: Add stock of electronics.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 32 and is married with three children aged between 3 and 8. All her children go to school. The family resides and owns a two roomed house where she stays with six people. She takes care of additional family members.  The family has access to electricity and has no piped water at home.  The family has three meals a day. Her greatest monthly expenses are utility bills, school fees for children, medication and food.

Lydia has a stall where she sells second hand clothes. She buys these second hand clothes from Owino Market. This is one of the busiest markets in Kampala city and she incurs transport costs getting there and back. She receives an average of 40 customers a day. She has run this business for over twenty years. Her main challenges are defaulters, the rainy season as she works from a muddy place, and ever increasing prices for used clothes. She sells on retail basis only.

She has been with MCDT for over five years and is servicing her tenth loan, working the whole time with the same team members. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second hand clothes. She aspires to see her business grow and to start her own wholesale business.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second hand clothes

loans.name: Emiola

texts.en:
Emiola is a happy, hard working woman. She is always happy when her customers come in to purchase medicines. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells daily from 7am to 7pm. She is itching for expansion in her business. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. 

She hopes to own a maternity home in the future. She is 35 years old and is married with 2 children. Her children attend school. To support the household, her husband sells electronics. 
She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Rwempiri Tukwatanise Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
In the small photo at the top left of the group photo are two gentlemen (M. Moses and K. Frank) who can late for the group meeting but are part of the group. 

T. Richard is 40 years old and is the leader of his lending group in Ibanda. He is a friendly and cooperative man and has operated a milling business in Kasonda trading centre for 10 years. 

Richard is a married man with 5 children who have no dependants. Some of his children are not at school. From his business, he is able to make a weekly profit of 50,000/=. He hopes to expand his business so that the profits can increase. He has a milling machine. Most farmers bring their produce to him for milling. He also buys produce and mills that for sale. That is what he plans to use this loan for.

loans.use: To buy produce for milling, after which he will resell as food.

loans.name: Grupo Positivo Group

texts.es:
El comité “Grupo Positivo”  está conformada por 16 integrantes,en la ciudad de Mariano Roque Alonso, las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a varias actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable y con vistas a un crecimiento constante, con la ayuda de una asistencia financiera permanente.
Estas mujeres se dedican a varias actividades, como la señora Gloria V. quien como actividad complementaria a las labores de su casa y generar ganancia vende perfumes.
Ella ofrece sus productos a sus vecinas o en casas comerciales, sus clientes son cocidas de ellas y le pagan en cuotas ya que es la manera más fácil de colocar sus productos.
Se citan las actividades de las otras integrantes:

texts.en:
The “Grupo Positivo” committee is made up of 16 members in the city of Mariano Roque Alonso. The members of the committee are mothers who are engaged in various commercial activities aimed at strengthening their households’ economy and to develop their undertakings in a sustainable way with the goal in mind to continue growing with the help of permanent financial support. These women are engaged in a variety of activities. Gloria V., for example, besides her domestic chores, sells perfumes. Her usual customers are neighbors or store employees. All her customers are known to her and they pay her in installments since this is the most efficient way to sell her products. The other members are in the following activities: 1 Gloria V. Perfume Sales 2 Consorcia C. Food Sales 3 Mirtha F. Fruit & Vegetable Sales 4 Irma B. Beverage Sales 5 Elizabeth P. Food Sales 6 Maria A. Costume Jewelry Sales 7 Maria Luisa B. Domestic Employee 8 Adriana A. Clothing Sales 9 Ada A. Domestic Employee 10 Cinthia B. Perfume Sales 11 Florencia V. Food Sales 12 Gabriela Caceres Vegetable Sales 13 Antonia N. Food Sales 14 Leticia V. Saleswoman 15 Yaquelyn S. Clothing Sales 16 Liz G. Meat Sales

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy perfumes.

loans.name: Five Lofa Sisters Group

texts.en:
Five Lofa Sisters is a group of 5 borrowers led by Garmai H.. She is 46 years old and is married with 5 children aged 14 to 31.  Garmai did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty.

She and her family live and work in the Old Road Community in Sinkor which is about 5 miles from downtown Monrovia, Liberia.  For 19 years, Garmai has been selling foodstuffs such as rice and oil. She buys her goods wholesale and sells them retail to residents of her community. Garmai started selling with 4000 Liberian Dollars and now has 20,000 Liberian dollars as working capital.  She interacts well with customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.  Garmai will use this loan to purchase more rice and oil.  She dreams that she and her family will have a good future.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Garmai is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more rice and oil

loans.name: Musibau

texts.en:
Musibau is married and his wife sells groceries to support their family. They are blessed with a child. His child is doing great at school.

He is a business man. To make a living in Ibadan, he sells phone accessories and rechargeable phone cards. His greatest challenge in his business is funds and he hopes to overcome this challenge. He hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He hopes to expand his business. 
He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en: Joseph is a 24-year-old artisan who makes cooking pots and pans. He has hired two people, who assist him in his business. He also practices farming for extra income. He appreciates Faulu Kenya for financing his business, which has allowed him to expand, and for helping him improve his customer service skills. He hopes to expand his business further so as to support his family better, hence he has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy steel and add to his stock of tools. He dreams of having his own store in order to supply his products wholesale. He describes himself as industrious and hard-working.

loans.use: To buy steel for manufacturing

loans.name: Onondivepa Group

texts.es:
El comité “Oñondivepa” se conformo gracias a que integrantes de otro comité de mismo barrio informaron a sus vecinas acerca del programa comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y decidieron juntarse junto con sus vecinas y conformar el dicho comité. Utilizaran  su crédito para diversas opciones de compra como ser: compra de insumos para la fabricación de comestibles, compra de leche azúcar, yerba, harina, sal, panificados y verduras para su posterior venta, compra venta de ropas, bebidas, compra de cueros para la fabricación de zapatos para su posterior venta, etc
Entre sus integrantes se encuentra la señora Juana A. quien se dedca a la venta de ropa, esta actividad lo realiza de manera ambulante, ella sale de su casa tres veces por semana recorriendo varios lugares de la ciudad y de esa forma ella vende sus productos y lograr traer un poco e ingreso que ayuda para el sosten de la casa, de esta forma todas las señoras trabajan para salir adelante.
texts.en:
The Onondivepa group was formed after the members of another group in the same region talked to their neighbors about the group, Mujeres Emprendedoras. They decided to get together with their neighbors of that group. They will use their loan to fund various forms of purchasing, such as: purchase of ingredients for the production of food; to purchase milk and sugar, herbs, flour, salt, bread products and vegetables for resale; to purchase clothing, and drinks; to purchase leather for shoemaking, etc. Among their members is Juana A. and her business is clothing sales. She sells her clothing by traveling to various parts of the city sometimes three times per week. She sells her products this way and she manages to bring home some income to the home. All of the other women in the group travel hard to see their success.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing, leather for shoemaking, milk, sugar, herbs, flour, breads, other ingredients, and drinks.

loans.name: Jamal

texts.en: JamA. is a 20-year-old single man living with his parents and 2 brothers. He cooperates with his father and brothers towards the family’s income. He has been working as an electrician for the past 4 years. During those 4 years, he has built up his experience and he has become able to take on more projects and electricity maintenance work. Today, JamA. is asking to borrow $1,200 to renovate his shop and to buy new electric tools needed to meet the need of the market and to develop his work.

loans.use: to renovate his shop and to buy new electricity tools

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy staples for local population

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more planks for resale.

loans.name: Remember To Pay Group

texts.en:
Remember To Pay is a group of five borrowers led by S. K.. He is 55 years old and is married, with six children aged 14-28 years old. S. did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty. He and his family live and work in the West Point Community, near Monrovia, Liberia.

S.’s business is the selling of building materials, such as planks and hardware. He has been running this business for 25 years and hopes to open a shop in the near future. He sells good quality planks and other materials for building in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. S. will use this loan to purchase more planks and hardware. He dreams of giving his children good medical attention when needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, S. is the one holding the sign. Tenneh Tamba is inset at lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more planks and hardware.

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus M. is single and 27 years old. Justus lives in Kilifi where he owns a quarry in an area called Maweni. He has been a major supplier of stone to his area residents for two years. Justus also has a secondary business where he operates a retail shop in the area, selling household goods.

Justus is not very old in KADET and this borrowing marks his first loan to finance his business. He plans to expand his quarry and to purchase quarry equipment. He also plans to increase the stock of flour, sugar and cooking oil in his retail shop. He hopes that his quarry business will be able to expand and be able to meet the demands from the constructors around the area.

He also hopes to diversify his business further into different fields.

loans.use: To expand his quarry, purchase quarry equipment, and to increase the stock of flour, sugar and cooking oil for his retail shop.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is a businesslady who operates a cafeteria. She was previously selling suitcases and bags. Since she joined Faulu Kenya she has been able to open her cafeteria, which she has been operating for two years. She is the mother of two children and her husband is a high school principal. She has requested a loan of Kes. 80,000 to buy a chips cooker, rice and beans. She hopes to rear layers (chickens) in the future. She sees herself starting her own schools and offering catering services.

loans.use: To buy a chips cooker, rice and beans

loans.name: Mwenda

texts.en:
Mwenda M. is a 53 year old, married mother of two. She operates a quarry business in the busy Kituoni area in Kilifi. Her business is two years old and has been doing well.

Mwenda is borrowing her first loan from KADET and she plans to expand the quarry and purchase quarry equipment. Most of her customers are local residents who buy stones for construction purposes.

Mwenda hopes that her business will expand further and become a large commercial quarry. She hopes to be able to supply her stones to the big construction businesses in the area.

loans.use: To expand the quarry and purchase quarry equipment

loans.name: Carlos

texts.es:
El Señor B. es soltero es  y  se dedica a la profesión de mecánico además es propietario de un taller mecánico  que el mismo instaló en su casa.
El cuenta con 10 años de antigüedad en la  profesión y cuenta con una clientela que confiá en sus servicios ya que es una persona que demuestra siempre responsabilidad en todo momento.
Este crédito fue para compra de una camioneta que utilizará  para su  traslado hasta donde sus clientes precisen. Esta muy agradecido por la ayuda brindada por la Fundación.
texts.en:
Mr. B. is single. He is a mechanic, and he has his own mechanic’s shop. He set up the mechanic’s shop at his house. He has been in the profession for ten years. He has customers who trust in his services because he is a person who always demonstrates responsibility. This loan was to buy a van, which he will use to drive where his customers need him. He is very grateful for the help given by the Foundation.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a vehicle

loans.name: Valentina

texts.en:
Valentina sells women's clothing at an open market in Melitopol city. She started this business 17 years ago. Although Valentina was not able to significantly develop her business, it has served as a stable source of income for her family throughout those years. 

Valentina has used microloans many times and found them very instrumental. She used them to purchase stock she needed when she did not have enough cash. This time Valentina would like to borrow 13,000 UAH to increase her stock of spring clothing. Her financial goal is to finish fixing the house where she lives with her husband and daughter.

loans.use: to increase her stock of clothes for sale

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a 32 year old, single lady who operates a wholesale shop where she sells polythene papers and sweets. Her business has been running for five years and she has employed one person. 

Since she joined Faulu Kenya her business has been growing because she has increased her stock. She has requested a loan of KES 50,000 to buy polythene papers and sweets. She hopes to open a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: to buy stock of polythene and sweets

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad has owned a barbershop in his town since 1996. He is 40 years old, married, and has 2 unemployed children who still go to school. He caters to a wide range of clients in the village and its neighborhoods.  He sometimes works overtime to earn more profit to satisfy the needs of the life, such as schooling, hospitality, family expenses, etc. Today, Mohamad wishes to improve the decor of his barbershop and to install air conditioning and wood floors to attract more clients. In order to do so, Mohamad is requesting $1,200.

loans.use: to improve the decor of his barbershop by installing wood flooring and air conditioning.

loans.name: Loutfi

texts.en:
Loutfi is a 54-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their child. Loutfi has been working in construction since 1986. He also works as a home decorator. Loutfi has requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase tools for his work. This is the first time that he has requested a loan. 
Loutfi is special in his work because he does it well, and he is known in his region for his good and talented work. His clients are his friends and neighbors, as well as people from the surrounding villages. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing this business because he wanted to have independent work based on his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase tools for his work.

loans.name: Bose

texts.en:
Bose retails groceries and medicines to make a living. She hopes to own a supermarket and a maternity home in the future. She has been in this business for a long time and she uses her years of experience to attract and retain customers. She hopes to make her businesses sustainable. 

She is 45 years old and is married with 2 children. Her eldest child is 20 years old. Her children are excelling in school and this makes her happy. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more medicines and groceries to sell. She says thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines and groceries to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a serious entrepreneur who does tailoring and was previously a hairdresser. She has been in the tailoring business for five years and has employed two people. She has previously taken out two loans from Faulu Kenya, which she used to add stock, thus improving her business. Esther is a single mother of two children who attend school. She says that she hopes to further expand her business so as to improve her family’s living standard. To bring this about, she has requested a loan of Kes. 50,000 to increase her stock of fabric. Her dream is to open other similar businesses.

loans.use: To increase her stock of fabric

loans.name: Wycliffe

texts.en:
Wycliffe is 29 years old and married, with two young children aged nine months and three years old. He runs a mixed farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, where he has been farming for over five years. His primary income comes from the sale of maize and beans, while he also sells limited amounts of cereals on the side. In recent years, Wycliffe has also earned supplementary income by providing transport services on his motorbike. He says that the main challenge he currently faces in all his businesses is the great fluctuations in prices for his goods.

Wycliffe is requesting this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 20,000 to start his own poultry project. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him provide for his family's basic needs, now and in the future. In the coming years, Wycliffe wants to open a small milling farm, and he hopes that enough stability prevails in the region with market prices and the economy in general so he can accomplish his goals.

loans.use: To start a poultry project

loans.name: Hicham

texts.en:
Hicham is a 37-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their five children. Hicham has owned a pickup truck, which allows him to transport merchandise since 1992. He requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his pickup, and to save some money for his children’s expenses. Hicham has been a microcredit client for five years now and has always paid on time. 
His previous loans allowed him to continually improve his work, as well as his family’s living conditions. With his previous loans, he was able to pay for his children’s school tuition. Hicham is speciA. in his work because of his punctuality. His clients can be anyone. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work and to improve his income.

loans.use: To to do some maintenance work on his pickup.

loans.name: Force To Go # 2 Group

texts.en:
Force To Go #2 is a group of five borrowers led by Nagbe W.. He is 26 years old and is single with one child who is four years old. Nagba could not continue his education through 12th grade due to poverty.

Nagbe’s business is the sale of shoes. He buys his shoes wholesale and sells retail on a table in the Waterside Market in Monrovia. He has been running this business for six years and hopes to open a shop in the future.

Nagbe keeps his shoes in good condition in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. Nagbe will use this loan to purchase more shoes to serve customers. He dreams that he and his child will one day live in better conditions.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Nagbe is the one holding the sign. Hagar M. is inset at lower left.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 32-year-old divorced man who lives in the Bekaa with his two children. Ali has been working as a van driver for over 10 years. Working as a van driver is his day job; Ali is also a DJ. He plays in the evening at different parties. His second job is more a hobby that he does for different occasions like anniversaries, weddings, diner parties, and more. Ali requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to do some maintenance work on his van that he uses for his daytime transportation. The van also allows him to transport his DJ equipment when he has an occasion. This is his third loan and he has always paid on time. Ali is speciA. in his work because of his punctuality as a driver and his good taste in music. His clients can be anyone. He decided to do both his businesses because he wanted to have independent work and improve his family’s income. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and to purchase more sophisticated tools for his DJ business.

loans.use: To do some maintenance work on his van .

loans.name: Sleiman

texts.en: Sleiman is a 29-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa with his wife and their child. Sleiman has been working as a car repairer and painter since 2007. Sleiman is special in his work because of his clean and clear work. He decided on doing his business because he wanted to have independent work. His clients are his friends and neighbors. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase an old car and renovate it so that he can sell it. From time to time, he purchases used old cars and renovates them so that he can sell them and improve his income. This is his second loan and he has always paid on time. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase an old car and renovate it.

loans.name: Meni Group

texts.en:
Meni Group is a group of five borrowers led by Majah B.. She is 39 years old and is married, with three children aged 13-25 years old. In addition to her children, she cares for a sibling. Majah did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty.

Majah’s business is the sale of used clothes at the Waterside Market, which is the largest market in Monrovia, Liberia. She has been running this business for ten years and hopes to open a shop in the future. She sells good quality clothes to customers and has a good business relationship with her customers in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Majah will use this loan to purchase more used clothes. She dreams of providing good living conditions for her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Majah is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes.

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
Jenifer is a 73-year-old widow with six children. They range in age from 22 to 40 years old, with her two youngest children currently attending college. She operates a mixed farm in western Kenya, near the town of Kitale, and has been farming for over twenty years. While she used to focus more on fruit and vegetable production, her primary income now comes from the sale of milk, which she does personally at the local markets. She says that the main challenge currently is finding a good, reliable market for her product where she can maintain profitability.

Jenifer requested this loan through Juhudi Kilimo for Kes. 71,400 to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She will also use a portion of the money to improve the sleeping shed she built for her current livestock.

Jenifer says that with this loan she will have sufficient milk to become a supplier to the KCC - the Kenya Cooperative of Creameries. This will result in a more stable income which she will use to pay for her children's college fees and their basic needs.

Looking to the future, Jenifer hopes to build a modern grazing unit to ensure her animals are well taken care of. She feels this will help get maximum benefit out of her income-producing assets.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga R. M., tiene la edad de 28 años, está en unión libre, y vive con su compañero y una hija de 6 años. El crédito lo quiere para preparar el terreno para posteriormente sembrar arroz y maíz. Desea darle una adeacuada preparación al terreno para luego darle un buen mantenimiento a los cultivos y así lograr una mejor calidad y poder obtener un ingreso mayor cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. No es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contenta con las facilidades que se le han  brindado siempre. Ella espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productora. 

About FUDECOSUR: The Foundation for the Development of Southern Communities is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing credit and capacitating programs to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Southern Costa Rica. You can obtain more information on FUDECOSUR from the website: FUDECOSUR.org
texts.en:
Olga R. M., 28, lives with her life partner and their 6-year-old daughter. She wants funding to prepare fields for subsequent rice and corn planting. She wants to prepare the soil adequately and then give her crops proper maintenance so that her crop yields will be of the best quality and her income will be greater at harvest time. This isn't her first loan with FUDECOSUR and she is very happy with the terms she's always gotten. She hopes in the future to offer her family a better quality of life and greater economic stability and to continue to grow as a person and as a producer.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To prepare fields for rice and corn planting.

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en: Nicolas Aguero is 44 years old and has been married to Blanca Portillo for 25 years.  They have 12 children together who they care for and who Nicolas supports with his earnings working as a carpenter.  Nicolas' two oldest sons, ages 18 and 20 work with him.  The family lives on Potrerito street in Coronel Oviedo.  According to Nicolas, his work and his family's well being is his life.  He is from a family of modest means and learned his trade from his father, Lorenzo.  Nicolas is seeking the loan from Fundación Paraguaya to purchase basic materials, as he as already signed a contract with a local school to build chairs and desks.  With this loan he will be able to purchase wood in bulk for a low price.

loans.use: Purchase wood
